monogr.title: Selections from Homer's Iliad, with an introduction, notes, a short Homeric grammar, and a vocabulary
monogr.author: Allen Rogers Benner

revisionDesc.change: edited markup and assigned CTS URN

div.p: a)/eide, for the form see § 41. The Attic present is a)/|dw. Like Latin cano, it admits an object (mh=nin) in the accusative. Cf. w)|da/s tinas a)/|dontes (Xen. Anab. IV, 3, 27).
qea/, § 66; elsewhere called ‘Muse,’ but Homer applies no more definite name than this to the goddess of epic song.— *phlhia/dew, for ending, § 65, § 68; scansion, § 43; composition, § 157.
*)axilh=os, declension, § 86, § 87.
ou)lome/nhn, ‘the baneful wrath’; for spelling, § 35. Translate as closely as possible in the Greek order, so as to retain the original emphasis; here ‘wrath’ may be repeated.
muri/', elided vowel, § 40.1; meaning, § 109.
*)axaioi=s, originally a tribal name, then used for ‘Greeks’ in general.
a)/lge', elision, § 40.1; declension, § 78, § 91.
e)/qhken, ‘made,’ a common Homeric meaning of ti/qhmi.
i)fqi/mous agrees with yuxa/s, the masculine doing duty as feminine.
*)/aidi (Attic *(/aidh|, i. e. a(/|dh|), declension, § 96; as used by Homer, almost always indicates the god himself, ‘Hades.’
au)tou/s, ‘the men themselves,’ ta\ sw/mata, in contrast with the yuxa/s.
teu=xe, not augmented, § 125.
ku/nessin (Attic kusi/ for kun + si), declension. § 78, § 82.
oi)wnoi=si, declension, § 73, § 76.
*dio/s, declension, § 98.
d'(e/), ‘while’; it will be observed that de/ must often be rendered not by this word only, but also by ‘for’ and even ‘although.’
e)telei/eto, spelling, § 150.
boulh/, the ‘purpose’ to defeat the Achaeans and to confer honor on the injured Achilles, in answer to Thetis's prayer; all this will be developed later.
e)c ou(= ktl. (kai\ ta\ loipa/ = et cetera), ‘from the time when once they quarreled and parted’; to be joined in thought with l. 1: ‘sing of the wrath from the time when’ etc.
diasth/thn, not augmented, § 125.
*)atrei+/dhs, formation, § 157. Agamemnon is meant, as is suggested by the appositive a)/nac a)ndrw=n. In another context the word might indicate his brother Menelaus as well (cf. 3.347, 350, 361).
a)/nac, on the hiatus, § 25, § 27, 60.
*)axilleu/s, spelled with two l's (compare *)axilh=os, l. 1), § 39.

With an art that has formed a model for succeeding epic poets, Homer takes up the story in the very middle with an exciting incident. What has gone before he allows to come to light gradually. The incidents of the Iliad occupy about seven weeks (forty-nine days) of the tenth year of the siege of Troy (cf. B 134, 295, 296); the first book occupies twenty-one days of this time.
a)/r, on the different forms of this little word, which, though indicating various shades of feeling, is often untranslatable, see § 49.1.
sfwe, enclitic pronoun, third person, accusative dual, § 110.
qew=n, partitive genitive with ti/s.
cun-e/hke, the syllabic augment points to the fact that i(/hmi originally began with a consonant; on the spelling, § 41.
ma/xesqai, syntax, § 212.
*lhtou=s, form, § 94.
ui(o/s, named in l. 14.
o(/, personal pronoun, § 118.2.
basilh=i (Attic basilei=), declension, § 86.
a)na\ strato/n, ‘through the camp.’
o)le/konto, poetic verb: ‘and the soldiers kept dying.’ On neglect of augment, § 125.
laoi/, declension and Attic equivalent, § 77.
ou(/neka, ‘because’; form, § 45.
to/n, probably demonstrative, § 118.1: ‘that’ Chryses, celebrated in epic song.
a)rhth=ra, composition, § 156.1.
nh=as, declension, § 101; Attic nau=s (GG. 136).
luso/menos expresses purpose.— qu/gatra (Attic qugate/ra), § 85.— a)/poina, probably in the form of gold, bronze, and raiment.

‘With the fillet of far-darting Apollo in his hands, upon a golden staff.’ In classical times suppliants regularly carried boughs entwined with wool, when urging their petitions, as is shown by various passages in later literature. Here the priest brings the sacred woolen fillet of his god on his own priestly staff. If ste/mmat'(a)—and not ste/mma t'(e)—is the true reading, the plural is probably used with reference to the parts of wool that composed the fillet; cf. notes on 3.29, 55. Below (l. 28) the singular occurs.
e(khbo/lou, short ultima in scansion, § 25.1.
*)apo/llwnos, quantity of initial vowel, § 30.
xruse/w| (Attic xrusw=|), lack of contraction. § 41; synizesis, § 43; the resulting syllable scanned short, § 25, 1. As to the meaning of ‘golden’ staff, see note on l. 246.
*)atrei+/da, accusative dual, § 65.
du/w, Attic du/o.
kosmh/tore, composition, § 156.1.
e)uknh/mides, ‘well-greaved’; see Introduction on Homeric armor. 30.
qeoi/, scanned as one syllable, § 43.
doi=en, why optative? § 201.
*pria/moio, declension, § 73.
po/lin, the ultima, though short, receives the ictus, § 32.

e)u/ = Attic eu)=. In the text this adverb is printed as two syllables in the fourth foot before the bucolic diaeresis ( § 11, § 19) and in the second half of the fifth foot. In other places in the verse both the contracted and the resolved forms occur.
lu=sai ... de/xesqai, infinitives for imperatives, § 213.
ta/, probably demonstrative, § 118.1.
a(zo/menoi agrees with u(mei=s understood.
e)p-eu-fh/mhsan, ‘cried out in approval’; the temporal augment is neglected, unnecessarily, for the reading might as well be e)p-hu-fh/mhsan.
ai)dei=sqai, complementary to e)peufh/mhsan, which amounts to a verb of commanding: ‘to reverence the priest.’
q' = te.
i(erh=a, like basilh=a (Attic basile/a_), § 86.
de/xqai, spelling, § 131.
ou)k ... h(/ndane, ‘it [i. e. to respect the priest and to accept the ransom] pleased not Agamemnon in his heart.’
h(/ndane, on the hiatus, § § 27; 61, 1.
qumw=|, syntax, § 177 (a).
e)pi\ ... e)/tellen, tmesis, § 163, § 165.
mu=qon, ‘threat.’
mh/ se ... kixei/w, ‘let me not find you’ § 193).
koi/lh|sin, declension, § 65, § 71; Attic koi/lais.
nhusi/, declined, § 101.
kixei/w, where found? § 149.
toi, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
th/n, personal pronoun, § 118.2.
pri/n ktl., ‘ere then shall old age overtake her.’
min, enclitic pronoun, here = Attic au)th/n, § 110. It may be used for masculine and neuter also.
For the hiatus between h(mete/rw| and e)ni/ (Attic e)n) see § 25.4.
oi)/kw| originally began with a consonant, § 61.28.
e)n *)/argei+ (declined like e)/pos, § § 91 and 41), the district in the Peloponnesus ruled by Agamemnon; the seat of his power was Mycenae. Cf. note on l. 79.
pa/trhs (Attic patri/dos), syntax, § 175.

‘Moving to and fro before the loom and sharing my bed.’ The construction of le/xos is remarkable; it may be considered a “limit of motion” accusative § 179); but elsewhere a)ntia/w takes a partitive genitive.
saw/teros, in emphatic position, to be translated after w(s.
ke, enclitic particle, § 49.3.
ne/hai, form, § 142.1; syntax, § 196.
w(\s e)/fat'(o) = Attic ou(/tws e)/fh.
e)/ddeisen, for double d, § 62.1; n movable in spite of the following d'(e/), § 50.
o( ge/rwn, § 119 (a).
bh=, accent, § 126.
para\ qi=na, ‘along the strand.’
polufloi/sboio, imitative of the sound of the wind-swept sea.
polla/, object of h)ra=q' (= h)ra=to, from a)ra/omai): ‘earnestly prayed.’
o( geraio/s, use of article, § 119 (a).
to/n, relative pronoun, § 118.4; cf. ‘that’ in English.
meu, enclitic pronoun, § 110; contraction, § 42.
a)mfibe/bhkas, to be translated by present tense, ‘guardest,’ § 187. The metaphor involved is illustrated by the line:
a)mfi\ d' a)/r' au)tw=| bai=n) w(/s tis peri\ po/rtaki mh/thr (P 4), ‘Menelaus strode before him [the slain Patroclus] like a cow before her calf,’ to give protection. Compare also E 299.
zaqe/hn, composition, § 160.
te i)=fi, hiatus, § 61.21.

ei/ pote ktl., ‘if ever I roofed overhead a temple pleasing in thy sight.’ The temple plays no further part in the story of Chryses; but the altar does appear later. In the earlier times the gods were worshiped at altars in the open air; but some distinct references to temples will be noticed later in the poem (E 446-448; Z 274, 279, 297).
nho/n, declension, § 77.
kata\ ... e)/kha (Attic kate/kausa), § 163, § 165.
h)d'(e/), common Homeric equivalent of kai/.
krh/hnon (Attic kra=non), from kraiai/nw (Attic krai/nw).
e)e/ldwr, spelling, § 61.13.
‘May the Danaans pay for my tears by thy shafts.’ ti/seian, syntax, § 201.
*danaoi/, another name for the ‘Greeks’ in general, regarded as the ‘people of Danaus,’ the mythical Argive king.
soi=si, meaning, § 113; declension, § 76.
be/lessin, declined like e)/pos, § 91, § 83.
tou=, personal pronoun, § 118.2.
kat' *ou)lu/mpoio karh/nwn, ‘down from the summits of Olympus.’— *ou)lu/mpoio = Attic *)olu/mpou.
karh/nwn, declined, § 100.
kh=r, accusative, ‘at heart.’
to/ca, a single bow; plural because made of parts fitted together.
w)/moisin, declension, § 76; syntax, § 177.
fare/trhn, spelling, § 64.
xwome/noio, of him ‘in his anger.’
au)tou= kinhqe/ntos, ‘as the god started up.’
h)/ie, Attic h)/|ei, from ei)=mi.
e)oikw/s, for the original spelling cf. § 61.24.
new=n, declension, § 101.
me/ta, adverb, § 162, § 164.
e(/hken, see note on l. 8.
‘And a dreadful clang arose from the silver bow.’ With the imitative words e)/klagcan (l. 46) and klaggh/ compare li/gce bio/s (4.125), which expresses a similar idea.
a)rgure/oio, uncontracted, § 41.
ou)rh=as, declined like basileu/s, § 86.
e)p-w/|xeto, ‘he assailed.’

‘But next he sped his keen shaft at the men themselves [au)toi=si] and kept shooting.’—Either be/los (note the long ultima) e)xepeuke/s illustrates ictus lengthening § 33) or the force of the original sigma of [s]exepeuke/s is still felt.
ba/ll', elision, § 40.1.
ai)ei/ = Attic a)ei/.
neku/wn, genitive of material with purai/ (cf. GG. 506).
qamei=ai, to be translated in the predicate, after the Greek order: ‘thickly,’ one after another.
kh=la = be/lea (cf. l. 51).
th=| deka/th|, ‘on the tenth day,’ like the Attic construction.
a)gorh/nde, spelling, § 64; suffix, § 155.5.
kale/ssato, double sigma, § 53.
tw=|, personal pronoun, § 118.2; syntax, § 176.
fresi/, fre/nes, diaphragm of the body; used by the Greeks for the seat of thought and emotion; cf. English ‘heart.’—Here (Attic ‘Hera’) and Athene (Attic ‘Athena’) were hostile to the Trojans. Why?
o(ra=to, § 125. Homer uses the middle of this verb in active sense.
h)/gerqen, form, § 136.8.
toi=si, dative of interest § 176), ‘rising up before them.’

de/ here has the force of a weakened dh/, ‘then,’ § 31. It can not be translated in this place by ‘but’ or ‘and’; yet by some it is believed to have once had that force, even here, surviving as a relic of the time when, in primitive language, all clauses were coördinated—when there was no “hypotaxis,” but only “parataxis.”
a)/mme, pronoun of first person, § 110.

plagxqe/ntas, from pla/zw, —‘Now I think that we, driven back, shall return home again, if possibly we should escape death—if, in fact, both war and pestilence are at the same time to destroy the Achaeans.’
ei)/ ken ... fu/goimen § 208) expresses a possibility more remote than ei) ... dama=| (l. 61).
ei) dh/, ‘if in fact’ is nearly equivalent to ‘since in fact.’
dama=| (future indicative, § 151) agrees with one subject only, like xrai/smh|, l. 28.
e)rei/omen, form, § 148; hortatory.
te, observe that this word helps out the meter and also accompanies a general statement; it is often not to be translated.
‘Who may say [potential—or “hypothetical”—optative, § 206] why Phoebus Apollo has become so much angered.’
to/sson, spelling, § 51.1.
o(/ g'(e), ‘he,’ with very slight emphasis.
eu)xwlh=s, e(kato/mbhs, genitives of cause; the vow may have been unfulfilled, the hecatomb neglected.
‘In the hope that when he has shared in the savor of unblemished lambs and goats, he may be willing to avert destruction from us’; cf. § 198.
ai) = Attic ei).
kni/shs, partitive genitive with a)ntia/sas.
bou/letai, subjunctive? § 147.
h(mi=n, dative of advantage (interest), ‘from us’; literally ‘for us.’
a)po\ ... a)mu=nai, tmesis, § 163.
h)= toi, often ‘to be sure,’ here little more than ‘well.’
kat' ... e(/zeto = Attic e)kaqe/zeto.
toi=si, cf. l. 58.
*qestori/dhs, composition, § 157.
What makes o(/s a long syllable? § 37.— ta\ e)o/nta = Attic ta\ o)/nta, ‘the present’: ta\ e)sso/mena = ta\ e)so/mena, ‘the future’; ta\ pro\ e)o/nta, ‘the past.’
te ... te ... te, ‘both ... and ... and.’
nh/essi, form, § 101.
ei)/sw, adverb, to be translated before *)/ilion, which is an accusative of limit of motion.
‘By means of his seer's art, which Phoebus Apollo had given to him.’
h(/n, possessive adjective, § 113; not an Attic prose word.
th/n, relative, § 118.4.
oi(, enclitic pronoun, § 110. Homer uses this word commonly as a personal pronoun, while in Attic Greek it is normally an indirect reflexive only.
sfin, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
ke/leai, form, § 142.1. Calchas felt himself bidden to speak on account of his preëminence among the seers; cf. l. 62.
muqh/sasqai, ‘to interpret,’ ‘to explain.’
Note that the ultima of *)apo/llwnos is long before e(kathbele/tao § 37). For declension of the latter word see § 65.
e)re/w, form, § 41.
su/nqeo, form, § 142.2, a.
o)/mosson, spelling, § 53.
h)= me/n § 31) = Attic h)= mh/n, used in asseverations: ‘yea verily’ or ‘in very truth.’
pro/frwn, ‘with all your heart,’ agreeing with subject of o)/mosson (GG. 571), but belonging in sense with the understood subject (‘you’) of a)rh/cein.
e)/pesin ( § 91, § 50) kai\ xersi/n, ‘in word and in deed.’
h)= ga\r ktl., ‘for truly I think I shall enrage a man.’
xolwse/men, infinitive, § 137.2.
*)argei+/wn, ‘Argives,’ a third name for the Greeks, the other two being *danaoi/ (l. 42) and *)axaioi/.

*)arge/ioi meant originally the people dwelling in *)/argos, which at first seems to have indicated the plain of central Thessaly, neighboring to *(ella/s. But the name *)/argos (or *)/argos *)axaiiko/n, as it is four times called) was early extended to the whole Peloponnesus. The Thessalian district is once called ‘Pelasgic Argos,’ in distinction (B 681).—The *)axaioi/ once dwelt in southern Thessaly—in *(ella/s and *fqi/h, apparently adjacent but distinct districts. The important fact is that the poets use these names (*)arge/ioi and *)axaioi/) freely to indicate all the Greeks; while the name so used later—*(/ellhnes—stands in Homer for a single tribe only, that dwelt in *(ella/s (of southern Thessaly). Even of the Homeric Hellas the boundaries are indefinite, and traces of an application of the name more extended than its original use appear in late parts of the Homeric poems (I 447, 478, Od. 1.344, Od. 4.726, 816, Od. 15.80).
oi( is dative singular, as is shown by the fact that it is enclitic: ‘him [in English, ‘whom’] the Achaeans obey.’
krei/sswn, spelling, § 56.
basileu/s, supply e)sti/, as very often. —On omission of a)/n or ke with the present general protasis, see § 197.
xw/setai, subjunctive, § 144, II.
‘For even if he swallows his anger for that day, indeed, yet [a)lla/] he keeps a grudge afterward in his heart, until he satisfies it.’
ei) ...katape/yh|, in same construction as xw/setai (l. 80).
te ... te, not translatable, accompanying the general statement, as often in Homer.
o)/fra tele/ssh| (spelling, § 52), present general protasis § 197).— o)/fra is poetic only; the Attic equivalent here is e(/ws, me/xri, or a similar word.
sth/qessin, declension, § 91, § 52.
fra/sai ei), ‘consider whether.’

qarsh/sas, ‘pluck up courage’; as the present of this verb indicates a state or condition, ‘to be courageous,’ the aorist may denote the entrance into that condition (GG. 464); this principle is frequently illustrated in the text of Homer.
ma/la, ‘surely,’ ‘without fail,’ strengthens ei)pe/. Account for the hiatus; § 61.16.
qeopro/pion, note that the last syllable, though short, receives the ictus; § 33.
ou), translate the negative later with tis (l. 88), before which in fact it is repeated.
w(=| te, the te is not translatable, § 123.3: ‘by prayer to whom, Calchas, you reveal oracles to the Danaans.’
e)meu= § 110) zw=ntos ... derkome/noio, genitive absolute.
soi/, after e)pi/ in composition.
e)poi/sei, future of e)pi-fe/rw.
koi/lh|s, cf. l. 26.
*danaw=n, partitive genitive with ou)/ tis (l. 88).
*)agame/mnona ei)/ph|s, account for the hiatus; § 61.16.
pollo/n, ‘by far,’ declension, § 105.
qa/rshse, cf. note on l. 85.
hu)/dae, au)da/w.
ou)d'(e/), ‘for ... not’; cf. notes on ll. 5 and 124.
tou)/neka, form, § 45.

prin ... pri/n (l. 98) = Attic pro/teron (or pro/sqen) ... pri/n: in translation omit the former pri/n. What construction follows pri/n in Attic Greek after a negative clause? See note on B 414 and cf. GG. 644 b and d.
*danaoi=si, for dative cf. l. 67, h(mi=n.
a)pw/sei, future of a)p-wqe/w.
a)po\ ... do/menai, tmesis, § 163.
do/menai, form, § 137.1, b. The subject ‘they’ (supply tina/) is purposely indefinite.
kou/rhn = Attic ko/rhn. Cf. the accusative plural ko/ras (Xen. Anab. IV, 5, 9).
Explain q', comparing l. 23.
*xru/shn, here the name of the place, not of the person.
i(lassa/menoi, spelling, § 53.
pepi/qoimen, form, § 128. ‘Then may we propitiate and persuade him.’
min = au)to/n.
me/neos, form, § 91. ‘With rage his gloomy heart was brimming’ (‘was greatly filled’).—On fre/nes cf. note, l. 55.
o)/sse de/ oi( § 61.6), ‘and his eyes’; syntax of oi(, § 176.
e)i/kthn, pluperfect dual from e)/oika § 61.24), ‘were like.’

ka/k' o)sso/menos, ‘with evil look,’ a phrase contrasting with e)u\ frone/wn, l. 73. The penult of the adjective kaka/ (cf. 3.86, doli/x') receives an acute accent, as is regular when there is elision of the originally accented syllable. The rule applies likewise to pronouns (e)/m', l. 133), verbs (ei)/s', l. 566), etc.; but prepositions and conjunctions lose their accent if the accented syllable is elided (GG. 34 a, b).
pros-e/eipen § 61.16) = Attic prosei=pen.
‘Evils are always dear to your heart to prophesy.’
manteu/esqai § 211) limits fi/la, ‘dear for prophesying’; the original dative force of the infinitive is here quite apparent (GG. 562).
e)sqlo/n = Attic a)gaqo/n, here in sense of ‘pleasant,’ ‘gratifying.’— What is the metrical quantity of the ultima of ei)=pas in its position before e)/pos? § 61.16.
w(s dh\ tou=d' e(/neka, ‘that doubtless for this reason,’ defined in the following line.
sfin, see l. 73.
ou(/neka, ‘because,’ as in l. 11.
*xrushi/dos, composition, § 158.— The ‘ransom of the maid Chryseis’ means the ransom offered for her.
bou/lomai, ‘prefer.’
*klutaimnh/strhs, genitive after the comparative idea in probe/boula. The correct ancient spelling of this name is *klutaimh/strh (Attic -a_).
e)pei\ ou)/ e(qen ktl., ‘since she is not inferior to her,’ literally ‘since she [Chryseis] is not worse than she [Clytaemnestra].’
ou)/ e(qen, why not ou)x? § 61, § 6; 110.
xerei/wn = Attic xei/rwn.

de/mas ktl., accusatives of specification. This line seems to summarize the excellent qualities of the Homeric woman: de/mas, ‘figure,’ fuh/n, ‘growth,’ ‘stature,’ fre/nas, ‘sense,’ e)/rga, ‘handiwork.’ The Homeric man should have fuh/, fre/nes, and a)gorhtu/s, ‘power of discourse’ (Od. 8.168).
ti, ‘at all.’
kai\ w(/s, ‘even so,’ i. e. although all this is true.—With do/menai supply ‘her’ as object.—After to/ ge supply e)sti/, the very common Homeric ellipsis.
bou/lom', elision, § 40.3.
e)/mmenai, form, § 137.6.
h)/, ‘rather than.’
oi)=os, ‘alone,’ not to be confused with oi(=os, ‘such as.’
e)/w (Attic w)=), subjunctive of ei)mi/, in a purpose clause introduced by o)/fra, which is here a final conjunction (Attic i(/na); compare l. 82, an example of the temporal use.
ou)de\ e)/oiken, account for the hiatus; § 61.24. ‘It is not seemly at all’ for me to lack a prize.
to/ ge, ‘this,’ demonstrative § 118.1), referring to the following clause.
o(/ moi § 176) ge/ras ktl., ‘that my prize goes elsewhere.’
h)mei/beto, cf. a)p-ameibo/menos (l. 84).
ga/r, [your demand is unfair and impossible,] ‘for’ etc. It is perhaps as well, however, not to attempt to render ga/r, if the translation is likely to be cumbersome. ‘Why!’ often gives it (GG. 672).
‘For we do not longer [e)/ti] know of common goods treasured up anywhere in abundance.’ In translation, ou)de/ may be rendered as two words (‘and ... not,’ ‘for ... not’) if it seems better.
i)/dmen, form, § 57.
cunh/ia = Attic koina/, here a substantive.
kei/mena, the familiar passive, in meaning, of ti/qhmi = ‘deposit.’
polla/ is a predicate adjective.
ta\ ... ta/, § 118.4 and 1: ‘what we plundered from the cities —that is distributed.
poli/wn (Attic po/lewn) declined, § 103.
e)/c, why accented? § 166.
‘And it is not right for the soldiers to gather these things again and make a common store of them’; literally ‘to bring together these things collected again.’
th/nde, Chryseis.
qew=|, ‘in honor of the god.’
pro/-es (pro-i/hmi), ‘let go forth,’ ‘yield.’
*)axaioi/, ‘we Achaeans’; note the person of the verb of which *)axaioi/ is subject.
ai)/ ke, Attic e)a/n.
dw=|si, form, § 136.6; this is easily recognized as the protasis of the more vivid future—or “simple future”—condition (cf. GG. 650).— e)calapa/cai, ‘to sack,’ purpose.
dh\ ou(/tws, pronounced as if written d' ou(/tws, § 43.

a)gaqo/s per e)w/n, ‘even though you are brave.’ per has the force of kai/ often in dependent clauses (cf. l. 81) and in constructions with the participle, such as this line illustrates; the participle is concessive. Sometimes both kai/ and per occur with the same participle (as ll. 217, 577). kai/per (one word) with concessive participle is familiar in Attic Greek (GG. 593 b).
mh\ ... kle/pte no/w|, ‘do not seek to deceive me in your heart’ (locative).

pareleu/somai (from par-e/rxomai), ‘outstrip,’ ‘overreach,’ metaphor from racing.—Achilles has frankly demanded that Agamemnon give up Chryseis; and he offers, in return, an unsubstantial chance of payment when the city of Troy is taken—a somewhat remote possibility. So, Agamemnon thinks, Achilles is holding out to him an illusory hope, and is keeping some ulterior motive hidden.

h)/, Latin an, ‘or perhaps,’ ‘is it that,’ introduces the second part of a double question, the first being implied and more or less indefinite. Most editors prefer h)= (‘truly’) here. Pope gives the idea of the line thus:
Shall I my prize resign
With tame content, and thou possess'd of thine?
A more literal rendering is: ‘is it that you wish—so that you yourself may keep your prize—me on the contrary [au)ta/r] to sit in “tame content” [au)/tws] bereft [deuo/menon] of mine?’
e)/xh|s, introduced by o)/fra (= Attic i(/na), expresses purpose.
e)/m', accented; cf. note on ka/k', l. 105.
deuo/menon, said to be Aeolic; the Attic lacks the u, which is the vocalized v.
ke/leai, cf. l. 74.

a)lla/, as usual, indicates that something is to be said quite different from the preceding context; it is derived from a)/lla, i. e. ‘otherwise.’ Do not translate by ‘but,’ unless this word is clearly demanded by the sequence of ideas; here ‘yet’ will do. Compare note on ll. 81, 82.
a)/rsantes, a)rari/skw.
o(/pws a)nta/cion e)/stai, § 200 (a). As the conclusion of this condition understand eu)= e(cei, ‘it will be well.’
ei) ... ke, Attic equivalent? Cf. l. 128.
dw/wsin, form, § 149 (5).
e)gw\ de/ § 31; cf. l. 58), ‘then I.’
ken ... e(/lwmai, syntax, § 192.
*ai)/antos, the son of Telamon is always meant, unless the poet expressly indicates the other Ajax, the son of Oïleus.
i)w/n, ‘going’ to your hut, or Ajax's, etc.
*)odush=os, declined like *)axilh=os, l. 1.
ken kexolw/setai, an instance of ken with the future perfect indicative, a construction foreign to Attic Greek; see § 190.
o(/n, syntax, § 179.
ken ... i(/kwmai, protasis of the more vivid future condition (cf. GG. 650, 616 a). With what prefix is i(/kwmai used in the equivalent Attic?
h)= toi, ‘to be sure.’
kai/, ‘even’ or ‘also.’
nh=a (Attic nau=n), declension, § 101.
e)ru/ssomen, ‘let us launch,’ form, § 144, II; double s, § 53.
e)\n d'(e/), ‘and there,’ in the ship; for accent see § 164.
a)gei/romen, where found? § 144, II.
e)/s, ‘within,’ ‘therein,’ § 164.
qei/omen, another hortatory subjunctive; on spelling, § 144, l.— a)/n (Attic a)na/), ‘on board,’ form, § 46.

bh/somen, § 144, II; this causative first aorist is not supplied in Attic Greek by bai/nw, but by biba/zw. So the Attic equivalent is biba/swmen. —The subject of e)/stw is ei(=s tis, to which a)nh\r boulhfo/ros is in apposition; a)rxo/s is a predicate nominative. ‘Let somebody—a man of good counsel—be captain.’
*)odusseu/s, here with two s's, with only one in l. 138; § 39.
‘That you may offer sacrifices and propitiate’ etc.
i(la/sseai, mood and tense, § 144, II; double s, § 53.
to/n, object of prose/fh.
u(po/dra i)dw/n, why is the hiatus possible? § 61.23.
On translating the tense of i)dw/n see § 186.
Agamemnon's threat to rob Achilles of his prize, Briseis, is quite sufficient to call forth the passionate speech that follows.
w)/ moi (dative of interest), exclamatory, ‘ah me!’
e)pi-eime/ne, ‘clothed in,’ vocative of perfect participle of e)pi-e/nnumi. Why is i of e)pi- not elided? § 61.20.
pei/qhtai, syntax, § 194.
o(do\n e)lqe/menai, ‘so as to go on an expedition.’

o(do/n, accusative of the space or way over which an action extends; the construction is somewhat akin to that of the cognate accusative. Cf. l. 496, Z 292.— e)lqe/menai, form, § 137.1, a; syntax like ma/xesqai, l. 8. The expression may refer to going to ambush, one of the bravest feats of Homeric warfare (l. 227); others understand it of the journey just proposed.
h)/luqon = Attic h)=lqon.
ai)xmhta/wn, declension, § 65.
maxesso/menos, scansion, § 32; spelling, § 53; = Attic maxou/menos. What is the force of the future here? Cf. luso/menos, l. 13.
moi, ‘in my sight.’
h)/lasan, ‘drove away.’
me/n, same as mh/n.
e)ribw/laki, prefix, § 160.
h)=, ‘truly.’
With polla/ supply e)sti/.
oi)/rea (from ou)=ros) = Attic o)/rh (o)/ros).
skio/enta, h)xh/essa, composition, § 159.—Why does not te (before h)xh/essa) suffer elision? § 61.5.
timh\n a)rnu/menoi, ‘to win recompense’; the present participle here expresses purpose and attendant circumstance (GMT. 840).
pro\s *trw/wn, ‘from the Trojans.’—tw=n oi)/ ti ktl., ‘all this you neither heed nor regard at all.’
metatre/ph|, how else might the form have been written? § 142.1, a.
a)fairh/sesqai, future in indirect discourse: ‘you threaten you will take away.’
e)/pi, why accented on the penult? § 166.
po/ll', for the accent cf. note on ka/k', l. 105.
ui(=es, declension, § 107.
me/n, again the same as mh/n, § 31.
soi\ i)=son, ‘equal to you,’ i. e. ‘equal to yours,’ a conciseness of expression that will be noticed more than once again (e. g. 3.238).—Why is e of pote not elided? § 61.27.
i)=son has short initial vowel in Attic.
o(ppo/t' (spelling, § 51.1) ... e)kpe/rswsi, supply the omitted particle, to make the clause normal Attic Greek. Cf. § 197.
to\ plei=on, ‘the greater part.’ Later (I 328, 329) Achilles claims to have sacked twelve cities by sea, and eleven by land in the Troad.
xei=res e)mai/, ‘my hands,’ in Attic would be ai( e)mai\ xei=res.
a)ta/r, same as au)ta/r, l. 51, etc., § 31.
h)/n in present general condition, as in Attic (GG. 650); so differing from the construction of ll. 163, 164, in form, rather than in force.
After ge/ras supply e)sti/.
o)li/gon te fi/lon te, a prize ‘little but none the less dear.’
nh=as, declension, § 101.
e)pei/ ke (= Attic e)ph/n or e)pa/n) ka/mw is equivalent to what sort of protasis? Cf. h)/n pote ... i(/khtai, l. 166.
*fqi/hnd'(e), composition, § 155.5.
i)/men, where found? § 137.7.
s', for soi/, § 40.4.
‘Nor do I intend, without honor here as I am, to amass wealth and riches for you.’ a)fu/ssein, literally, is ‘to draw’ full draughts of a liquid; its use here is metaphorical, of course.
feu=ge ma/l'(a), the imperative strengthened as in l. 85, ma/la ei)pe/.
e)p-e/ssutai (from e)pi-sseu/w), for translation see § 187; for double s, § 39.
ei(/nek' e)mei=o § 110) = Attic e)mou= e(/neka.—Why pa/r' and not par', i. e. pa/ra and not para/? § 167.
ke ... timh/sousi, form, § 146; syntax, § 190.
mhti/eta, form, § 67.
e)ssi, form, § 136.2.
diotrefe/wn basilh/wn § 86). The poet regularly represents kings as cherished by Zeus, king of the gods, just as minstrels and harpists are in favor with the Muses and Phoebus Apollo.
kartero/s, spelling, § 58.
ei) ... e)ssi, simple present supposition, as in Attic Greek (GG. 647).
pou, ‘doubtless.’
sh=|s § 113), Attic sai=s.
se/qen, where found? § 110.
kote/ontos (agreeing with se/qen), ‘in your wrath.’

w(s means ‘as’; after this line a correlative clause, ‘so shall I take away Briseis,’ would be expected; but after an interruption (th\n me\n ... pe/myw), which disturbs the construction, the main thought is loosely resumed with e)gw\ de/ ke ktl. (l. 184).
e)/m' (for accent cf. l. 133), one of the two accusative objects of the verb of depriving; but compare the construction of l. 161.
nhi\ e)mh=|, ‘a ship of mine,’ the regular Attic expression also. Agamemnon had 100 ships, according to B 576.
k' a)/gw, syntax, § 192.
*brishi/da, formation, § 158.
klisi/hnde, suffix, § 155.5.
to\ so\n ge/ras, ‘that prize of yours.’
o(/sson, spelling, § 51.3.
se/qen, why genitive? § 175.
kai/, ‘even’ or ‘also.’

i)=son, neuter cognate accusative with fa/sqai (fhmi/): ‘to speak on a footing with me.’ Yet considerable freedom of speech—for princes, at least—was recognized in the Homeric assembly (cf. I 32, 33).
o(moiwqh/menai § 137.1, b) a)/nthn, ‘to make himself like me [‘to make himself my peer’], face to face’; the passive infinitive is apparently used reflexively here.
*phlei+/wni, formation, § 157.—e)n de/ oi( ktl., ‘and his heart in his shaggy breast.’
de/ oi(, on the hiatus, § 61.6; syntax, § 176.
e)russa/menos, original spelling, § 61.19.

para\ mhrou=, ‘from the thigh,’ where the sword hung suspended in its sheath by a strap that passed probably over the right shoulder. The sword hung at the left side, so that the right hand could more easily draw it from its sheath.

The four optatives in this and the following line stand in indirect questions, in the secondary sequence (after mermh/ricen), for deliberative subjunctives of the original thought § 209). Achilles said to himself: tou\s me\n a)nasth/sw (‘shall I force these men to rise,’ with reference to a violent dismissal of the assembly); *)atrei+/dhn d' e)nari/zw; h)e\ xo/lon pau/sw e)rhtu/sw te qumo/n;
o(\ d'(e/), here and in some other places in Homer, does not imply a change of subject. What is the Attic use? See GG. 549 b.
h(=os = Attic e(/ws.

h(=lqe de/, another instance of de/ meaning ‘then’; see notes on ll. 58 and 137. At just the right moment, when the situation is getting more and more perplexing, the goddess appears on the scene, and the difficulty is solved. This device—the interference of a god—is common in the Attic drama (deus ex machina).
ou)rano/qen, suffix, § 155.2.
pro/, ‘forth’ or ‘forward.’—h(=ke, i(/hmi.
sth=, accent, § 126.
o)/piqen = o)/pisqen, in Attic prose.
ko/mhs, syntax, § 172.
oi)/w| fainome/nh, ‘appearing to him alone.’
o(ra=to, what is the Attic equivalent? Cf. note on l. 56.
qa/mbhsen, ‘was struck with wonder’; see note on qarsh/sas, l. 85.
deinw\ ktl., ‘for her eyes shone terribly.’
deinw/, adjective with adverbial force.
fa/anqen, form, § 136.8. The expression reflects Athene's epithet, glaukw=pis (l. 206).
min, with pros-hu/da (cf. hu)/dae, l. 92).
fwnh/sas, ‘began’ and ‘addressed’ (proshu/da). On scansion of this line see § 4.
ti/pt'(e), form, § 48.—What is the ‘aegis’ of Zeus? See Introduction, 29.—ei)lh/louqas, e)/rxomai.
‘Is it that you may see?’ etc.
*)atrei+/dao, declension, § 65.
e)/k, I will speak ‘out.’
e)re/w, cf. l. 76.
tele/esqai, tense, § 151.
a)\n ... o)le/ssh| § 53), syntax, § 192.
au)=te, ‘again,’ ‘in turn.’
pau/sousa, what does the tense express? Cf. l. 13.
to\ so\n me/nos, ‘this anger of yours’; cf. l. 185.
pi/qhai, form, § 142.1; syntax, § 198.
mhde\ ... e(/lkeo § 142.1), ‘draw no further.’
h)= toi, ‘to be sure,’ ‘yet.’
o)nei/dison, literally ‘upbraid,’ here may be rendered: ‘threaten with reproachful words’ (e)/pesin).
w(s e)/setai/ per, ‘how it shall even come to pass.’ On the force of per, cf. note on l. 131.
e)/setai = Attic e)/stai (l. 212); a third form, par-e/ssetai, is seen in l, 213; a fourth, e)ssei=tai, will be met, B 393.
‘Some day even thrice as many splendid gifts shall come to you, on account of this insolence’ of Agamemnon.
u(/brios, genitive, declined like po/lis, § 103.
i)/sxeo, pei/qeo, formed like e(/lkeo, l. 210.
ei)ru/ssasqai, ‘to observe,’ ‘obey’; the subject is me understood; the object, e)/pos.
kai\ ... per, see note on l. 131.
qumw=|, syntax, § 177 (a).
kexolwme/non agrees with me understood.
o(/s ke ... e)pipei/qhtai is the protasis of what kind of condition? Cf. GG. 616 a.
e)/kluon, the gnomic aorist § 184) is regarded as a primary tense.

h)=, ‘he spoke’ = Attic e)/fh; common in the Attic formula, h)= d' o(/s, Latin inquit, ‘said he’; not to be confused with the adverb h)=, ‘truly. This whole sentence, it will be observed, may be well translated nearly, if not quite, in the Greek order.
sxe/qe, form, § 154.2.
w)=se, w)qe/w.
bebh/kei, meaning of tense, § 188.
e)/s, why accented? § 166.
e)pe/essin, form, § 91.
kuno\s o)/mmat' e)/xwn, cf. kunw=pa, l. 159; the poet makes the dog typical of shamelessness; the deer, of cowardice.
kradi/hn, § 58.
po/lemon, with ictus on the ultima, § 32.
qwrhxqh=nai § 137.3) limits te/tlhkas, l. 228.
lo/xond'(e), cf. N 277, e)s lo/xon, e)/nqa ma/list' a)reth\ diaei/detai a)ndrw=n, ‘to an ambush, where most of all the valor of men is clearly seen.’— a)risth/essi, declension, § 88.
te/tlhkas, on force of tense, § 187.—to\ de/ toi ktl., ‘for this seems to you to be death.’
kh/r, note accent, and cf. l. 44, kh=r.
lw/ion (in Attic poetry lw=|on), how compared? GG. 182, 1.
dw=r' a)poairei=sqai, supply an object, as antecedent of o(/stis, ‘to deprive of gifts [him] whosoever opposes you in speech.’ On the conditional relative sentence, see § 197.
Supply the place of the omitted protasis by ‘else,’ i. e. ‘were it not so.’
lwbh/saio, construction, § 207.
e)/pi, adverb, ‘besides.’ For ictus on ultima, see § 38.

Achilles held a staff, put into his hand by a herald, as a sign that he had the right to address the assembly; on ending his speech he threw it down (l. 245). On the other hand, Agamemnon held no temporary scepter, but a permanent one (B 101 ff.), for he was a ‘scepter-bearing king.’— nai\ ma\ ktl., ‘verily by this staff.’
to/, relative; cf. to/n, l. 36, th/n, l. 72.
e)pei\ dh\ prw=ta (cf. l. 6) ktl., ‘since once for all it is parted from its stump.’
o)/ressi, double s, § 52.

le/loipen, translation, § 187. Vergil renders the thought (Aen. XII, 208, 209):
cum semel in silvis imo de stirpe recisum matre caret.
‘Since once for all cut from its stump in the forest, it [the scepter] is severed from its parent tree.’
e(, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
min, here for skh=ptron, neuter; cf. l. 29 (min = au)th/n) and l. 100 (min = au)to/n).
pala/mais, declension, § 72.
dikaspo/loi, appositive to ui(=es (l. 237).

oi(/ te, use of the enclitic, § 123.3. In these days there seems to have been no written law; the ‘decrees’ or ‘dooms’ (qe/mistes) of Zeus were probably the spoken words of the ‘Zeus-cherished kings,’ which had come to have a certain stability.
pro\s *dio/s, ‘on behalf of Zeus,’ or ‘at the bidding of Zeus.’— ei)ru/atai, form, § 142.4, a; force of tense, § 187.
The important words, to be taken closely with nai\ ma\ to/de skh=ptron (l. 234), begin here.
h)= pote, ‘surely one day.’
*)axillh=os, objective genitive with poqh/.
ui)=as, declension, § 107; syntax, § 179.
dunh/seai, form, § 142.1; Attic dunh/sei.
eu)=t' a)/n = Attic o(/tan.
qnh/|skontes, ‘being slain.’
pi/ptwsi, in protasis of what sort of condition? Cf. GG. 628, 650.
e)/ndoqi, suffix, § 155.3.
xwo/menos, with ultima used for long syllable, § 32.
o(/ t', elision and meaning, § 40, § 2; 123, 7.
ou)de/n, ‘not at all,’ in origin a cognate accusative.
poti/ = Attic pro/s.
gai/h| = Attic gh=|.

xrusei/ois (= Attic xrusoi=s), cf. shorter form, xruse/w|, l. 15.— peparme/non, from pei/rw. The wooden staff seems to have been enclosed in a sheath, which was fastened on with nails; both sheath and nails may have been of gold. See Tsountas and Manatt, The Mycenaean Age, pp. 167-169, and Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, p. 250.
e(te/rwqen, suffix, § 155.2.
toi=si, ‘before them,’ cf. note on l. 58.
tou= § 118.4) ... a)po\ glw/sshs, ‘from whose tongue.’
kai/ = ‘moreover,’ if translated at all. Cicero quotes the line (Cato Maior, 10, 31): ex eius lingua melle dulcior fluebat oratio.
me/litos, why genitive? § 175.
r(e/en = Attic e)/rrei.

tw=|, dative of interest, ‘for him,’ ‘in his day.’ The sense is: ‘he had already seen two generations of mortal men perish.’ Estimating a generation as a period of thirty years, some ancient commentators reckoned Nestor's age as seventy.

mero/pwn, perhaps ‘mortal,’ was anciently but improperly derived from mei/romai, ‘divide,’ and o)/y, ‘voice,’ and taken to mean ‘articulately speaking.’ Compare Swinburne's
men upon earth that hear
Sweet articulate words
Sweetly divided apart. —Atalanta in Calydon.
e)fqi/aq', where found? § 142.4, a.—The former oi(/ is relative; the latter (oi(), the personal pronoun, to be taken with a(/ma: ‘together with him.’
tra/fen, form, § 136.8. Note the poet's simple order, which may properly be kept in translation: ‘were bred and born.’
h)gaqe/h|, prefix, § 160; lengthened initial vowel, § 35.
w)\ po/poi indicates amazement; translate freely, ‘'tis past belief!’
h)=, as before (l. 78), ‘truly.’
ghqh/sai, form, § 136.4; it agrees with the nearer subject only. Lines 255-257 contain a less vivid future—or “possible”—condition in its normal form; cf. GG. 651 (1).
kexaroiato, tense, § 128; ending, § 142.4, d.
sfw=in, with marname/noiin in agreement, syntax, § 174. On the form sfw=in, see § 110; puqoi/ato, § 142.4, d; marname/noiin, § 73.
‘(You) who are superior to the (other) Danaans in counsel, and superior in fighting.’
pe/ri, accent, § 164.
boulh/n, accusative of specification; so, too, ma/xesqai.
*danaw=n, why genitive? Cf. *klutaimnh/strhs, l. 113; se/qen, l. 186; e)mei=o, l. 259.
de/ = ga/r.
h)/dh ga/r pote, ‘for once on a time (gone by).’
h)e/ = Attic h)/, ‘than.’
per = ‘even.’
u(mi=n, dative by attraction to case of a)rei/osin (a)ndra/sin). What case would be expected?
a)ne/ras, form, § 85.—Why does not ou)de/ suffer elision? § 61.23.
i)/dwmai, syntax, § 191.
For oi(=on *peiri/qoon etc. we should expect oi(=os [h)=n] *peiri/qoos etc.; but again we find attraction—to the case of toi/ous (l. 262).
*kaine/a, form, § 90.
The line is wanting in the best MSS.
*qhse/a, form, § 90.— a)qana/toisin, on quantity of initial vowel, § 34.
ka/rtistoi, predicate adjective: ‘they were the very [dh/] bravest men that were ever reared on earth.’
kei=noi, spelling, § 120.
tra/fen, form, § 136.8.
me/n = mh/n, as usual.
e)/san (Attic h)=san), § 125.

fhrsi/n, Aeolic for Attic qhrsi/n or qhri/ois, ‘wild beasts.’ The name refers to the rude Thessalian *ke/ntauroi, ‘Centaurs.’ “Such a name is not likely to have been assumed by the tribe itself, but is rather an opprobrious term applied to them by their enemies” (Ridgeway, The Early Age of Greece, vol. i, p. 178).
kat' e)/m) au)to/n § 112), ‘by myself alone,’ i. e. ‘independently,’ so that my valor could be clearly seen.
tw=n, demonstrative, § 118.1.
a)/n ... maxe/oito (Attic ma/xoito), ‘would fight.’
meu occurred l. 37.
boule/wn, case and scansion, § 70.
cu/nien, ‘heeded’; where found? § 136.7.
u)/mmes = Attic u(mei=s, § 110.
Addressed particularly to Agamemnon.
to/nd'(e), Achilles, one of the two objects of the verb of depriving.
a)gaqo/s per e)w/n, cf. note on l. 131.
a)poai/reo, form, § 48; Attic a)fairou=.
e)/a (i. e. e)/ae), ‘suffer’ her to remain with him.
prw=ta, cf. note on l. 235.
Now Nestor turns to Achilles.
e)rize/menai, where found? § 137.1, a.

ou)/ poq' o(moi/hs e)/mmore timh=s, ‘never shares in a common honor’ with other men, i. e. he has superior dignity; Agamemnon was a “scepterbearing king”; Achilles was not, for his father still ruled; therefore Achilles should yield precedence to Agamemnon.
e)/mmore (mei/romai), form, § 39; translated by present, § 187.
Note that kartero/s is an adjective of the positive degree; cf. l. 178.—Achilles's mother was Thetis, a goddess of the sea.
a)ll'(a/), ‘yet.’
pleo/nessin, Attic ple/osi or plei/osi. For syntax, cf. the dative in the phrase toi=si d' a)nista/menos, l. 58.
de/, cf. l. 58.
div.l: li/ssom'(ai), i. e. e)gw\ de/ ei)mi o( lisso/menos (Nägelsbach^{1}), ‘for it is I, Nestor, that beseech you.’

div.p: *)axillh=i, dative of advantage, ‘for Achilles's sake.’
meqe/men, form, § 137.2.
pe/letai = e)sti/.
pe/ri, as in l. 258.
pa/ntwn, syntax like that of *danaw=n, l. 258.
pa/ntessi, cf. pa=sin, l. 283.

a(/ tin'(a) ktl., things ‘in which I think somebody will not obey.’ By tina Agamemnon evidently means himself.—In translation distinguish carefully among pe/ri ... e)/mmenai (l. 287), krate/ein, a)na/ssein, and shmai/nein: ‘to be superior,’ ‘to have power over,’ ‘to lord it,’ ‘to dictate.’

290 and 291. ‘If the immortal [ai)e\n e)o/ntes] gods did make him a warrior, therefore do his abusive words rush forward [like so many warriors to the front] for utterance?’ Others render: ‘therefore do they [i. e. the gods] permit him to utter abuses?’ If the latter translation be accepted, proqe/ousin must come, not from pro-qe/w, ‘run forward,’ but from pro-ti/qhmi, and be equivalent to Attic pro-tiqe/asi—a sole instance of the form.— e)/qesan, for the meaning cf. note on l. 2.
What part of speech is oi(? Observe the accent on ultima of the previous word.
muqh/sasqai indicates purpose.
ga/r, cf. note on l. 123.
pa=n e)/rgon, ‘in every matter.’
o(/tti, spelling, § 51.2.
e)pite/lleo, formed like e(/lkeo, l. 210.
A weak line, “athetized,” i. e. rejected as spurious, by some ancient critics.
sh=|sin, cf. teo/n, l. 282 and § 113. With su\ d' e)ni\ fresi\ ba/lleo sh=|sin, compare Vergil's tu condita mente teneto (Aen. III, 388).
298 maxe/ssomai, for spelling cf. l. 153. What is the Attic equivalent?
soi/, note the emphatic repetition: ‘by force (of hands) I will not fight with you—no, not with you or anybody else’; ‘you all’ is subject of a)fe/lesqe.
tw=n, emphatic repetition of tw=n a)/llwn (l. 300), partitive genitive with ti.
ou)k a)/n ti fe/rois, ‘you had better not carry away anything,’ potential optative, used—in mock courtesy—with the force of a prohibition. Cf. B 250.
a)e/kontos e)mei=o = Attic a)/kontos e)mou=. Cf. a)/kontos *ku/rou, Xen. Anab, I, 3, 17.
ei) d' a)/ge mh\n pei/rhsai, ‘come now! just try it.’ ei) d' a)/ge is interjectional, and perhaps for an earlier ei=) a)/ge, i. e. ei)=a a)/ge. Cf. Vergil's eia age (Aen. IV, 569).
gnw/wsi, form, § 149; ‘may witness (it).’— kai\ oi(/de, ‘these men here too.’
e)rwh/sei, see note on B 179.
douri/, declined, § 97; Attic do/rati.
a)n-sth/thn, on the prefix see § 46; -sth/thn, cf. l. 6.
a)gorh/n, cf. l. 54; ‘the assembly’; the word never means ‘market-place’ in Homer.

The lodge of Achilles is described in 24.448-456: it was built for him by his Myrmidons, of pine timbers; the roof was thatched; the door was fastened by a single great bolt of pine; adjoining it was a great courtyard enclosed by stakes, set close together. Elsewhere (16.231) we infer that the courtyard (au)lh/) contained an altar of *zeu\s e(rkei=os.
e)i/sas, spelling, § 61.27.
h)/ie, cf. l. 47.
*menoitia/dh|, the first introduction of the ‘gentle’ Patroclus is as the ‘son of Menoetius.’
a(/lade, force of suffix, § 155.5.
e)ei/kosi, spelling, § 61.9.
bh=se, transitive first aorist; cf. bh/somen, l. 144, and note.
a)na/ is an adverb; cf. a)/n, l. 143; for its accent (not retracted), cf. § 168.
ei(=sen, a causative first aorist, containing the root of e(/zeto, l. 68.
u(gra\ ke/leuqa, ‘their ways in the sea’ (cf. Isaiah xliii, 16: “a way in the sea, and a path in the mighty waters”).
313, 314. The scholiast compares Euripides, Iphigenia in Tauris, 1193 qa/lassa klu/zei (washes away) pa/nta ta)nqrw/pwn kaka/.
‘The savor went heavenward, curling around in the smoke’; that is, permeating the smoke.
lh=g'(e), imperfect third singular; cf. imperative lh=g', l. 210.— th/n, relative § 118.4) ‘with which’ he had threatened. (Cf. GG. 530 a.)
e)p-hpei/lhs'(e), cf. the present a)peilei=s, l. 161.
tw/, relative.
xeiro/s, syntax, § 172.
e(lo/nt'(e) agrees with ‘you two’ (sfw=i) understood.
a)ge/men, form, § 137.2; syntax, § 213.
ei) ... ke, Attic equivalent? Cf. l. 128.
dw/h|sin, form, § 149 (5).
e)gw\ de/, ‘then I,’ see note on l. 58.
ken ... e(/lwmai, syntax, § 192.
to/, ‘this,’ demonstrative.
kai\ r(i/gion, ‘even more shivery’; more disagreeable or dreadful than the present mission.
ba/thn, Attic e)bh/thn.

para/, ‘along.’ The ships of the Greeks stretched in lines along the shore; Odysseus's occupied a central position; while the two ends—the most dangerous positions—were guarded by the ships of Telamonian Ajax and Achilles (11.5-9).
ge, why is e not elided? § 61.23.
ou)d(e\) ... gh/qhsen *)axilleu/s, ‘and Achilles felt no thrill of joy’; on the force of the aorist, cf. l. 85.
tarbh/sante, note the tense, ‘struck with fear.’
basilh=a, form, § 86.
h(=|sin, ‘his,’ form, § 113.
kai/, ‘too.’
a)=sson, comparative of a)/gxi, ‘near’; superlative, a)/gxista.
moi, ‘in my sight.’
u)/mmes, supply e)ste/.
o(/, relative, § 118.4.
*patro/klees, declension, § 102.
sfwin, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
a)/gein, syntax, § 211.
ma/rturoi = Attic ma/rtures, of third declension.
pro/s, ‘before’; cf. the meanings that have been already pointed out in idiomatic uses, ll. 160 and 239.
tou= basilh=os a)phne/os, ‘that king unkind’: the order is like to\n *xru/shn ... a)rhth=ra (l. 11).
dh\ ai)=te, pronounced as if d' au)=te § 43).
ge/nhtai, in this more vivid future protasis note the omission of ke, § 197.
a)mu=nai, syntax, § 211.
toi=s a)/llois, dative of advantage (interest); translate with ‘from.’
ga/r receives the ictus (as in a few other lines) in spite of its quantity § 33).
qu/ei, ‘rages.’
‘And he does not know at all how to look at the same time to the past and to the future,’ i. e. ‘to consider carefully.’
pro/ssw and o)pi/ssw are spelled in Attic with one sigma.
‘How his Achaeans shall fight safely beside the ships.’
o(/ppws § 51.1) introduces a dependent interrogative (not purpose) clause, with the future indicative § 200).
oi(, ‘for him,’ ‘his’ § 176).
maxe/ontai, form, § 151; cf. the more common future, maxesso/menos, l. 153.
para\ nh=as, ‘along past the ships’; cf. note on l. 327.
gunh/, in apposition to h(/, § 118.3.
e(ta/rwn, with no/sfi.
e)/f' (e)/pi), for the accent cf. § 166.
polla/, cf. l. 35.
xei=ras o)regnu/s, toward his mother, who dwelt in the sea.
‘Mother, since you gave me birth once for all, though for a short life, honor at least ought the Olympian to have granted me.’

ge, appended to the aorist e)/tekes, gives emphasis to the single past act; with minunqa/dion e)o/nta, per has its usual force, as noted in l. 131; with timh/n, per has the force of ge, a meaning that will be noticed again (e. g. l. 508). —The form o)/fellen = Attic w)/feilen. But to express this thought in Attic Greek xrh=n or e)/dei with infinitive and subject accusative would be used (GG. 460).
nu=n d'(e/), ‘but as it is.’
au)to/s, of course not in person, but ‘by his own order.’
a)pou/ras, on the form see § 63.3.
patri/, Nereus.
a(lo/s, syntax, § 175.
h)u/te = Attic w(/sper.
da/kru xe/ontos (with au)toi=o), ‘as he wept.’
se fre/nas, construction, § 180.
ei)/domen, on the digamma, § 61.23; subjunctive, § 143.
It is better to translate tau=ta pa/nt'(a) with a)goreu/w (deliberative subjunctive, in question of appeal) and to understand the words with i)dui/h|.
i)dui/h| § 61.23) = Attic ei)dui/a|, and agrees with toi.

The home of Chryseis was Chryse; and to this she is restored (l. 430 ff.). Naturally the question arose in ancient times, “How was she taken, then, when Thebe fell?” And the answer had to be made that either (1) she was visiting in Thebe at the time when Achilles captured that town, or (2) on the same expedition on which Achilles took Thebe he stormed Chryse also. Thebe was the home of Andromache before her marriage to Hector; she was the daughter of King Eëtion. Achilles's own prize, Briseis, was taken in the spoil of the captured town Lyrnessus.
e)nqa/de, suffix, § 155.5.
da/ssanto, cf. de/dastai, l. 125; and for spelling, § 54.
sfi/sin, here a reflexive pronoun, and therefore accented § 111.4).
e(kathbo/lou, cf. l. 75.
*)apo/llwnos, long initial vowel here, § 30.
eu)came/nou, on translation of the tense, § 186.
h)=en = Attic h)=n.
e)passu/teroi betrays in the u for o its Aeolic origin.
a)/mmi, Attic h(mi=n, § 110; this word with u)/mmi, u)/mmes, etc., is Aeolic.
e(ka/toio, cf. l. 75.
prw=tos, ‘I was first’ to urge.
*)atrei+/wna, form, § 157.
h)pei/lhsen mu=qon, ‘made a threat’; mu=qos is a word of varied connotations, which the Greeks felt the meaning of; our English translation must take its cue from the context.
o(/, relative use of the article, § 118.4.
th\n me/n, ‘the one’ damsel; th\n de/ (l. 391), ‘the other.’
*xru/shn, here the town, not the priest.
pe/mpousin, ‘are escorting.’
ne/on klisi/hqen ktl., ‘only now, heralds led away [literally ‘went leading’] from my lodge.’
With e)/ban § 136.7) the participle contains the leading idea, as with Attic oi)/xomai. Cf. w)/|xeto ple/wn (Xen. Anab. II, 6, 3), ‘went sailing off,’ ‘sailed away.’
klisi/hqen, for suffix cf. ou)rano/qen, l. 195.
*brish=os, from nominative *briseu/s, declined like basileu/s, § 86.
peri/sxeo, peri-e/xw.
e)h=os, form, § 99.
394, 395. ‘Go to Olympus and beseech Zeus, if ever you gladdened his heart at all, whether by word or by deed.’
*di/a has the ictus on -a, § 38.
w)/nhsas, o)ni/nhmi.
polla/ki, Attic polla/kis.
seo, enclitic pronoun, § 110; limits a)/kousa.
patro\s e)ni\ mega/roisin, ‘in the halls of my father,’ Peleus.
e)ni/ receives the ictus on -i, § 38.
eu)xome/nhs, ‘boasting,’ agrees with seo (l. 396).
e)/fhsqa, form, § 136.3.
*kroni/wni, for syntax compare l. 67, h(mi=n.
oi)/h e)n a)qana/toisin, you ‘alone among the immortals.’
u(pelu/sao, form, § 142.1. u(p- means ‘from under’ the weight of his bonds.
w)=x', i. e. w)=ka.
makro/n, ‘high.’
au)=te, ‘again,’ ‘in turn.’
ou(= § 113 patro/s, Poseidon.
o(/s, with force of demonstrative, § 123.4.
u(pe/ddeisan, for spelling cf. l. 33.
ou)de/ e(, account for hiatus; § 61.6.
e( refers to Zeus.
tw=n min mnh/sasa, ‘remind him of this.’
labe\ gou/nwn ( § 97, § 172); not a peculiar act here, but the regular custom of suppliants in Homer.

‘In the hope that he may perhaps be willing to give aid to the Trojans, and to hem in the others at their ships' sterns and about the sea— the Achaeans.’ Achilles disdainfully sets the Achaeans' name at the very end, simply mentioning them as tou\s de/ at first (Cauer, Die Kunst des Übersetzens^{2}, p. 90).
ai)/ ken e)qe/lh|sin § 136.6), in syntax like ai)/ ke pi/qhai, l. 207.
e)pi\ ... a)rh=cai, tmesis, § 163.
e)/lsai, ei)/lw.

kteinome/nous, agreeing with *)axaiou/s: letting them be ‘slain.’— i)/na pa/ntes ktl., Pope gives the sense:
and bring
The Greeks to know the curse of such a king.
e)pau/rwntai, ‘get acquainted with’; literally ‘partake of’ (e)pauri/skw).
o(/ t' a)/riston ktl., cf. l. 244.
ai)na/, adverbial accusative with tekou=sa, ‘after bearing you unto trouble’ (cf. Job v, 7).

o)/feles para\ nhusi\n ... h(=sqai once meant ‘you ought to be sitting beside the ships’; cf. l. 353; and if ai)/qe be translated ‘ah!’ we may keep the rest of the sentence in its literal meaning. A wish in present time, impossible of fulfilment, is implied; cf. Xen. Anab. II, 1, 4, a)ll' w)/fele me\n *ku=ros zh=n.—The force of h(=sqai (l. 416) is ‘to be staying’ or ‘to be passing the time’ rather than ‘to be sitting,’ which is literal.

e)pei/ nu/ toi ai)=sa ktl., supply e)/sti, ‘since your measure of life is [i. e. ‘endures’] for but a brief space, not at all for very long.’ For the adverbs in the predicate, adjectives might be expected; but this Homeric construction has several parallels. Cf. 4.466, mi/nunqa de/ oi( ge/neq' o(rmh/: ‘his onset was [endured] for a brief space.’—For quantity of ultima of ma/la, cf. § § 37; 62, 2.—That Achilles had a choice between two destinies is told in I 410-415. He might have a long, inglorious life or a short, glorious one; as is well known, he chose the latter. There is no hint of the choice in the present context, however.
nu=n d'(e/), ‘but as it is.’
peri\ pa/ntwn, ‘above all.’
e)/pleo, ‘you were’ and still are; or simply ‘you are’, form, § 142.1.
tw=|, ‘therefore,’ § 117.
kakh=| ai)/sh|, ‘unto an evil doom.’ Cf. § 178.
e)re/ousa, ‘in order to tell’; cf. luso/menos, l. 13.
terpikerau/nw|, form and meaning, § 59.

a)ga/nnifon, spelling, § 39; prefix, § 160. When Olympus is called snowy, the poet has in mind those parts only that do not extend above the level of the clouds. On the other hand, the region where the gods dwell is the ever bright summit, high above the clouds and remote from the sight of men; here there is neither rain nor snow, but only perpetual fair weather, as the poet of the Odyssey sings (Od. 6.42-45). This summit reaches up into heaven (ou)rano/s).
ai)/ ke pi/qhtai, syntax, § 198.
mh/ni'(e), ‘rage on.’
*ai)qioph=as, as if from nominative *ai)qiopeu/s. But elsewhere *ai)qi/opas, as if from *ai)qi/oy, is found.
xqizo/s agrees with subject of e)/bh. Homer commonly uses temporal adjectives where the English idiom employs adverbs.
poti/, cf. l. 245.
a)pebh/seto, tense, § 153.
gunaiko/s, genitive of cause.

a)e/kontos, with a pronoun (like au)tou=) understood, is probably in the genitive absolute construction: ‘against his will.’ Others make it stand in an objective relation to bi/h| = ‘with violence done to him unwilling,’ ‘despite his unwillingness.’
a)phu/rwn, § 63.4.
stei/lanto, ‘furled.’

‘The mast they let down into [literally ‘made approach’] its crutch, lowering it with the forestays quickly.’ The forestays were untied from the bow; and the mast thus released was bent back into its crutch.
th\n d'(e/), the ship.
eu)na/s, stones for ‘anchors,’ ‘mooring-stones’; these they let go (e)k ... e)/balon) from the bow, while they made the stern cables (prumnh/sia) fast (kata\ ... e)/dhsan) to the shore.
bh=san, cf. bh/somen, l. 144.
nho/s, declined, § 101.
xersi/, ‘arms.’
r(e/cai, in same sense as r(e/cas, l. 147.
i(laso/mesqa, ending, § 142.3; mood, § 144, II; cf. i(la/sseai, l. 147.
toi/, form, § 115.
ou)loxu/tas, sacrificial barley, ‘barley for strewing’ (xe/w, ‘pour’); cf. Od. 3.441, which has to do with the description of a sacrifice: e(te/rh| d' e)/xen ou)la\s
div.l: e)n kane/w|, ‘and in his other hand he [Aretus] had barleycorns in a basket.’ This barley was sprinkled on the consecrated victims before they were sacrificed.

div.p:
h)me
 (i. e. h)= me
 [= mh
]) dh/ pote ... pa/ros, ‘surely once before.’
pa/ros = Attic pro/sqen.
e)me/, with ietus on the ultima; this would be justified by the pause § 32), even if the next word did not begin with a liquid § 38).
i)/yao, in formation like u(pelu/sao, l. 401.
h)d' e)/ti kai\ nu=n, ‘and now too, again.’ h)d' (h)= de/) is correlative with h)me/n (l. 453). The clauses may be bound together in English by rendering (freely) h)me/n, ‘as,’ and h)de/, ‘so.’
e)pikrh/hnon, cf. note on l. 41.
au)e/rusan, formation, § 63.1; understand ‘the heads’ of the victims as object. With e)/sfacan and e)/deiran, understand ‘the victims’ as object.
kata\ ... e)ka/luyan, tmesis, ‘covered up.’

di/ptuxa (supply kni/shn) poih/santes, ‘making it [the fat] doublefolded’; i. e. ‘folding it about’ the thigh-pieces, on both top and bottom. —e)p' au)tw=n ktl., ‘and on them they put raw pieces.’ They cut bits of meat as primal offerings from all the limbs; these were burnt along with the thigh-pieces as a sacrifice to the god (in this instance, Apollo), who was believed thus to become a partaker of the rite.
e)/pi § 162), ‘thereon.’
pempw/bola § 108.5), ‘five-tined spits,’ for roasting several pieces of meat at once (Van Leeuwen). Cf. o)beloi=sin, l. 465.
kata\ ... e)ka/h, § 163.
e)pa/santo, pate/omai.
ta)=lla, § 44.

a)mf' (adverb) o)beloi=sin e)/peiran, ‘they pierced them around with spits.’ Cf. Verg. Aen. 1, 212: [viscera] pars in frusta secant veribusque trementia figunt. ‘Some cut the flesh in bits and pierce it quivering with spits.’
tetu/konto, teu/xw, § 128.
ti ... e)deu/eto (= Attic e)dei=to, cf. deuo/menon, l. 134), ‘felt any lack,’ ‘went ungratified.’
daito/s, genitive of material.
e)i/shs, ‘adequate,’ ‘sufficient.’
‘But when they had satisfied [literally ‘dismissed’] their desire for drink and food.’
po/sios, declined like po/lis, § 103; cf. u(/brios, l. 214.
e(/nto = Attic ei(=nto, from i(/hmi.

e)/ron, second declension = Attic e)/rwta, third declension.—Cf. Vergil's imitation, Aen. VIII, 184:
Postquam exempta fames et amor compressus edendi.
‘When hunger had been satisfied and desire to eat had been appeased.’
kou=roi = Attic ko/roi. Cf. kou/rhn and note, l. 98.
e)peste/yanto potoi=o, ‘filled up to the brim with wine.’
potoi=o, genitive of material.

‘And then they passed it around to all, after they had first made libation with the cups.’ With a ladle they poured some wine into every man's cup, for him, in turn, to spill upon the ground, as an offering to the gods. The custom is said still to continue in Persia. (Cf. Fitzgerald's translation of the Rubáiyát, quatrain xxxix of the fourth edition, and note on the same.)
e)parca/menoi depa/essin § 78), literally ‘after having begun with the cups’ (instrumental dative); the verb is limited to this ritualistic use.
panhme/rioi, agreeing with the subject, ‘all the rest of the day.’
h)=mos = Attic o(/te.
h)e/lios = Attic h(/lios.
e)pi\ kne/fas h)=lqen, ‘darkness came on’ § 163).
*)hw/s, declined, § 92.
a)na/gonto (a)n-h/gonto), ‘they put to sea,’ the regular Attic prose word.
q' means what? Cf. l. 23.
prh=sen, see note on B 415.
481, 482. a)mfi\ de\ ku=ma ktl., ‘and around the stem of the ship the purple billow gurgled loud as she sped along.’
diaprh/ssousa, spelling, § 56.
kata/, ‘over against,’ ‘opposite’; in nautical term, ‘off.’
e)ski/dnanto = Attic e)skeda/nnunto.
ne/as, spelling, § 29.
diogenh/s, on quantity of initial syllable, § 34.
u(o/s (= ui(o/s), spelling, § § 29; 107, 1.
pwle/sketo, meaning of suffix, § 154.1.
po/lemon, by what principle is the ictus permitted to rest on the ultima? § 32.
fqinu/qeske, suffixes, § 154.2.
poqe/eske, § 154.1.
a)uth/n, ‘war-cry,’ not the same word as au)th/n.
pto/lemon = Attic po/lemon.
e)k toi=o, ‘thereafter,’ with reference not to what has immediately preceded, as would be natural, but to the meeting of Achilles and Thetis (cf. l. 425).
duwdeka/th, cf. dwdeka/th (l. 425); which is Attic?
kai\ to/te dh/, ‘then it was that.’
i)/san = Attic h)/|esan or h)=|san.
lh/qeto = Attic e)p-elanqa/neto.
e)fetme/wn, declined like boule/wn, l. 273.
e(ou=, § 113; what in Attic? Cf. GG. 551 d, 554 a.
a)nedu/seto, tense, § 153.

ku=ma, accusative of the space or way over which an action extends; cf. A 151, Z 292, and the different construction in A 359. For the meaning, compare the merman's words to his mate:
"Go up, dear heart, through the waves;
Say thy prayer, and come back to the kind sea-caves!"
She smiled, she went up through the surf in the bay. Matthew Arnold, The Forsaken Merman.
h)eri/h, construction like that of panhme/rioi (l. 472) and xqizo/s (l. 424).
ou)rano\n *ou)/lumpo/n te, cf. note on l. 420.
eu)ru/opa, ‘far-thundering,’ third declension accusative (as if from eu)ru/oy) of a first declension noun, eu)ru/opa (nominative).
gou/nwn, cf. l. 407.
o)/nhsa, cf. w)/nhsas, l. 395.
ti/mhso/n moi ui(o/n, note the metrical scheme, --- - -u u -uu-uu --, with moi remaining long in spite of the hiatus; so, too, *sminqeu= (l. 39).
a)/llwn, a genitive of comparison (i. e. originally separation), as if w)kumorw/tatos were a comparative adjective; the English point of view, however, requires ‘of all’ after the superlative.
e)/plet'(o), cf. e)/pleo, l. 418.
a)pou/ras, cf. l. 356.
su/ per = su/ ge.
to/fra ... o)/fra, ‘so long’ ... ‘until.’
o)fe/llwsin, ‘magnify.’
nefelhgere/ta, § 67.
w(\s e)/xet' e)mpefuui=a, ‘so she clung, fast clasping.’ Cf. genua amplexus ... haerebat, Verg. Aen. III, 607, 608.
e)mpefuui=a is, literally, ‘grown on.’ a vigorous metaphor.
nhmerte/s, composition, § 161.
e)pei\ ou)/ toi ktl., ‘since no fear rests upon you.’
e)/pi, accent, § 167; quantity of ultima, § 37.
‘Sorry doings, to be sure! in that you will compel me to fall out with Here, when she shall vex me with reproachful words.’ Why does not loi/gia suffer elision? § 61.18.
o(/ te, § 123.7.—e)f-h/seis, e)f-i/hmi.
e)re/qh|sin, in form like e)qe/lh|sin, l. 408.
kai\ au)/tws, ‘even as it is.’
kai/ te, the second of these words is not a conjunction here, nor has it any translatable meaning; it simply accompanies the general statement, as often in Homer. See on l. 81.
melh/setai = Attic melh/sei. For ke with the future indicative, cf. l. 139 and § 190.
o)/fra tele/ssw, ‘until I accomplish them.’ For omission of ke, § 197.
ei) d' a)/ge, see note on l. 302.
o)/fra, ‘in order that.’
tou=to, supply e)sti/.
e)c e)me/qen, § 155.2.
e)mo/n, understand te/kmwr, ‘pledge,’ and again supply e)sti/.
e)/p'(i), ‘thereto.’
*kroni/wn, formation, § 157.
krato/s, declension, § 100.

me/gan d' e)le/licen ktl., Vergil's annuit et totum nutu tremefecit Olympum (Aen. IX, 106). These three lines (528-530) are said to have been quoted by the sculptor Phidias when he was asked after what model he should fashion his great statue of Zeus at Olympia (Strabo VIII, p. 354).
die/tmagen, formation, § 136.8.
a)/lto, where found? § 131.
*zeu\s de/, supply e)/bh from the context.
e(o/n, cf. e(ou=, l. 496.
a)ne/stan, formation, § 136.7.
patro/s, genitive limiting e)nanti/on, ‘before.’ Cf. note on the kindred verb a)ntia/w, l. 31.
e)perxo/menon, agrees with a pronoun (e. g. e() understood, object of mei=nai.
ou) de/ min ktl., ‘and Here, on seeing him, was not unaware’ etc.
min is object of i)dou=s'(a).
sumfra/ssato, spelling, § 54.
oi( is dative after su/n in composition.
dh\ au)=, synizesis, § 43.
toi fi/lon e)sti/n, ‘it is your pleasure.’
e)o/nta (as well as frone/onta, l. 542) is in agreement with the understood subject (se) of the infinitive dikaze/men (l. 542).
krupta/dia (accusative plural neuter) frone/onta (accusative singular masculine) dikaze/men, ‘to consider and give judgment on secret matters.’
542, 543. ou)de/ ti/ pw/ moi ktl., ‘and you never bring yourself with any heartiness to tell me a plan that you are considering.’
o(/tti, cf. l. 294.
e)pi-e/lpeo, why is the -i of the prefix not elided? § 61.13.— mu/qous, ‘counsels.’
ei)dh/sein (Attic ei)/sesqai), from oi=da.
xalepoi/, supply ei)de/nai, ‘hard for you to know.’
e)/sont'(ai) has mu=qoi understood as subject.— On a)lo/xw| per e)ou/sh|, see note on l. 131.
a)ll' o(\n me\n [mu=qo/n] k' e)pieike\s [h)=| tina] a)koue/men, ‘but whatsoever counsel it is fitting for anybody to hear,’ etc.
pro/teros [sou=], ‘sooner than you.’
ei)/setai, see ei)dh/sein, l. 546.
o(\n [mu=qon] may well be translated in the plural, to conform, in English, to tau=ta (l. 550).
e)qe/lwmi, formation, § 136.1.
e(/kasta § 61.11), ‘one by one.’
poi=on (predicate adjective with reference to mu=qon), ‘what a charge is this that you have spoken!’ On mu=qon, see note on l. 388.
kai\ li/hn, ‘assuredly.’
pa/ros (here = Attic pa/lai) with the Greek present is to be translated by the perfect tense in English (cf. GG. 454 d); compare the Latin iam dudum with the present.
a(/ss'(a), form, § 124.
e)qe/lh|sqa, formation, § 136.3.
dei/doika, spelling, § 62.1.—mh/ se parei/ph| ktl., ‘lest it prove that Thetis has talked you over’ (GMT. 93).
pole/as, form, § 106.

daimoni/h (masculine daimo/nie), a common term of address, means properly a person whose conduct is so unusual or unexpected that he (of she) seems to be influenced by some untoward divinity. Sometimes a single word, sometimes a short clause, selected with reference to the context, will convey this meaning in English: ‘Here, I do not understand you,’ or ‘my misguided wife!’ Either the poet is unconscious in allowing god to address god in this inappropriate way, or he is displaying a kind of humor in letting gods mimic the speech of men.
prh=cai, § 64.—a)ll' a)po\ qumou= ktl., ‘but you will be the more removed from my heart,’ i. e. out of favor with me.
e)/seai, Attic e)/sei.
to\ de/ toi ktl., cf. l. 325.

ei) ... e)sti/n, simple present condition with nothing implied (GG. 647): ‘suppose this is as you say [ou(/tw], 'tis my own affair [or ‘my pleasure’], I presume.’ In this idiomatic use me/llei = Attic e)/oike: me/llei ei)=nai = ‘it is like to be’ (present tense), ‘it is, very likely,’ or ‘presumably.’
toi, dative of advantage (interest), ‘for you,’ i. e. ‘from you’: cf. l. 67, h(mi=n.
xrai/smwsin, ‘ward off,’ an aorist which previously (ll. 28 and 242) has been met in the sense of ‘help’; its subject is o(/soi qeoi\ ei)/s' ktl., ‘all the gods that are on Olympus.’
a)sson, see note on l. 335.
i)o/nq' = i)o/nta, agreeing with e)me/ understood; that this pronoun of the first person is to be supplied, is indicated distinctly enough by the clause o(/te ... e)fei/w.
e)f-ei/w (i(/hmi) is inflected like qei/w, § 149 (2).
e)/ddeisen, account for double d. § 62. 1.
kaqh=sto, ka/q-hmai.
fi/lon, its force? § 114.
e)pi\ h)=ra (used by Homer in this formula only) fe/rwn, ‘bearing kindly service,’ ‘doing favor.’
h)= dh\ loi/gia e)/rga, cf. l. 518, where the expression is exclamatory; but the construction here is obviously different, for a complete predicate is supplied by ta/d' e)/ssetai ktl.
ta/d'(e), meaning, § 120.
e)lao/neton, literally ‘drive,’ ‘run’ (transitive); here figuratively, ‘keep going,’ ‘keep up.’

div.l: e)sqlh=s h)=dos (= h(donh/), ‘enjoyment of a goodly feast.’— e)pei\ ta\ xerei/ona (= xei/rona, cf. l. 114) nika=|, ‘since worse matters prevail.’ ta\ xerei/ona means ta\ kaka/ (cf. l. 107), ‘rather’ than ta\ a)gaqa/.

div.p: kai\ au)th=| per noeou/sh|, ‘although she is herself discreet.’
kai\ ... per, see note on l. 131.
neikei/h|si, inflected like e)qe/lh|sin, § 136.6; for -ei- see § 150.— su\n ... tara/ch|, tmesis.
580 ei)/ per, ‘just suppose.’
stufeli/cai, supply h(ma=s. The conclusion—‘he can do it’—is understood. Cf. l. 136.
kaqa/ptesqai, syntax, § 213.
i(/laos, § 77.
te/tlaqi, § 136.9.
e)n with o)fqalmoi=sin, ‘before.’
qeinome/nhn, in agreement with se (l. 587): ‘lest I see you being beaten.’
a)ntife/resqai limits a)rgale/os. Cf. manteu/esqai, l. 107.
h)/dh ga/r ... a)/llote, cf. h)/dh ga/r pote, l. 260.
memaw=ta, ‘eager,’ agrees with me.
ka/ppeson = kate/peson. For kap-, § 47.
meidh/sasa, translation of tense, § 186.
paido/s, ‘from her son.’
xeiri/, ‘with [or ‘in’] her hand.’

oi)noxo/ei (oi)=nos, xe/w) ... ne/ktar, the poet seems unconscious of the original meaning and thinks only of the main idea, ‘poured.’ Compare Xen. Anab. II, 4, 12: h)=n de\ [to\ tei=xos] w)|kodomhme/non, ‘the wall was built’; yet oi)kodome/w is literally to ‘build a house’ (oi)=kos and de/mw, ‘build’). Other examples are not uncommon.
a)fu/sswn, ‘drawing off,’ or ‘dipping’ with a ladle. The gods who are used to Hebe and Ganymedes as cupbearers make merry over the awkward Hephaestus.
e)nw=rto, e)n-o/rnumi.
ge/los, second declension in Homer (= Attic ge/lws, third declension); cf. similar nouns in this book: ma/rturoi (l. 338) and e)/ron (l. 469).
fo/rmiggos and *mousa/wn (l. 604), like daito/s, limit e)deu/eto.
kakkei/ontes (kata/ and kei=mai), cf. note on 16.852.
e)/ban, cf. l. 391.
h(=xi = Attic h(=|, ‘where.’
a)mfiguh/eis, ‘lame in both legs,’ ‘the halting god,’ according to the ancient interpretation: “both-foot-halting god,” Chapman renders it. Many prefer a modern interpretation: ‘strong in both arms.’

i)dui/h|si (Attic ei)dui/ais) prapi/dessin, ‘with cunning mind.’ Other works of this god that are mentioned in the Iliad are: the aegis and scepter of Zeus (B 101, O 308 ff.); the arms of Achilles (18.478 ff.); the wonderful golden maidens who supported the lame god's steps (18.417); the automatic tripods (18.373 ff.); the breastplate of Diomedes (8.195) that formerly belonged to Glaucus (Z 235). Still other works are told of in the Odyssey.
qeoi/ and a)ne/res, appositives to a)/lloi.
timh/sai, construction, § 199.
*)axaiw=n limits nhusi/n.

ou)=los, syntax, § 169. Countless dreams are kept ready for service, according to the poet of the Odyssey (Od. 19.560-567); those that are true pass forth by a gate of horn; the false by a gate of ivory.
a)goreue/men, syntax, § 213.
ka/rh § 100), accusative of specification.
13, 14. a)mfi\s ... fra/zontai, ‘counsel in two (diverse) ways’; ‘are at variance’ about the fate of Troy.
e)pe/gnamyen, ‘brought over.’
*nhlhi/w| ui(=i § 107), ‘to the son of Neleus.’ *nhlhi/w|, adjective, is equivalent to *nhlh=os, genitive.
ti=)(e), imperfect, = Attic e)ti/ma.
tw=| ... e)eisa/menos, ‘having likened himself to him,’ ‘assuming his likeness.’
*)atre/os, form, § 90.
ou) xrh/, ‘it befits not.’ Do not say, ‘it is not necessary.’
pannu/xion agrees with a)/ndra. How do you account for the fact that the ultima, though naturally short, receives the ictus? § 32.
e)pitetra/fatai, form, § 142.4, c; ‘are entrusted.’
cu/n-es, cun-i/hmi.
seu, with kh/detai.
33 sh=|sin e)/xe fresi/, ‘guard (this) in your heart.’
eu)=t' a)/n, cf. A 242.
a)n-h/h| (i(/hmi), like qh/h|, § 149 (2).

de\ li/p' (the reading of the best MS., Venetus A, and probably of Aristarchus) is written d' e)/lip' in other MSS. The latter reading is quite as likely as the former to be a correct interpretation of the original. This is one of many instances that illustrate the arbitrary character of editing with reference to the use of the augment.
au)tou=, ‘there’ on his couch.
frone/ont'(a) agrees with to/n (l. 35), ‘considering’ those things (ta/).
tele/esqai is probably future § 151).
e)/mellon, ‘were meant,’ ‘were destined.’
fh= § 126), ‘he thought.’
nh/pios, § 170.
Arrange thus: e)piqh/sein e)/mellen, which is like the Attic in construction and meaning.
ga/r receives the ictus, § 33.
e)/p'(i), for the accent see § 166.
min a)mfe/xuto, ‘was poured around him,’ ‘murmured in his ears.’
nhga/teon: the most reasonable meaning proposed for this doubtful word is ‘shining,’ ‘glistening,’ an epithet appropriate to a linen chiton.
skh=ptron, wrought by Hephaestus and given by him to Zeus, from whom it descended to Agamemnon (ll. 101-108).
The dawn of the twenty-second day of the poem, which is not ended until Book 7, l. 380; it is the first great day of battle. See note on A 8.
*zhni/, declension, § 98.
e)re/ousa, ‘to announce,’ ‘to herald.’
khru/kessi ... ke/leusen, regular construction in Homer. What follows keleu/w in Attic Greek? Cf. GG. 570 c.
khru/ssein, § 56.
boulh/n, object of i(=ze. The principal ‘elders’ (ge/rontes) are enumerated, ll. 404-408.
*nestore/h|, agreeing with nhi/, used instead of *ne/storos. Cf. *nhlhi/w|, l. 20.
basilh=os is in apposition to *ne/storos, the implied genitive.— *puloigene/os, formation, § 155.4.
h)rtu/neto = h(/rmoze, ‘framed.’ The root a)r, ‘fit,’ ‘fit together,’ is seen also in the Homeric a)rari/skw, etc.
dia\ nu/kta, ‘through the night,’ a Homeric idiom; cf. dia\ ... u(smi/nas, l. 40. How would the idea be expressed in Attic prose? Cf. Xen. Anab. IV, 6, 22: e)/kaon pura\ polla\ dia\ nukto/s.
57, 58. ma/lista ... a)/gxista, ‘he bore a very close resemblance to Nestor in particular’ (ma/lista).
w)/|xet' a)popta/menos, ‘flew off and was gone,’ ‘went flying off.’ See note on A 391. For ictus on -os see § 32.
ai)/ ken ... qwrh/comen (form, § § 144, II; 145), for construction see § 198.
h(\ qe/mis e)sti/n, ‘as is usual,’ like our “as is the rule.” The relative agrees with the predicate noun.
a)/lloqen a)/llos = Latin aliunde alius.
e)rhtu/ein, syntax, § 213. The object is ‘them,’ i. e. the Achaeans.
h)maqo/entos, formation, § 35, § 159.
Protasis of past contrary to fact—or “unreal past”—condition (GG. 649).
e)/nispen, second aorist of e)ne/pw, ‘tell.’
‘We should call it a deceit [on the part of an unfriendly god], and should retire rather’ than credit it; i. e. should turn our backs upon it On this use of the potential optative see § 207.
nu=n d'(e/), like A 417.
e)/c, why accented? § 166.
skhptou=xoi basilh=es, see note on A 234.
e)pesseu/onto, on double s see § 39.
h)u/te, ‘even as’; see note on A 359.
ei)=si, sometimes, as here, has a present meaning in Homer (not future, as in Attic).
melissa/wn, spelling, § 56.
a(dina/wn, a word of uncertain derivation: ‘restless,’ ‘murmuring.’ Here, ‘murmuring bees’; for other shades of meaning see notes on 16.481, 18.124, 316.
ai)ei\ ne/on e)rxomena/wn, ‘always pouring forth anew’; ‘with ever fresh flights.’
e)p' a)/nqesin would be e)p' a)/nqh (accusative) in Attic prose.
ei)arinoi=sin, formation, § 35.
ai(\ me/n ... ai(\ de/, translate as in Attic (GG. 549 a).
-te marks the general character of the statement.
pepoth/atai, form, § 142.4, a; meaning, § 187.
tw=n, an important word, ‘of them.’ the Achaeans.
o)/ssa dedh/ei (dai/w, on tense, § 188), ‘rumor was ablaze,’ spread like fire.
tetrh/xei (tense, § 188), tara/ssw.
sfeas, enclitic pronoun, § 110; to be read as one syllable, § 43.
sxoi/at'(o), syntax, § 198. 1. So, too, a)kou/seian.
spoudh=| = Attic mo/gis.
e)rh/tuqen, Attic ending? § 136.8.

a)rgei+fo/nth|, epithet of Hermes: this may scarcely be translated ‘slayer of Argus,’ for Homer does not show any knowledge of the story of Io, which was probably later. In fact. dia/ktoros a)rgei+fo/nths belongs to a list of holy formulas, not in every instance clearly understood by the Greeks themselves, but probably inherited from very ancient ritual songs. Others are: po/tnia *(/hrh, nefelhgere/ta *zeu/s, di=a qea/wn, doth=res e)a/wn, *(ermei/as a)ka/khta, kudi/sth *tritoge/neia. It has been suggested that ‘the bright-appearing’ (cf. a)rgh/s and fai/nw) was possibly the original sense of ‘argeïphontes.’
*(ermei/as, ending, § 66.
Thyestes was a brother of Atreus and after the latter's death succeeded to the kingship during the minority of Agamemnon.
*que/st'(a), § 67; = *que/sths.
forh=nai, form, § 131; syntax, § 211.
*)/argei+ panti/, the whole Peloponnesus. See note on A 79.
a)na/ssein, in same construction as forh=nai.
e)n-e/dhse, e)n-de/w.
sxe/tlios, ‘harsh god!’ Cf. nh/pios, l. 38.
e)kpe/rsant'(a) agrees with me understood. Cf. A 541.

a)pone/esqai, for long initial vowel see § 34. The present of this verb usually has a future meaning, like the presents mentioned in note on 16.852. Translate, ‘should sack and return’ or ‘should sack before returning.’
duskle/a, shortened from dusklee/a. It is probably better to read dusklee/).
*)/argos, syntax, § 179.
‘Such is the pleasure, doubtless, of Zeus, who is above all in might.’ On me/llei ei)=nai cf. A 564.
ka/rhna, declension, § 100.
kai/, ‘too.’
‘For this is shameful even for future men to hear.’
puqe/sqai limits ai)sxro/n. Cf. a)ntife/resqai, A 589, manteu/esqai, A 107. The next two lines and a half explain to/de.
toio/nde toso/nde te lao/n, ‘so brave and so many soldiers.’
d'(e/) = ga/r. See note on A 5.
pe/fantai, singular, for n belongs to the theme, not to the ending.
ei) ... k'(e), with optative; see on A 60.

o(/rkia pista\ tamo/ntes, ‘after sacrificing trusty oath sacrifices,’ ‘after offering sacrifices for a faithful treaty’; in this idiom o(/rkia is cognate object of tamei=n, ‘sacrifice.’ Properly the verb means ‘to cut’ the throat of the victim; cf. 3.292.
a)riqmhqh/menai, where found? § 137.1, b.
[ei)] *trw=es me/n [k' e)qe/loien] le/casqai, ‘if the Trojans should be willing to assemble themselves.’
le/casqai = sullegh=nai kai\ a)qroisqh=nai e)n tau)tw=| (scholium).
e)fe/stioi o(/ssoi e)/asin (= Attic ei)si/n), ‘all that are at home.’
Again understand ei) at the beginning of this clause and of the next (l. 127).
oi)noxoeu/ein, syntax, § 211.
e(/kastoi, each deka/s.
The conclusion of the conditions (ll. 123-127).
deuoi/ato, for the Attic equivalent cf. notes on A 134, 468.—See note after l. 483 as to relative numbers of Achaeans and Trojans.
ple/as, short form of ple/onas.
polle/wn, cf. polla/wn (l. 117), and for scansion, § 43.
pla/zousi occurred A 59 (plagxqe/ntas).
ei)w=s'(i) = e)a/ousi.
dh/, ‘already.’
beba/asi, form, § 133, foot-note.
dou=ra § 97), ‘timbers.’ After a neuter plural subject Homer uses a singular or plural verb at his pleasure.
h(/at'(ai), form, § 142.4, b.
potide/gmenai (from prosde/xomai), § 131.
au)/tws, ‘still’ unaccomplished.
w(s a)\n e)gw\ ei)/pw, ‘as I shall direct,’ protasis of the more vivid future condition (GG. 632 A, 650; GMT. 529).
peiqw/meqa, hortatory subjunctive.
ou) ... e)/ti ... ai(rh/somen, ‘no longer is there hope that we shall take.’
meta\ plhqu/n, ‘among the crowd,’ a distinctly Homeric idiom; remarkable here because used with a verb of rest. Cf. A 221, 222, bebh/kei ... meta\ dai/monas.

fh/, ‘like,’ is noted in the scholia as the reading of Zenodotus, but the MSS. here all have w(s. It is interesting to know that this ancient particle of comparison has been preserved in one other place in Homer (14.499) by the requirement of the meter.
euro/s te no/tos te, i. e. the wind between these two points, ‘a southeast wind.’ See note on I 5.
w)/ror'(e), where found? § 128. Distinguish from perfect o)/rwren, l. 797.
w(s d' o(/te, common Homeric formula to introduce a simile; ‘and as [happens] when’ etc.—kinh/sh|, ke or a)/n omitted, § 197.
la/bros, with adverbial force, ‘violently.’
e)/pi, ‘thereto,’ yielding to the assault of the wind.
h)mu/ei, the subject is lh/ion.
a)lalhtw=|, ‘with shouting.’
i(/stat'(o) (in sense of a)ni/stato as explained by scholium), ‘stood up,’ ‘stood aloft.’
i(eme/nwn § 61.22), ‘eager to go,’ agrees with a pronoun, ‘of them,’ understood.
What is the force of ken with the aorist indicative e)tu/xqh (= e)ge/neto)? GG. 467 c, 468 b.
u(pe/rmora, ‘beyond the decrees of fate,’ i. e. that had not been determined by fate.
This interference of the goddesses is to be placed side by side with that in A; see note on A 194.
w)\ po/poi, see note on A 254.
a)trutw/nh, see note on a)rgei+fo/nths, l. 103. The original meaning was perhaps ‘the unwearied,’ ‘the invincible.’
ka/d, § 47; translate with the verb, as if kata-li/poien.
eu)xwlh/n, ‘as a boast’ in apposition to *(ele/nhn (l. 161).
nh=as, on the quantity of the ultima see § 32. But the force of a lost sigma of [s]a/lade (cf. Lat. sal) may have been still felt.
a)i/casa, on the tense, § 186; with bh=, ‘she darted away.’ Cf. notes on l. 71 and A 391.
mh=tin has the ictus on the ultima, although it is short; see § 33.
e(stao/t'(a), i(/sthmi.
e)usse/lmoio, on double s see § 39.
min, syntax, § 179.
kradi/hn, qumo/n, syntax, § 180.
peso/ntes, ‘tumbling,’ of disorderly embarkation, because hasty. Embarking in good order would be expressed by e)mba/ntes, as is suggested by a scholium.

mhde/ t' e)rw/ei [Monro (Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 332) accepts as better the reading of four MSS., mhd' e)/t' e)rw/ei], ‘and do not delay’; with this verb associate the noun e)rwh/ (16.302), ‘cessation.’ But e)rwh/sei, ‘shall run,’ ‘shall gush out’ (A 303), seems to be a different word; with it is to be associated a corresponding noun, e)rwh/ (3.62), ‘rush,’ ‘thrust,’ ‘blow.’
fwnhsa/shs, translate by present, § 186.
qe/ein, syntax, § 211; ‘he started to run.’
This Eurybates is to be distinguished from the herald of Agamemnon, mentioned A 320.
o(/s, why long? § 61.6.
*)agame/mnonos limits a)nti/os, ‘to meet’; compare the similar con struction with the adverb e)nanti/on, A 534.
oi(, dative of interest, meaning here ‘from him.’ The scepter became the symbol of his authorization to speak on behalf of Agamemnon to the kings who were his peers and to the common soldiers.
kixei/h, optative in protasis of past general condition; on the form cf. subjunctive kixei/w, A 26.
e)rhtu/saske, meaning of suffix? § 154.1.
daimo/ni'(e), ‘sir! your conduet is unaccountable’; cf. note on A 561.
