kako/n, on quantity of the ultima see § 37.

deidi/ssesqai § 62), elsewhere in Homer transitive, and perhaps here too; ‘it is not befitting to terrify you, like a low-born man.’ Others understand it (here only) as intransitive, ‘it is not becoming for you to be afraid.’
ou) ga/r pw sa/fa oi)=sq'(a), oi(=o/s [e)sti] no/os ktl., ‘for you do not yet clearly know what [literally ‘of what sort’] is the purpose of the son of Atreus.’
boulh=|, the council of the ge/rontes.
oi(=on e)/eipen, ll. 56-75.
‘May he not in his wrath (as I fear he may) do some harm to the sons of the Achaeans.’ This distinctly Homeric construction expresses an object of fear with the desire to avert it. See GMT. 261.
qumo/s, ‘spirit.’
basilh=os, Agamemnon, if the statement is not general.
Note the emphasis continually laid on the belief that the Homeric king rules by divine right.
‘And, again, whatsoever man of the people he saw and found bawling out.’ For the occasion of their shouting cf. l. 151, toi\ d' a)llh/loisi ke/leuon ktl.
e)la/sasken, ‘would strike’ § 154.1).
daimo/ni'(e), cf. note on l. 190.
e)nari/qmios, ‘counted in,’ ‘of account.’
me/n = mh/n § 31).

a)gaqo/n, a neuter substantive in the predicate, as often in Attic Greek, instead of a predicate adjective (a)gaqh/). Cf. foberw/taton d' e)rhmi/a (Xen. Anab. II, 5, 9), ‘solitude is a most fearful thing.’
Omitted in most MSS. The interpolator evidently had in mind I 99, but made a bad metrical blunder when he used basileu/h| for bouleu/h|sin.
sfi/si, ‘them,’ i. e. his subjects, is introduced very awkwardly.
h)xh=| the ‘roar’ of voices is meant. Cf. a)lalhtw=|, l. 149.
te, as oiten, marks the general character of the statement.
*qersi/ths, the significance of the name is of some interest (the ‘Bold’); the first element is qe/rsos, said to be Aeolic for qa/rsos.
mou=nos = Attic mo/nos.
The sense of lines 213-215 is: ‘who knew how to say many uncivil things, so as to quarrel with kings in a reckless and unseemly way, and to prate whatever he thought was ridiculous to the Argives.’
Why is o(/s long? § 61.16.
e)/pea ... a)/kosma/ te polla/ te, ‘words both disorderly and many’ is literal.
e)rize/menai, syntax, § 212.
After a)ll' supply le/gein or a similar verb.
ei)/saito = Attic do/ceie, optative in protasis of a past general condition. See GG. 616 b, 618, 651 (2).

ai)/sxistos a)nh/r, ‘the ugliest man’ in predicate relation to the subject of h)=lqen. Compare ka/rtistoi, A 266 and note. “The most ill-favored wight was he ... of all the Grecian host” (J. S. Blackie).
u(po\ *)/ilion, Troy was situated on a hill.
e)/hn = h)=en (A 381) = Attic h)=n.
e(/teron po/da, ‘in one foot,’ accusative of specification.
sunoxwko/te (form, § 127), ‘bent together,’ ‘cramped.’
kefalh/n, for construction cf. po/da, l. 217.—yednh\ ktl., ‘and sparse was the woolly hair that grew thereon.’
e)/xqistos ... ma/list'(a), cf. note on l. 58.
o)ce/a keklhgw/s, ‘with shrill cries.’
le/g'(e), ‘he kept telling over,’ ‘recounting.’
tw=|, Agamemnon. It was because Thersites had the crowd behind him that he dared to be so insolent.
makra\ bow=n, ‘bawling loud.’
te/o (Attic ti/nos or tou=), § 122.1; genitive of cause with e)pime/mfeai,
dh\ au)=te, § 43.
plei=ai, supply ei)si/.
eu(=t' a)/n = what in Attic prose? GG. 628. A present general protasis.
h)/, introducing a question; cf. note on A 133.
e)/ti, ‘besides.’— e)pideu/eai = Attic e)pi-de/ei, ‘you want.’
oi)/sei (with ke), § 190.
tis (l. 229) ... *trw/wn i(ppoda/mwn, ‘a Trojan horseman.’
ui(=os, genitive, § 107.
a)/poina, ‘as a ransom,’ in apposition to o(\n [xruso/n], l. 229.

gunai=ka, the genitive (gunaiko/s) would be expected, to correspond with xrusou= (l. 229); but either the poet loses sight of a specific verb, or perhaps he has in mind poqe/eis, which takes the accusative, as A 492.— mi/sgeai and kati/sxeai (l. 233) are present subjunctives, the ending -eai being shortened from -hai ( § 28, § 29).
h(/n t'(e) ... kati/sxeai, purpose clause.
au)to/s, with ictus on ultima, § 33.
Understand tina/, ‘a man,’ as subject of e)pibaske/men.
pe/pones, ‘weaklings’; cf. Achilles's word, ou)tidanoi=sin, A 231.— e)le/gxe'(a), ‘reproaches,’ ‘wretches.’
*)axaii/des, ou)ke/t' *)axaioi/, imitated in Vergil's words (Aen. IX, 617), O vere Phrygiae (neque enim Phryges).
pesse/men, cf. katape/yh|, A 81; what is the metaphor involved?
xh)mei=s, form, § 44.
ou)ki/, generally found at end of sentence and of verse = Attic ou)/.
e(/o, accented, § 111.4; a genitive after the comparative a)mei/nona.
e(/o has the ictus on the ultima, § 38.
a)lla\ meqh/mwn [e)sti/], ‘but he is remiss,’ he lets things pass. Thersites perhaps has in mind how Achilles stopped in the very act of drawing his sword on Agamemnon (A 219).
The very words used by Achilles, A 232.
poime/na law=n, the full significance of this phrase is discussed by Socrates, as related by Xenophon, Memorabilia, III, 2, 1. Cf. note on 3.179.
u(po/dra i)dw/n, cf. A 148.
h)ni/pape, peculiar formation, § 129.
o(/ssoi ... h)=lqon, ‘of all that came.’
‘Therefore [tw=|, cf. A 418] you had better not speak with kings passing through your mouth.’
a)\n ... a)goreu/ois is potential optative with the force of a prohibition—in mock courtesy; cf. A 301.

a)na\ sto/ma may be rendered freely, ‘on your tongue’ or ‘on your lips’; cf. Xen. Cyropaedia, I, 4, 25: pa/ntes to\n *ku=ron dia\ sio/matos ei)=xon kai\ e)n lo/gw| kai\ e)n w)|dai=s, ‘all had Cyrus on their lips both in speech and in songs.’
Before profe/rois and fula/ssois, which are in the same construction with a)goreu/ois, understand ou)k a)/n: ‘you had better not heap reproaches on them and watch (your chance for) going home.’
h(\sai o)neidi/zwn, ‘you keep on reproaching’; for this meaning of h(=mai cf. A 415, 416. Thersites sat down later (l. 268).
didou=sin, for dido/-nsin § 133).
kixh/somai, first aorist subjunctive, probably; the corresponding indicative, kixh/sato, occurs Z 498 and elsewhere. Cf. § 145.
w(/s nu/ per w(=de, ‘even as you now are.’
mhke/t' ... e)pei/h, what sort of wish? § 201. Odysseus emphatically says *)odush=i instead of e)moi/.
a)po\ ... du/sw, tmesis.
fi/la, meaning, § 114.
ai)do/a, ‘nakedness.’
[se] au)to/n, ‘you yourself,’ object of a)fh/sw.
peplhgw/s, ‘scourging.’
skh/ptrou ... xruse/ou, cf. note on A 246.
ta/rbhsen, see notes on A 85, 331.
a)lgh/sas, ‘smarting with pain.’
a)xrei=on i)dw/n, ‘with a foolish look.’
a)xnu/menoi, on account of disappointment about going home.— h(du/, ‘sweetly,’ ‘pleasantly,’ ‘heartily.’
tis, ‘many a one.’
ei)/pesken, force of suffix, § 154.1.
plhsi/on, substantive (from plhsi/os); with a)/llon, ‘his neighbor.’
w)\ po/poi, cf. A 254.
dh/, ‘already.’
boula/s (a kind of cognate accusative) t' e)ca/rxwn a)gaqa/s, ‘taking the lead in good counsels.’
koru/sswn, ‘arming (with helmet),’ here metaphorically, ‘marshaling’ (po/lemon).
a)/riston, in predicate relation to to/de, ‘this is by far the best deed that he has done.’
o(/s, introducing a causal clause; ‘in that he restrained that slanderer—impudent as he was—from his harangues.’
a)gora/wn, syntax?
qhn, ‘I rather think,’ in irony.
pa/lin au)=tis a)nh/sei (a\n-i/hmi), ‘will impel him back here again.’
fa/san, note the plural with collective subject, plhqu/s.
oi( prw=toi/ te kai\ u(/statoi, ‘both the nearest and the farthest.’ But oi( may be the pronoun, a dative of reference.
pa=sin ... mero/pessi brotoi=sin, ‘in the sight of all mortal men.’
qe/menai, for meaning cf. note on A 2; for form cf. do/menai, A 98.
e)ktele/ousin, tense, § 151.
Cf. l. 113. With e)kpe/rsant'(a) supply se.
w(/s te (Attic w(/sper), ‘like.’
h)/ (the MS. reading) is superfluous to the sense; h)/ ... h)/, or te ... te, would be natural enough, but not h)/ ... te. Some editors read h)=.

‘Surely there is toil enough for a man in weariness to return,’ i. e. to cause him to return home. Supply tina/ as subject of ne/esqai. It is possible, by adopting one or more of the emendations proposed for this line, to get a more usual construction and perhaps better sense; but they are all without MS. authority.
kai\ ga/r, ‘for even,’ as sometimes in Attic Greek (GG. 672 d).
q', in general statement.
ei)le/wsin, to be read with synizesis; for meaning cf. e)/lsai, A 409. How is the mood accounted for? Cf. e(/lwmen, l. 228, and § 197.
h(mi=n, dative of interest; cf. tw=|, A 250.
e)/nnatos, for e)/nvatos. Compare e)na/th, l. 313, where digamma is neglected. This line does not quite accord with l. 134, where the nine years are said to be already gone.
mimno/ntessi = me/nousi (in Attic prose), dative plural of me/nwn (l. 292)
keneo/n (Attic keno/n), ‘empty-handed,’ agrees with tina/ understood, the subject of the two infinitives.
mh/ (instead of ou)), because the relative clause is the protasis of a condition.
e)/ban ... fe/rousai, ‘carried off’; see notes on A 391, B 71.

xqiza/ te kai\ prwi/z'(a), ‘yesterday or the day before’; the sense is: ‘a day or two from the time when the ships gathered at Aulis,’ or ‘hardly had the ships gathered at Aulis,’ when etc. Others render: ‘but a day or two ago, when’ etc., making the phrase epitomize the nine intervening years between the mustering at Aulis and the present moment.
dafoino/s, meaning of prefix, § 160.
a)ta/r, ‘while.’
te/kna, object of o)durome/nh, which, though often taking a genitive of cause, is sometimes used transitively (T 345, 24.714, 740).

d' e)lelica/menos is probably for an original de\ velica/menos, aorist of e(li/ssw § 61.15), which naturally means ‘coiling himself up.’ Similar formations occurring elsewhere also (as from e)leli/zw) have been noted and corrected by editors.
a)mfiaxui=an (commonly called perfect of a)mfia/xw) is probably another example of a word not transmitted in its original form.
a)ri/zhlon (=a)ri/dhlon), meaning of prefix, § 160.
o(/s per e)/fhnen, ‘who also revealed him’ or ‘the very god that’ etc. (GG. 216.)
qauma/zomen, imperfect. Homer does not use the historical present. see § 182.
e)tu/xqh, ‘came to pass’; cf. l. 155.

qew=n, with e(kato/mbas. This line is usually connected with the following one instead of the preceding. But the punctuation of our text seems to have been that of Cicero's (cf. De Divinatione, II, 30, 64).
ei)s o(/ ken = Attic e(/ws (a)/xri, me/xri, e)/ste) a)/n.

*gerh/nios. When Pylos was sacked by Heracles, so the old story ran, and Nestor's eleven brothers were slain, Nestor alone escaped, for he was being cared for e)n *gerh/nois (scholium), a Messenian people or place. So he was called Gerenian. It is altogether probable, however, that the story is fanciful, and that the name is a relic of a remote past which even the later epic poets themselves were unfamiliar with.
w)\ po/poi, cf. A 254, where Nestor begins with the same words.— h(/ dh/, ‘surely now.’
‘In what way, then, will our compacts and oaths come out?’ That is, ‘what, then, will become of our compacts and oaths?’ The allusion is evidently the same as in ll. 286-288.
bh/setai conforms to the neuter plural subject o(/rkia only; cf. note on l. 135.

‘Then may all plans and counsels of men be burned’ to nothing! If these pledges given by you—worthless as they turn out to be—are typical of all such, better that they all be brought to naught than continue to mislead.
spondai\ a)/krhtoi, ‘libations unmixed’ (with water). The wine furnished by the contracting parties was mingled in token of cementing the contract.
e)pe/piqmen § 57) = e)pepoi/qemen.
au)/tws, ‘in vain.’
polu\n xro/non ... e)o/ntes, to be rendered by the English perfect. Cf. A 553.
e)/q' (e)/ti) w(s pri/n § 30), ‘still as before.’
e(/na kai\ du/o, ‘one or two’; for kai/ compare xqiza/ te kai\ prwi/za, l. 303. The words are in apposition to tou/sde.
*)axaiw=n limits toi/, ‘who of the Achaeans.’

au)tw=n, perhaps a neuter objective genitive with a)/nusis, ‘accomplishment of them,’ i. e. of the plans. But it is probably better to take au)tw=n as a predicate genitive of possession referring to the ‘one or two’ Achaeans and translate: ‘but they shall not achieve anything.’
pri\n ... pri/n, used as in A 97, 98.
i)e/nai limits bouleu/ws)(i) (l. 347).
*dio\s ai)gio/xoio, construction, § 174 (3).
a)stra/ptwn, nominative when the accusative would be regular to agree with *kroni/wna (l. 350).
tina, ‘every man.’

ti/sasqai (ti/nw), ‘take pay for.’—*(ele/nhs o(rmh/mata ktl., ‘the efforts and groans about Helen’ is the better of the traditional interpretations: i. e. the efforts and groans that we Greeks have put forth for her.
e)pi/sph| (e)fe/pw), ‘meet’ death: for we shall slay him on the spot.
frh/trhfin § 155.1), in the same construction as fu/lois.
gnw/sh|, i. e. gnw/seai.
o(/s ktl., ‘whoever of the leaders is cowardly and who of the soldiers, and whoever is brave.’
e)/h|si, form, § 136.6; for the syntax cf. GG. 616 a. 621 a.
kata\ sfe/as (to be read with synizesis), for meaning compare A 271.
maxe/ongai, future, § 151.
ei)=en, in a hardly attainable wish. see § 202.
me ... ba/llei. ‘plunges me.’
h)=rxon xalepai/nwn, ‘was first to be angry.’
ei) de/ pot' e)/s ge mi/an [boulh\n] bouleu/somen, ‘if ever our plans shall converge into one plan,’ i. e. ‘if we shall ever plan in accord.’
a)na/blhsis, on the suffix, § 156.2.
cuna/gwmen = Latin committamus. *)/arha is the personification of proelium or pugnam. Cf. Vergil's proelia ... conserimus (Aen. II, 397 f.).
tis, ‘every man,’ as in l. 355.
a)spi/da qe/sqw, ‘let him make his shield ready.’ ‘Let him gird on [peri-qe/sqw, ‘put on’] his shield’ is the interpretation of a scholiast.
a)mfi\s i)dw/n seems to be for an original a)mfi\ vidw/n § 61.23), ‘looking on both sides of,’ ‘seeing to’; with a(/rmatos.
w(/s ke ... krinw/meq'(a), ‘that we may strive together [literally ‘seek a decision’] in hateful war.’ For the syntax of the clause, § 196.
mete/ssetai, ‘shall intervene.’
ei) mh/, ‘except that,’ ‘until.’
teu, enclitic pronoun, § 122.2; ‘many a man's.’
sth/qesfin, § 155.1.
a)spi/dos a)mfibro/ths, the big shield. Cf. Introduction, 23.— xei=ra, accusative of specification.—As subject of kamei=tai understand tis, ‘many a man.’
o(\n de/ k'(e) ... noh/sw, protasis of the more vivid future condition.
mimna/zein limits e)qe/lonta, which agrees with o(/n (l. 391).
ou)/ oi(, why not ou)/x oi(? § 61.6.

a)/rkion, ‘sufficient,’ ‘secure.’ The latter meaning applies here: ‘it shall not be assured to him hereafter to escape dogs and birds of prey,’ or freely, ‘he shall have no security hereafter from dogs and birds of prey.’ —For the form e)ssei=tai see note on A 211.
ku=ma, supply i)a/xh|.
problh=ti skope/lw|, in apposition to a)kth=| (l. 395), to which it gives a more definite conception.
ku/mata (l. 396) pantoi/wn a)ne/mwn, ‘waves driven by all the various winds.’
ge/nwntai, subject understood, a)/nemoi.

a)/llos d' a)/llw| (Latin alius alii) e)/reze ktl., ‘one man made sacrifice to one of the ever-living gods, another man to another.’ This implies that particular divinities were worshiped by different tribes.—Lines 400-410 illustrate the commonest of the metrical pauses, § 16

boh\n a)gaqo/s, ‘good at the martial cry,’ epithet of a brave man. It is to be noted that the trumpet (sa/lpigc) was not used by Homeric heroes; the word occurs but once, in fact, and then in a simile (18.219). Signals for attack and retreat were given by powerful shouting on the part of the leaders.

a)delfeo/n, Attic a)delfo/n, cf. keneo/n, l. 298.—The subject of the clause w(s e)ponei=to is introduced in advance, and made object of the principal verb (proleptic accusative): ‘he knew his brother, how he was toiling’; i. e. ‘he knew how his brother was toiling.’ Compare “You find yourself ... watching the storms how they gather,” Kinglake's Eothen, Examples in older English are not uncommon.

Pope paraphrases this line:
Oh thou! whose thunder rends the clouded air,
Who in the heaven of heavens hast fix'd thy throne,
Supreme of gods! unbounded and alone!
See also notes on A 420, B 458.
pri\n ... pri/n, cf. note on A 97.—For construction of du=nai and e)pi\ ... e)lqei=n (tmesis), § 213.
ka/ta, for accent on penult cf. § 164.
prhne/s, predicate adjective limiting me/laqron, after which it is to be translated ‘headlong’; the use is metaphorical, the adjective commonly being applied to living creatures.

bale/ein, form, § 137.4.—Instead of the Homeric me ... bale/ein, what construction follows pri/n in Attic Greek after a negative clause? Cf. Xen. Anab. I, 1, 10: kai\ dei=tai au)tou= mh\ pro/sqen katalu=sai pro\s tou\s a)ntistasiw/tas pri\n a)\n au)tw=| sumbouleu/shtai. GG. 644 b and d.
ai)qalo/en, ‘smoke-begrimed’ roof; the me/garon had no chimney; and the roof and walls became stained with smoke from the hearth and from braziers and torches used for illuminating at night.
prh=sai, here ‘burn’; cf. A 481, where the sense is ‘puffed out.’

puro/s, ‘with fire,’ a kind of partitive genitive, where an instrumental dative would be expected; prh/qw is used with the genitive after the analogy of verbs of sharing and filling, which regularly take a partitive genitive (of material).
dhi/oio, h is short in scansion, § 28.
*(ekto/reon, for *(/ektoros, cf. *nhlhi/w|, l. 20; *nestore/h|, l. 54.
dai+/cai with subject me (l. 414) is also included in the pri/n construction: ‘and until I have rent Hector's tunic on his breast so that it is ragged [or ‘into shreds’] with my bronze.’
pole/es, declension, § 106.
lazoi/ato, why optative? § 201.
o)da/c, cf. note on T 61.
de/kto, form, § 131.
i(ra/ = Attic i(era/.
a)me/garton, used like r(wgale/on (l. 417): ‘so that it was unenviable’; i. e. ‘to a sad extent.’
u(pei/r-exon, for an original u(pe/r-sexon.
*(hfai/stoio = puro/s.
mhke/ti ... legw/meqa, ‘let us no longer be gathered’ is a traditional rendering; others translate the verb, ‘talk with one another.’

a)mballw/meqa, for meaning cf. a)na/blhsis, l. 380. With reference to this word an interesting digression of the scholia is worth repeating: e)rwthqei\s gou=n *)ale/candros, pw=s th=s *(ella/dos e)kra/thse, “mhde\n a)naballo/menos” ei)=pen.
a)geiro/ntwn, imperative.
i)/omen, subjunctive, § 143.
qa=sson is rendered by Nägelsbach ‘the sooner the better.’
e)gei/romen, aorist subjunctive, § 144, ll.—For the construction o)/fra (‘in order that’) ke ktl. see § 196.
kri/nontes, ‘marshaling’ (literally ‘separating’) into tribes and clans; cf. l. 362.
e)ri/timon, force of prefix, § 160.

a)gh/raon a)qana/thn, ‘ageless,’ ‘immortal,’ not precisely equivalent in meaning. The distinetion is nicely drawn in the ancient myth of Tithonus, the husband of Dawn (*)hw/s); being a mortal, he asked for immortality (a)qanasi/an) from her who was a goddess; this he received and lived on forever; but because through ignorance he did not ask for agelessness (a)ghrasi/an) as well, he presently became subject to the troubles of old age. The goddess could not grant his request for death, but changed him into a cicada.
h)ere/qontai, spelling, § 35.
kardi/h|, with e(ka/stw| (l. 451), § 180.
a)/llhkton, spelling, § 39.
te, what is its force here? Cf. l. 90.
tw=n, ‘of them,’ with xalkou=.
qespesi/oio, freely, ‘countless,’ with reference to the shields and weapons.
pamfana/ousa shows the reduplicated root fan. Compare paifa/s: sousa, l. 450.
ai)qe/ros, the clear air above the denser a)h/r. The top of Olympus is in this element; so Zeus is spoken of, l. 412, as ai)qe/ri nai/wn.
tw=n can not be translated at this point; it is later repeated (l. 464), when care must be taken to render it.
doulixodei/rwn, spelling, § 35.

*)asi/w| e)n leimw=ni, ‘in the Asian meadow.’ So the words were understood by Vergil, who speaks of the birds ‘that seek everywhere for food through the Asian meads, in the sweet pools of Caÿstrus’: [volucres] quae Asia circum dulcibus in stagnis rimantur prata Caÿstri. Georgics, I. 383, 384.

Again he alludes to the Asia palus (Aen. VII, 701, 702), home of swans. [*)asi/w, i. e. *)asi/ew, genitive of *)asi/as, is a common reading also; the sense then is, ‘the meadow of Asias,’ who is said to have been a king of the Lydians.]

prokaqizo/ntwn, occurring where a finite verb parallel with potw=ntai might be expected, agrees with the genitives that have preceded, either o)rni/qwn (l. 459) or its appositive nouns (l. 460). The Homeric order should be preserved in translation: ‘as they noisily keep settling to the fore.’

smaragei= de/ te leimw/n, Vergil's
sonat amnis et Asia longe
pulsa palus (Aen. VII, 701, 702), ‘the river and the Asian mead resound with echoes far and wide.’
proxe/onto, the ultima remains short before *skama/ndrion: cf. l. 467 also. This is a metrical irregularity.
au)tw=n, ‘of the men themselves.’
te, not to be translated, § 123.3.
a(dina/wn, see note on l. 87.
ai(/ te and (l. 471) o(/te te, § 123.3.
deu/ei, ‘wets,’ a distinet verb from deu/omai, ‘want.’
tou/s, not to be translated at this point; it is repeated in l. 476, where it must not be neglected.
r(ei=a = Attic r(a|di/ws.
terpikerau/nw|, § 59.
zw/nhn, ‘waist,’ means a woman's ‘girdle’ usually.
bou=s, a noun of common gender; with tau=ros (l. 481) in apposition, ‘bull’; in the plural, meaning ‘herds,’ bo/es is feminine, as l. 481 and A 154.
a)ge/lhfi, syntax, § 177 (a).
e)/pleto, ‘is,’ § 184.
h(rw/essin, ‘among the warriors,’ with e)/coxon.

Then follows, after an invocation of the Muses, the “Catalogue of the Ships,” a summary of the forces gathered at Troy. It is particularly valuable as an epitome of very ancient Greek geography. It has little excuse, however, for being thrust into the narrative at this point, where it makes but a tedious interruption. It is recognized by crities as the latest accretion to the poem, belonging probably to the seventh century B. C.

Altogether 1,186 ships of the Greeks are enumerated; there were 120 men in each ship of the Boeotian contingent, the poet relates; and he later gives the number in each of the ships of Philoctetes (from Methone, etc.) as 50. On the basis of these data it is impossible to figure with any exactness the number of men whom the Greeks believed to have gone against Troy. A scholium on B 122 states that the number of Greeks is said by some to have been 120,000, by others 140,000; the Trojans, without reckoning allies, numbered 50,000 (according to 8.562, 563).

Following are the introductory lines of the Catalogue:
e)/spete nu=n moi, *mou=sai *)olu/mpia dw/mat' e)/xousai,—
u(mei=s ga\r qeai/ e)ste pa/reste/ te i)/ste te pa/nta,
h(mei=s de\ kle/os oi)=on a)kou/omen ou)de/ ti i)/dmen—
oi(/ tines h(gemo/nes *danaw=n kai\ koi/ranoi h(=san.
plhqu\n d' ou)k a)\n e)gw\ muqh/somai ou)d' o)nomh/nw,
ou)d' ei)/ moi de/ka me\n glw=ssai de/ka de\ sto/mat' ei)=en,
fwnh\ d' a)/rrhktos, xa/lkeon de/ moi h)=tor e)nei/h,
ei) mh\ *)olumpia/des *mou=sai *dio\s ai)gio/xoio
qugate/res mnhsai/aq', o(/soi u(po\ *)/ilion h)=lqon.
a)rxou\s au)= nhw=n e)re/w nh=a/s te propa/sas.
With them may be compared Vergil's Aeneid, VII, 641-646; VI, 625, 626.
The description of the advancing host of Achaeans is resumed.
*dii\ w(/s (cf. § 33, § 37, end), ‘as under the might of Zens.’
ei)n, § 35, end.
pedi/oio, syntax, § 171.
w)ke/a, spelling, § 29.
a)gora/s, what kind of accusative? GG. 536 a.
de/gmenos § 131), ‘awaiting the time when’ (o(ppo/te).
nau=fin = new=n, § 155.1.
mu=qoi ... a)/kritoi, cf. a)krito/muqe, l. 246.
e)p' ei)rh/nhs, ‘in the time of peace.’
o)/rwren, cf. l. 146.
polla/, ‘often.’
toio/nde toso/nde te, see note on l. 120.
pedi/oio, syntax, § 171.
a)/llh d' a)/llwn glw=ssa, in Latin alia aliorum lingua: ‘some speak one tongue, others another.’
pa=sai ... pi/lai, according to Aristarchus, means ‘the whole gate’; he contended that there was but one great gate of Troy, the ‘Scaean,’ known also as the ‘Dardanian’ (X 194).
o)rw/rei, pluperfect (on translation of the tense see § 188).
po/lios, the last two syllables must be pronounced as one (-yos); and this one is lengthened ( § 32, § 33).
The remainder of the book (ll. 816-877) mentions the allies of the Trojans.
klaggh=| t' e)noph=| t'(e), syntax, § 178.
o)/rniqes w(/s, scanned --- -; for the quantity of -qes see § 37.
per = kai/, ‘also,’ and belongs with gera/nwn. Cf. A 131.
pe/lei ou)rano/qi pro/, ‘rises in heaven, to the fore,’ ‘rises before heaven.’

Vergil (Aen. X, 264-266) condenses the simile thus:
quales sub nubibus atris
Strymoniae dant signa grues, atque aethera tranant
cum sonitu, fugiuntque notos clamore secundo.
‘As beneath the stormy clouds Strymonian cranes proclaim their approach, sweeping noisily through the air and fleeing before the winds “with clamor in their train.”’
xeimw=na, ‘winter.’
e)p'(i/) with genitive = ‘toward’ here.

The existence of pygmies was known to Herodotus also, who had heard of some little men living in a remote (and rather indefinite) country reached by journeying south and west from Libya (Herod. II, 32). Accounts of African pygmies are familiar enough from the reports of numerous travelers of our own day. So, while Homer's battles between pygmies and cranes belong to the realm of fairyland, it is not to be doubted that he had a basis of fact for his mention of the diminutive men.
e)/rida, form, § 80.
kate/xeuen, on translating the tense, § 184.
kle/pth| de/ te nukto\s a)mei/nw (accusative singular agreeing with o)mi/xlhn, l. 10), ‘but better for a thief than night.’
The order for translation is: e)pi\ to/sson, e)pi\ o(/son, (a man can see) ‘only so far as’ etc.
pedi/oio, syntax § 171.
e)p' a)llh/loisin i)o/ntes = Attic e)p' a)llh/lous i)o/ntes.

Tennyson says of Paris in Oenone:
A leopard skin
Droop'd from his shoulder, but his sunny hair
Cluster'd about his temples like a god's.
prokali/zeto, ‘challenged’ by his attitude, not by speech.
makra\ (cognate accusative) biba/nta, ‘with long strides.’
w(/s te le/wn e)xa/rh, ‘as a lion rejoices,’ § 184.
kerao/n, on quantity of the ultima, § 32.

div.l: seu/wntai, § 197.1. The apodosis (katesqi/ei) of this general condition is accompanied by te, which while untranslatable often marks a general statement.

div.p: e)c o)xe/wn, ‘from his chariot.’ Homer may use a plural form with reference to the different parts of which an object is composed. Cf. A 14, 45.
The use of chariots in Homer is limited to a comparatively few conspicuous warriors; the great majority of the fighting men go afoot. Sec Introduction. 27.
fi/lon h)=tor, ‘in his heart,’ accusative of specification.

a)pe/sth, gnomic aorist like e)xa/rh (l. 23); so too e)/llabe (l. 34), a)nexw/rhsen (l. 35), ei(=le (l. 35).—The simile is imitated by Vergil (Aen. II 379-382):
Improvisum aspris veluti qui sentibus anguem
pressit humi nitens, trepidusque repente refugit
attollentem iras et caerula colla tumentem:
haud secus Androgeus visu tremefactus abibat.

‘Like a man treading among prickly briers, who unwittingly sets foot upon a snake, and quivering recoils from it with a start as it rears its angry crest and swells its dark-hued neck: even so did Androgeus trembling at the sight start to retreat.’
u(/po, ‘beneath,’ adverb.
e)/llabe, spelling, § 39.
pareia/s, with min, syntax, § 180.
*du/spari, ‘evil Paris,’ in striking contrast with the following ei)=dos a)/riste. A similar antithesis is noticed in Tennyson's Oenone: “Beautiful Paris, evil-hearted Paris.”
ai)/q' o)/feles ktl., construction, § 203.
te ... te, here equivalent to ‘or’; cf. B 303, 346.
e)/menai § 137.6), as subject supply se.
u(po/yion may be translated as a substantive, ‘object of others' [a)/llwn] suspicion.’
fa/ntes, ‘thinking.’—As subject of e)/mmenai supply se.
a)risth=a pro/mon = a)/riston pro/maxon. For Paris as pro/maxos cf. l. 16. [Some editors make a)risth=a, subject of e)/mmenai, and pro/mon a predicate noun after it.]
ou)/neka kalo\n ei)=dos e)/p' (i), ‘because you have a fair form.’
e)/p' (i), accent, §167.

The words a)ll' ou)k ktl. may be Hector's own, not the reported gibes of the Achaeans; but if a comma be read for the colon (after e)/p'), they may be regarded as a continuation of the Achaeans' thought.
bi/h is might for offense; a)lkh/, strength for defense.
h)= toio/sde e)w/n, ‘really, being such a one,’ did you do so and so? ‘Is this the man that sailed the deep’ etc., is the English idiom.
e)piplw/sas and mixqei/s (l. 48) are best translated as finite verbs parallel with a)nh=ges (l. 48), although of course denoting prior action.
nuo/n, ‘allied by marriage,’ here.
ph=ma, xa/rma (l. 51), and kathfei/hn (l. 51) are accusatives in apposition to the whole preceding sentence (cf. GG. 539): ‘(to be) a great distress’ etc.

ou)k a)\n dh\ mei/neias § 206) ktl., ‘you had better not wait for martial Menelaus,’ ironical advice. For construction cf. B 250. Most editors put an interrogation point at the end of the line, making a taunting question.
The protasis, ‘if you should wait,’ is understood. ‘Then you would know what sort of man he is whose blooming wife you have.’
ou)k a)\n ... xrai/smh|, construction, § 192.
*)afrodi/ths has initial syllable short, § 4.
h(/ te ko/mh to/ te ei)=dos, in apposition to dw=ra.
o(/t' e)n koni/h|si migei/hs, ‘vhen haply you roll in the dust,’ less vivid future protasis. The use of the plural koni/h|si suggests the particles that compose the whole; cf. o)xe/wn, l. 29.

56, 57. h)= te/ ken h)/dh ktl., the protasis—here wanting—may be supplied by ‘else’: ‘else surely you had already worn a chiton of stone.’ This is generally understood to mean ‘you would have been stoned to death’; but it may be that the allusion is to a mound of stones heaped up as a covering over the dead. Cf. II Samuel xviii, 17:
And they took Absalom, and cast him into a great pit in the wood, and laid a very great heap of stones upon him.
The Homeric line may easily carry both meanings; the same pile of stones that caused the death might serve as the dead man's barrow also (Studniczka).
e(/sso, e(/nnumi.
kat' ai)=san, ‘in just measure,’ ‘after my deserts.’
u(pe\r ai)=san, ‘unduly.’
Paris means, ‘with your words you have cut me to the quick.’
ei)=sin, ‘goes,’ ‘is driven.’
douro/s, ‘a timber.’
te/xnh|, ‘with art,’ ‘skilfully.’
As subject of o)fe/llei understand ‘the axe’; it increases the effect of the man's blow by its sharpness.
e)rwh/n, cf. note on B 179.
*trw=as kai\ pa/ntas *)axaiou/s, in apposition to a)/llous, ‘the others, the Trojans’ etc.
a)mf'(i/) with dative, like Attic peri/ with genitive.
e(lw\n ... oi)/kad' a)ge/sqw, ‘let him take and carry home with him.’
eu)= strengthens pa/nta, ‘each and every one.’ The treasures referred to were brought away from the palace of Menelaus when Helen eloped with Paris.
oi( d' a)/lloi, in apposition to ‘you,’ the subject of nai/oite (l. 74), and toi/, the subject of nee/sqwn (l. 74): ‘as for the rest, you’ etc.
filo/thta, in same construction as o(/rkia.
tamo/ntes, cf. B 124.
nai/oite, syntax, § 204.
toi\ de/, the Greeks.
*)/argos e)s i(ppo/boton ktl., in this formula there is probably a trace of the original meaning of Argos, the district in Thessaly. Cf. note on A 79.
e)/ballon, irregular, but quite Homeric, for ba/llontes, which would be expected in a construction parallel with titusko/menoi.
mu=qon, ‘challenge’; cf. note on A 388.
ke/letai, ‘he proposes.’
*trw=as and *)axaious are in apposition to a)/llous.
au)to/n, ‘himself.’
oi)/ous, ‘alone,’ in agreement with au)to/n and *mene/laon (l. 90).

a)kh\n e)ge/nonto, ‘were hushed’; a)kh/n, an adverb, was originally an accusative case. No wonder they were silent, as a scholiast suggests: Paris, the adulterer, now coolly proposes a duel with the injured husband; already having taken the wife, he asks for the opportunity of taking the husband's life also.
frone/w ktl., ‘my mind is [Monro, Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 238] that Argives and Trojans should now be parted.’
pe/posqe = pepo/nqate. Another reading, pe/pasqe, is often preferred. The forms arise from pepoq-te or pepaq-te; q becomes sigma before another lingual mute and t is aspirated.
*)aleca/ndrou ktl., ‘on account of the beginning that Alexander made.’
te/tuktai, ‘is prepared.’
teqnai/h, diakrinqei=te, syntax, § 204.
oi)/sete, form, § 153.
a)/rn'(e), dual. The ‘white ram’ is an offering to the sun; the ‘black ewe,’ to the earth, black being the appropriate color of victims offered to the chthonian deities.

The Greeks, being strangers (cei=noi) in the land, propose to sacrifice to Zeus— *zeu\s d' e)pitimh/twr i(keta/wn te cei/nwn te, cei/nios, o(\s cei/noisin a(/m) ai)doi/oisin o)phdei=. ‘For Zeus is the protector of suppliants and strangers, the strangers' god, who attends on strangers to whom respect is due’ (Od. 9.270, 271).
a)/cete, tense, § 153.
*pria/moio bi/hn, ‘the might of Priam’= ‘mighty Priam.’—The expression o(/rkia ta/mnh|
div.l: au)to/s evidently does not mean that Priam ‘by his own hand’ may perform the sacrifice, for Agamemnon does this (l. 273).

div.p: pai=des ... a)/pistoi, Paris is particularly meant by this general charge.
108-110. General truths.
oi(=s may be masculine or neuter: ‘among what men’ or ‘in what affairs an old man has a part.’ On o( see § 119.
met-e/h|si, § 136.6; on omission of a)/n or ke in the present general protasis, § 197.
pro/ssw kai\ o)pi/ssw, for meaning cf. A 343.
o(/pws ... ge/nhtai, syntax, § 199.
i(/ppous, horses harnessed to chariots.
e)pi\ sti/xas, ‘in rows,’ like 18.602.
e)k ... e)/ban, from the chariots; there was no cavalry in Homeric warfare. See Introduction. 27.
a)mfi/s, ‘between,’ separating Achaeans and Trojans.
a)/rn' = a)/rna.
oi)se/menai, tense, § 153.
th/n, relative.
ei)=xe, as his wife.
*laodi/khn, appositive to th/n (l. 123).
di/plaka, ‘double mantle,’ substantive (or adjective with xlai=nas understood) in apposition to i(sto/n (l. 125), ‘web.’ See Introduction, 12,
e)ne/passen, ‘was weaving therein.’
w)ke/a, spelling, § 29. 130. nu/mfa fi/lh, ‘dear child.’
oi(/, relative; the antecedent is oi(/ (l. 134), ‘those.’
e(/atai, form. § § 29; 142, 4, b. The meaning is ‘rest’ rather than ‘sit,’ for they are standing, as is shown by the next line.
tw=| nikh/santi (syntax, § 176), to be translated as if tou= nikh\santos.

ke marks the participle as conditional; the only other instance, in Homer, of this use of ke is in l. 255; it is very likely suggested by the form of l. 71, o(ppo/teros de/ ke nikh/sh|, where ke is of course regular with the subjunctive.
keklh/sh|, ‘you shall be called,’ is nearly equivalent to ‘you shall be.’
a)ndro/s, mentioned in ll. 52, 53.
a)/steos, Sparta.
tokh/wn, Leda and her husband Tyndareus; but Helen's father was Zeus (l. 199).
o)qo/nh|sin, here used as a veil. Cf. note on 18.595.

oi(\ d' a)mfi\ *pri/amon ktl. The names are to be translated as nominatives; cf. Xen. Anab. III, 5, 1: oi( d' a)mfi\ *tissafe/rnhn kai\ *)ariai=on a)potrauo/menoi a)/llhn o(do\n w)/|xonto, oi( d' a)mfi\ *xeiri/sofon kataba/ntes e)stratopedeu/onto ktl. ‘Tissaphernes and Ariaeus and those that were with them’ ... ‘Chirisophus and his followers.’
*ou)kale/gwn te kai\ *)anth/nwr, a free use of nominatives where accusatives, in the same construction as *pri/amon, etc., might be expected.
e)pi\ *skaih=|si pu/lh|sin, cf. note on Z 373.

dendre/w|, scansion, § 43; like xruse/w|, A 15. The note of the cicada is described as ligurh/n, ‘shrill,’ ‘clear,’ in the familiar Anacreontic (32, l. 14), and perhaps the difficult leirio/essan is intended to convey a similar meaning here; it is commonly translated ‘delicate.’

i(ei=sin, Attic i(a=sin (i(/hmi), ‘send forth’: from i(e/-nsin § 133). In connection with this curious association of the aged councilors with cicadas, the story of Tithonus (note on B 447) may be recalled; but of course the poet here limits the likeness to the voice alone.
ou) ne/mesis = ou) nemeshto/n, ‘it is no cause for blame.’
pa/sxein with polu\n xro/non has the force of a perfect in English. Cf. note on A 553.
ph=ma, in apposition to ‘she,’ i. e. Helen, the subject of li/poito. The verb is used in passive sense § 185).
pa/roiq' (e), with e)mei=o, ‘beside me.’
phou/s, connections by marriage.
moi, ‘in my sight,’ a true dative § 176).
w(s = i(/na, ‘in order that.’
o(/s tis o(/d' e)sti\n *)axaio\s a)nh/r, ‘who this Achaean man is,’ repeats in the form of an indirect question the object of e)conomh/nh|s (l. 166), to/nd' a)/ndra pelw/rion.

kefalh=|, ‘in stature,’ dative of respect, a subdivision of the instrumental use § 178); cf. kefalh=| (l. 193), w)/moisin (l. 194), and also the accusatives of specification, a closely related construction, kefalh/n and w)/mous, l. 227.
e)/asin, cf. B 125.
Helen's dutiful reply to Priam's kindly address of l. 162: ‘rev erend in my sight are you, dear father, and awful.’
e(kure/, ‘father-inlaw,’ once began with sv, the force of which consonants still survives in this line.
For dveino/s see § 62.
w(s o)/felen ... a(dei=n § 203), ‘oh that death had been my choice —evil death!’—a(dei=n, a(nda/nw.
gnwtou/s, with special reference to her brothers, Castor and Polydeuces (l. 237).
pai=da, cf. Od. 4.12-14:
*(ele/nh| de\ qeoi\ go/non ou)ke/t' e)/fainon, e)pei\ dh\ to\ prw=ton e)gei/nato pai=d' e)rateinh/n, *(ermio/nhn, h)\ ei)=dos e)/xe xruse/hs *)afrodi/ths.
‘To Helen the gods never again gave offspring, when once she had borne a lovely daughter, Hermione, who had the looks of golden Aphrodite.’— o(mhliki/hn, ‘companionship,’ i. e. ‘companions.’
ta/ g' ou)k e)ge/nonto, ‘this came not.’
to/, ‘therefore.’
a)mfo/teron, ‘both,’ an appositive to the following nouns, basileu/s ... ai)xmhth/s.

te after basileu/s is pleonastic. On the whole line cf. Xen. Memorabilia, III, 2, where Socrates is represented discussing the meaning of the words, in close connection with the other phrase commonly applied to Agamemnon, poime/na law=n (e. g. B 243):
‘Why does Homer praise Agamemnon in these words— a)mfo/teron, basileu/s t' a)gaqo\s kratero/s t' ai)xmhth/s?

Is it not because he would be a mighty warrior not if he alone should struggle nobly against the enemy, but if he should lead all his army to fight bravely; and a good king, not if he should direct his own life only with success, but if he should lead his subjects also to prosperity?’
kunw/pidos agrees with e)mou=, implied in e)mo/s. Cf. Z 490.
ei)/ pote e)/hn ge, ‘if such he ever was’; an expression of painful doubt whether the past was really true.

‘In very truth, many were the sons of the Achaeans under your command, it now appears [r(a],’ is a literal rendering; but the English idiom requires, ‘many are the sons of the Achaeans under your command, I now see.’ The Greek and the English take different points of view: the Greek suggests, ‘I was formerly somewhat mistaken in my view; it now appears [a)/ra] that all the time certain facts were true’ (and still continue so); the English lays emphasis on the present situation only, implying what the Greek states, just as the Greek implies what the English states. Compare similar examples, I 316, II 33, 60, etc.
e)le/xqhn, ‘was numbered’ (root leg), or possibly ‘was posted’ (root lex, cf. leca/sqwn, I 67).

*)amazo/nes: the tradition, recorded in the scholium, is that the Amazons, who lived by the Thermodon, overran Phrygia the Great, on a marauding expedition, in the time of the Phrygian leaders, Mygdon and Otreus. Priam went to the aid of the Phrygians, whose vast force greatly impressed him. It will be observed that the later story that the Amazons with their queen Penthesilea came to aid Priam against the Greeks scarcely tallies with this Homeric allusion in which Priam appears as the Amazons' enemy. In this myth of the Amazons' invasion of Asia Minor some scholars see a record of the incursions of northern tribes with their warlike women. Various peoples of the north had customs which agree remarkably with those ascribed to the Amazons; and it is not impossible that an extravagant version of their migrations survived in the Amazon myth. Another theory about the matter is set forth by A. H. Sayce in The Hittites, pp. 78-80, where it is maintained that the story of the Amazons has its origin in “the armed priestesses of the Hittite goddess.”
mei/wn me/n, supply e)sti/.
w)/moisin, ste/rnoisin, cf. l. 168 and note.
i)de/ = kai/.
i)de/sqai limits eu)ru/teros, ‘broader to look upon.’
kti/los has short ultima in spite of the following w(/s.

*)iqa/khs kranah=s, cf. Od. 4.605-608:
e)n d' *)iqa/kh| ou)/t' a)\r dro/moi eu\re/es ou)/te ti leimw/n:
ai)gi/botos, kai\ ma=llon e)ph/ratos i(ppobo/toio.
ou) ga/r tis nh/swn i(pph/latos ou)d' e)ulei/mwn,
ai(/ q' a(li\ kekli/atai. *)iqa/kh de/ te kai\ peri\ pase/wn.

‘In Ithaca there are neither broad runs nor any meadowland at all; it is grazed by goats and more lovely than a land where horses are pastured. For none of the isles that lie upon the sea is suited to horse driving or even rich in meadows; and of Ithaca this is true above all.’
th\n d' ... a)nti/on hu)/da = th\n de\ ... proshu/da.

h)/dh ga\r ... pot'(e), cf. A 260. Menelaus and Odysseus came to Troy on an embassy before hostilities actually began; the incident is referred to elsewhere also (11.138-141). Their purpose was to demand Helen. At that time Antenor, son of Hicetaon, entertained them and frustrated a treacherous plot against their lives. After the capture of Troy, as the scholiast continues, Agamemnon gave orders to spare the home of Antenor, marking it by a suspended leopard skin.
a)ggeli/hs, genitive of a)ggeli/h, with e(/nek)(a), ‘on a message about you.’
seu= is objective genitive with a)ggeli/hs. For the order cf. l. 100: *)aleca/ndrou e(/nek' a)rxh=s. [Some understand a)ggeli/hs as nominative=a)/ggelos, and take seu= with e(/nek)(a).]
sta/ntwn, partitive genitive.
u(pei/rexen, cf. B 426.
w)/mous, accusative of specification.

a)/mfw d' e(zome/nw, in apposition to the following nominatives, of which the first only, *)odusseu/s, is expressed; the second, *mene/laos, is implied. It is as if the poet had continued, *mene/laos d' h(=tton geraro/s.
h)=, ‘although,’ ‘yet.’
ge/nei, in sense of geneh=|, ‘in birth,’ ‘in years.’
u(pai\ ... i)/deske § 154.1), ‘kept looking down.’
kata\ xqono/s, ‘down on the ground,’ with o)/mmata ph/cas. In this construction the genitive probably illustrates the local use (cf. § 171, § 173).
skh=ptron, why did he hold a scepter? Cf. A 234.
fai/hs ken § 207), ‘you [indefinite subject] would have thought.’

za/koton ... tin'(a), ‘a very surly fellow,’ because he kept his eyes on the ground; a)/frona ... au)/tws, ‘a mere [or ‘perfect’] dolt,’ because he seemed not to know enough to gesticulate with the staff.
e)ri/sseie, force in English, § 207; cf. fai/hs ken above (l. 220).
‘Then we were not so much amazed at seeing Odysseus's looks’ as we were at his words (scholium). His oratory was an agreeable surprise.
qeo\s w)/s, on the scansion, § 37.
ken ... gnoi/hn, potential optative; in this instance the present indicative would better conform to the English idiom.
t' is for toi, § 40.4; or possibly te (cf. A 521).
i)de/ein, form, § 137.4.
tw/ moi ktl., ‘whom the same mother bore that bore me.’
moi mi/a, ‘one with me,’ is short for ‘the same as my mother.’ mi/a here = h( au)th/, and the dative is either a true dative or possibly “sociative.”
The idea is, either they did not come at all, or although they came, they do not wish to take part in the battle.

243, 244. The poet of these lines does not recognize the story, if he knew it, of the alternate immortality of the Dioscuri. It is mentioned, however, in the Odyssey (Od. 11.302-304). The lyric poet Pindar relates (Nemean X, 49-90) the story of the slaying of Castor, who was mortal; and he tells how immortal Polydeuces, with the consent of Zeus, shared his immortality with his brother:
metameibo/menoi d' e)nalla\c a(me/ran ta\n me\n para\ patri\ fi/lw|
*di\ ne/montai, ta\n d' u(po\ keu/qesi gai/as e)n gua/lois *qera/pnas,
po/tmon a)mpipla/ntes o(moi=on.

‘And shifting their abode by turns, they spend one day in company with their father Zeus, and the next they pass under the hidden places of the earth, in the recesses of Therapne, fulfilling a like destiny.’—Nemean X, 55-57.
qew=n: with o(/rkis pista/ as in l. 269.
o(/rkia, offerings for cementing oaths, namely a)/rne du/w kai\ oi)=non (l. 246).
o)/rseo, form, § 153.
ta/mhte, note the change to plural subject, ‘you all.’
a)mfi\ gunaiki/, Attic peri\ gunaiko/s. Cf. peri\ sei=o, l. 137.
tw=| de/ ke nikh/santi, cf. l. 138.
e(/poito, syntax, § 204.
nai/oimen, syntax, § 204.
ne/ontai, with future meaning.
a)\n ... e)/bh, ‘mounted’ the chariot.
di/fron, accusative of limit of motion.
*skaiw=n, for *skaia/wn. Supply pula/wn (pulw=n).
e)/xon, ‘guided.’
e)c i(/ppwn, ‘from their chariots’; cf. notes on ll. 29, 113.
a)/n, supply w)/rnuto.
o(/rkia, cf. l. 245.
mi/sgon, ‘mingled’ the wine of the Greeks with that of the Trojans. Wine unmixed with water (B 341, spondai\ a)/krhtoi) was used in such ceremonies.
The knife (ma/xairan, l. 271), ‘which always hung by the great scabbard of his sword.’
a)/wrto (for which a)/orto has been proposed as the proper spelling) is pluperfect of a)ei/rw, and means, literally, ‘was suspended.’
ta/mne tri/xas, as a sign that the victim was consecrated for sacrifice.
a)ri/stois, with *trw/wn kai\ *)axaiw=n.
*)he/lios, case, § 169.
oi(/, ‘ye that,’ includes Hades and Persephone and in particular the Erinyes. Cf. T 258-260:
i)/stw nu=n *zeu\s prw=ta, qew=n u(/patos kai\ a)/ristos, *gh= te kai\ *)he/lios kai\ e)rinu/es, ai(/ q' u(po\ gai=an a)nqrw/pous ti/nuntai, o(/tis k) e)pi/orkon o)mo/ssh|.
*trw=as ... a)podou=nai (syntax, § 213)=Attic *trw=es a)podo/ntwn or a)podo/twsan.
timh/n, ‘recompense,’ ‘fine.’
a)potine/men, in same construction as a)podou=nai.
h(/ntin' e)/oiken, ‘whatever 'tis seemly’ (to pay).
h(\ ... pe/lhtai expresses purpose; ‘so that it shall be in remembrance [literally ‘be in motion’] among men to come also.’

ou)k instead of mh/ is found in this protasis because the negative modifies e)qe/lwsin alone, with which it forms one idea, ‘refuse’; the construction is Attic also. If the negative were unattached, and modified the whole clause, it would be mh/.
au)ta\r e)gw/, ‘I for my part.’
h(=os, cf. A 193.
a)po\ ... ta/me, tmesis.
a)po\ ... ei(/leto, tmesis.
depa/essin modifies a)fusso/menoi, not e)/kxeon (l. 296)
e)/kxeon, supply xama/dis (l. 300).
‘Whichever party may be first to commit wrong contrary to the oaths’—protasis of what sort of condition? GG. 651 (1).
sf'(i), ‘their,’ § 176.
r(e/oi, syntax, § 201.
au)tw=n agrees with a genitive implied in sf)(i) (l. 300). Preserve the Greek order in translation: ‘their own and their children's.’
a)/lloisi damei=en, ‘become subject to others.’
a)/lloisi, for prose u(p' a)/llwn, is properly a dative of interest § 176), but commonly called dative of agent.
e)n = ‘before.’

Why did Priam take away with him the two lambs that he had contributed to the sacrifice? A scholium says, ‘to bury them; for it was usual for citizens of the land to bury their oath-victims, and for strangers to cast theirs into the sea.’ (Cf. T 267 f.)

xw=ron ... dieme/treon, cf. l. 344, which means, ‘and they [the combatants] stood near each other in the measured space.’ It is suggested in the scholia that certain bounds were determined for the contestants, retreat beyond which was an acknowledgment of defeat. These limits may well have served also to keep the spectators from crowding in. How far the contestants were separated at the beginning of the struggle, the reader is not told.

‘They shook the lots,’ says the poet; then after repeating the people's prayer, which is made while the shaking takes place, he recurs to the thought more definitely (l. 324) and adds, ‘Hector shook’ the lots.
a)fei/h, construction, § 209.
‘Grant that he die and enter the house of Hades.’
do/s is to be understood before filo/thta ... gene/sqai. If this line stood by itself, apart from the preceding verse, it could be brought under § 213, as equivalent to filo/ths ... gene/sqw.

324, 325. The man whose lot jumped out of the helmet first was chosen —in this instance—to hurl the spear first. As it was an advantage under the present circumstances to have this first chance, Hector looked away, in shaking the helmet, to avoid any charge of unfair play.
kata\ sti/xas, ‘in rows.’

e)/keito (in meaning, passive of ti/qhmi), ‘were placed,’ conforms to its neuter plural subject teu/xea. Its connection with the former subject, i(/ppoi, is so loose that in translating i(/ppoi another predicate, e(/stasan, had better be supplied.
Paris came light-armed, to fight as a bowman (cf. ll. 17 f.). Now in preparing for the duel, he arms as for a hand-to-hand contest.
He puts on his brother's breastplate, for apparently he had not brought his own, as the duel was unexpected. He had one at home, however (Z 322).
h(/rmose, if intransitive (cf. P 210, T 385), has qw/rhc under stood as subject; if transitive (cf. Od. 5.162, 247), has ‘he’ (Paris) as subject and qw/rhka understood as object.
His sword and shield were suspended by straps passing over his shoulders, the sword strap probably over the right shoulder, the shield strap probably over the left. Cf. A 190.
o(/ oi( pala/mhfin a)rh/rei, ‘which fitted his hand.’
e(ka/terqen o(mi/lou = e)c e(kate/rou o(mi/lou. The Greek point of view is characteristically ‘from’ the object; we say, ‘in either throng,’ ‘each in his own army.’
deino\n derko/menoi, ‘glaring dreadfully.’
pro/sqe, ‘first,’ like pro/sqen, l. 317.
e)/rrhcen, the understood object is a)spi/da.
oi( ai)xmh/, ‘its point’; oi( (dative of interest, § 176) refers to xalko/s, ‘the bronze’ head of the spear.
w)/rnuto, ‘poised himself.’
a)/na, vocative of a)/nac.—do\s ti/sasqai o(/ ktl., ‘give me vengeance on him who’ etc.
tis ... kai\ o)yigo/nwn a)nqrw/pwn, ‘many a one of men to come also.’
e)rri/gh|si, form, § 136.6.
filo/thta para/sxh| (par-e/xw), ‘proffers hospitality.’
dia/, scansion, § 36.
a)nasxo/menos, ‘raising his arm’ to deal the blow.
au)tw=|, i. e. the fa/los, on which see Introduction, 33.
te kai/, for translation cf. B 303, 346, 3.40.
kako/thtos, genitive of cause, a common Attic construction; cf. Xen. Anab. VII, 4, 23, timwrh/sasqai au)tou\s th=s e)piqe/sews, ‘to punish them for the attack.’
a)/gh, a)/gnumi.
pala/mhfin, here ablatival genitive, § 155, § 1; 175.
ko/ruqos, syntax, § 172.
o)xeu/s, appositive to o(/s.—te/tato, tei/nw.
o)cu/, cognate accusative with no/hse, ‘had directed a quick glance.’

i(ma/nta boo/s (genitive of material) ktl., ‘strap made from the skir of an ox slain with might.’ This means a strong strap; for, as the scholiast explains, the leather made from diseased animals, that die natural deaths, is inferior.
ktame/noio, aorist middle with passive meaning, § 185.
keinh/ (note the accent) = Attic kenh/.
trufa/leia, see Introduction, 33.
e)/gxei+ xalkei/w|: the warrior regularly carried two spears; Menelaus's first spear only has been thrown (ll. 18, 367, 368).
qeo/s, feminine, as A 516, etc.
kale/ous'(a), tense, § 151.
i)/e = Attic h)/|ei (ei)=mi).
e(anou=, ‘robe’ § 172).
e)ti/nace, ‘shook’ her; supply min.
min, object of prose/eipen.
oi( § 176), i. e. Helen, has naietaou/sh| in agreement.
h)/skein has n movable, although the imperfect of a contract verb.
min refers to the wool spinner; the subject of file/esken is Helen.
fai/hs, with indefinite subject.
daimoni/h, ‘wonderful goddess!’
ph| ... poli/wn, § 173.
*frugi/hs and *mh|oni/hs limit poli/wn (l. 400).
u(postre/yeias, § 201, § 204.
*)/olumpon, accusative of limit of motion.
ei)s o(/ ke = Attic e(/ws a)/n.
poih/setai, § 144, II.

If I do go, Helen reasons, the Trojan women will reproach me for being the cause of renewed hostilities. According to the terms of the compact, I ought now to go to the victor, not to the vanquished Paris.— e)/xw, ‘I already have.’
sxetli/h, the first syllable is short, § 4.
mhti/somai § 144, II), in construction corresponding with meqei/w (l. 414) and a)pexqh/rw (l. 415).
su\ de/ ken ... o)/lhai, future statement in an independent sentence, § 192.
oi)=ton, cognate accusative.
katasxome/nh ktl., similar in meaning to l. 141, a)rgennh=|si kaluyame/nh o)qo/nh|sin.
qea/, appositive to *)afrodi/th (l. 424).
pa/lin kli/nasa, ‘averting.’
h)ni/pape occurred B 245.
w(s w)/feles ... o)le/sqai § 203), ‘ah! you ought to have perished there!’
a)ndri/, so-called dative of agent with passive damei/s (cf. a)/lloisi, l. 301); this construction is limited to what tenses in Attic Greek? GG. 524 b.
*menela/ou, genitive of comparison with fe/rteros (l. 431).
proka/lessai, where found? GG. 284. Where might a different form. prokale/ssai (note accent), be found? GG. 285. The advice in this line and the next is ironical.
a)lla/ s' e)gw/ ge ... ke/lomai, ‘no, I for my part urge you.’
damh/h|s, § 149 (a).
me ... qumo/n, § 180.
Paris is not candid enough to add that he himself escaped death by the timely intervention of Aphrodite only.
e)gw/, supply nikh/sw.
pa/ra, adverbial, as l. 135, A 611, B 279.
trapei/omen (te/rpw), second aorist passive subjunctive, § 149 (a).
a)mfeka/luyen, ‘encompassed,’ or ‘enmeshed’ like a net (scholium). Many modern commentators prefer ‘enwrapt’ like a cloud.
se, object of a(rpa/cas (l. 444).

trhtoi=si, ‘perforated’ with holes, applied to bedsteads. There are various explanations: one, that through these holes passed the leather thongs (i(ma/ntes) which formed a network to support the bed-clothes; another, that the holes were bored in the process of fitting together the parts of the frame.
o(/milon, of Trojans.
ei) ... e)saqrh/seien, § 198.1.
filo/thti, § 178.

ei)/ tis i)/doito is probably to be translated as the protasis of a past contrary to fact condition; the construction is extraordinary, but comparison may be made with I 515-517, X 20. For ei) tis i)/doito, ei) ei)/donto has been proposed, which conforms to the regular Attic construction, found in Homer also (e. g. l. 374). The line reads in the MSS.:
ou) me\n ga\r filo/thti/ g' e)keu/qanon, ei)/ tis i)/doito.

fai/net' (ai) ... *menela/ou, ‘seems to belong to Menelaus.’ Menelaus has not fulfilled the terms prescribed by Agamemnon (l. 284), for he has not slain Paris; but he has satisfied Hector's statement of the terms (l. 92), for Paris by deserting the lists has left him the victory. Compare note on l. 315. Menelaus did not notice Aphrodite's interference, and is of course, like the others, puzzled by Paris's disappearance.
a)potine/men, § 213. Cf. notes on ll. 286, 287.
oi(\ me/n, Diomedes and his charioteer, Sthenelus.
tw\ de/, Aeneas and Pandarus. The combination of dual subject, dual participle, and plural verb is not inconsistent with epic diction.
to/n, Diomedes, as shown by *tude/os ui(e/ (l. 277).

o)isto/s, in apposition to be/los. The reference is to ll. 95-106 of this Book, where it is told how Pandarus shot an arrow at Diomedes, slightly wounding his shoulder:
to\n d' ou) be/los w)ku\ da/massen (l. 106).
nu=n au)=t'(e), ‘once more now.’
ptame/nh, pe/tomai.
ai)xmh/ is the ‘point’ of the spear.
tw=| d' e)/pi, ‘and over him.’
e)/pi is thus accented by Cauer § 166), in spite of the fact that d'(e/) intervenes.
makro/n, cognate accusative.
be/blhai, § 142.2, a.
kenew=na, accusative of specification.— diampere/s, adverb, really neuter of diamperh/s, ‘quite through’ (dia/ + a)n(a/) + root per of pei/rw, ‘pierce’).
ou) tarbh/sas, ‘undismayed’; the time is coincident with that of prose/fh § 186).
h)/mbrotes = Attic h(/martes.
me/n, ‘surely,’ = Attic mh/n.
pri\n ... pri\n h)/ = Attic pro/sqen ... pri/n (without h)/), Latin priusquam.
e(/teron, ‘one of you twain.’
ai(/matos, ‘with blood,’ partitive genitive.
talau/rinon § 63.2), ‘enduring the oxhide shield,’ i. e. ‘stout in battle.’
r(i=na (nominative r(i/s), § 179.—The subject of e)pe/rhsen is be/los understood.
a)po/, with ta/me, § 163: ‘the unyielding bronze cut his tongue off at the root.’

e)cesu/qh: this aorist (cf. e)k-seu/w) does not occur elsewhere in Homer; it has the support of the Alexandrian scholar Zenodotus; Aristarchus, on the other hand, favored e)celu/qh, the reading of some MSS. The latter form, difficult in itself, has been ingeniously interpreted as an ancient mistake for e)c-e/luqe or (with n movable) e)c-e/luqen, the unaugmented form of e)c-h/luqen, Attic e)c-h=lqen, which gives excellent sense.
nei/aton, ‘lowest part of.’
pamfana/onta, see note on B 458.
yuxh/ te me/nos te, ‘both breath of life and strength.’

As Diomedes, when he hurled his javelin, was afoot, and Pandarus was in his chariot, it has long been discussed how the spear could have inflicted a vertical wound from above. If one is not satisfied with the explanation that Athene guided the weapon (l. 290), he may suppose that Pandarus was bending forward to dodge the missile when caught by the spear-point (scholium).
a)po/rouse, understand ‘from his chariot.’
a)mfi\ ... bai=ne, compare the metaphorical use of the same words in A 37.—For accent of w(/s, § 123.5.
a)lki/, metaplastic dative from nominative a)lkh/.
oi(, dative of advantage.
tou= refers to the slain Pandarus; in construction like patro/s, A 534.

smerdale/a, note long ultima; § § 38; 61, 5. Vergil evidently had in mind this passage, with M 445 ff. and 21.403 ff., when he wrote Aen. XII, 896-901 (Turnus is the subject):
Nec plura effatus saxum circumspicit ingens,
saxum antiquum ingens, campo quod forte iacebat,
limes agro positus, litem ut discerneret arvis.
Vix illud lecti his sex cervice subirent,
qualia nunc hominum producit corpora tellus:
ille manu raptum trepida torquebat in hostem, etc.

Dryden's translation is:
Then, as he roll'd his troubled eyes around,
An antique stone he saw; the common bound
Of neighbouring fields, and barrier of the ground:
So vast, that tweleve strong men of modern days
Th' enormous weight from earth could hardly raise.
He heav'd it at a lift; and, poised on high.
Ran, staggering on, against his enemy.
r(e/a, short form of r(ei=a § 29), Attic r(a|di/ws.

tw=|, ‘with this’; like the Attic idiom, ba/llein li/qois, ‘to throw stones.’ ‘This he threw at Aeneas's hip, where the thigh plays in the hipjoint—“the cup” men call it.’ For te of l. 305 see § 123.3.
te marks the general statement.
pro\s d' (e/), ‘and besides.’
w)=se d' a)/po = Attic a)pw=se (a)p-wqe/w) de/.
r(ino/n, ‘skin.’ Distinguish from r(i=na (l. 291).
e)/sth, ‘he held himself upright,’ although he fell on his knee; he did not faint.
gai/hs, ‘on the earth,’ genitive of place.
ken ... a)po/loito = Attic a)pw/leto a)/n. see § 207.
‘And she spread the fold of her shining white robe in front, for his protection.’
oi( is dative of advantage.
ui(o\s *kapanh=os, Sthenelus.
ta/wn, ‘those’ commands, § 115.
h)ru/kake, § 129.
mw/nuxas, ‘solid-footed,’ in contradistinction to the cloven hoofs of oxen, etc.
e)c a)/ntugos h(ni/a tei/nas, ‘tying the reins to the chariot-rim.’
*ai)nei/ao limits i(/ppous.
o(mhliki/hs, syntax, § 175; cf. A 287. ‘Companionship’ here as in 3.175 means ‘companions.’
oi( refers to Sthenelus.
a)/rtia h)/|dei, ‘knew things that suited’ him, ‘was congenial’ to him. Compare 16.73, h)/pia ei)dei/h, ‘have a gentle heart’; Od. 9.189, a)qemi/stia h)/|dei, ‘had a lawless heart.’
w(=n i(/ppwn e)piba/s, ‘mounting his chariot.’
h(ni/a sigalo/enta, ‘gleaming reins’; probably the reins were decorated with little pieces of ivory, sewed on: such reins are mentioned, E 583: h(ni/a leu/k' e)le/fanti, ‘reins white with ivory.’
*tudei+/dhn is to be taken with meta/ of me/qepe, while i(/ppous is direct object of the verb.
nhle/i, § 161.
a)ndrw=n, with po/lemon.

*)enuw/, a murderous, city-destroying goddess of war, usually accompanying Ares. Later poets say that she was the mother (or daughter or nurse) of Ares; and from this source came his name *)enua/lios. Cf. Xen. Anab. I, 8, 18.
r('(a), perhaps a substitute for a lost v)(e), that is, e(, ‘her.’— o)pa/zwn = diw/kwn.
a)/krhn xei=ra, ‘the extremity of the hand’; the part near the wrist is meant, as is shown by l. 339.—On ou)/tase see note, O 745.
a)blhxrh/n: if possible, preserve the Homeric order, ‘her hand—her soft hand.’
prumno/n is a substantive.
do/ru xroo\s (partitive genitive) a)nteto/rhsen (l. 337) ... prumno\n u(/per qe/naros, ‘the spear bored through the skin above the base of the palm,’ i. e. through the “heel” of the hand.
For the long ultima of me/ga see note on l. 302.—The final vowel of a)po/ has the ictus before e(/o, which originally began with sv § 61.6).
ka/bbalen (=kate/balen), ‘let fall,’ § 47.
pole/mou, genitive of separation.
h)\ ou)x, to be read with synizesis, § 43.
x) = ke.
e(te/rwqi, literally ‘on the other side’; here ‘elsewhere’ or ‘from a distance.’
gignw/skwn, with concessive force.
u(pei/rexe, for u(pe/r-sexe. Cf. B 426.
deina\ d' o(moklh/sas, ‘breaking forth with a grim cry.’ For the force of the aorist cf. note on A 85.
The sense is, the race of gods is not like to that of men: it is superior.
te follows e)rxome/nwn rather than xamai/, because xamai\ e)rxome/nwn is regarded as a single expression: “men creeping here below” (Chapman).
a)leua/menos, for the tense, § 186.
*perga/mw|, the citadel of Troy.
ei)n i(erh=|, § 35, end. The temple here mentioned seems to have been a family seat of Apollo, his mother, and his sister.

Hector, fulfilling the bidding of his brother Helenus, returns to the city to urge a public supplication of Athene and the other gods. The ‘oak’ seems to have been a conspicuous landmark on the plain, outside the Scaean gate; elsewhere (e. g. E 693) it is mentioned as sacred to Zeus.
ei)ro/menai pai=das ktl., ‘asking about their sons’ etc.
e)/tas, ‘relatives,’ more distant.
cesth=|s ai)qou/sh|si, porticoes built about the courtyard with blocks of smoothly hewn stone.
dedmhme/noi, de/mw.
‘And for his daughters, on the opposite side, facing these [chambers of his sons] within the courtyard, were twelve chambers.’
koura/wn limits qa/lamoi (l. 248).
e)/nqa indicates the courtyard with its chambers, to which Hecabe was coming from the me/garon.

*laodi/khn e)sa/gousa probably means ‘while she was leading [or ‘accompanying’] Laodice to her apartment’; the old interpretation, ‘while proceeding to Laodice's apartment,’ suits the sense well enough; the objection to it is that it makes e)sa/gousa intransitive. The verse offers an explanation of Hecabe's presence in the courtyard.
Arrange for translation: oi(= (dative of interest) e)ne/fu xeiri/, ‘she grasped [literally ‘grew to’] his hand.’
marname/nous, agreeing with *trw=as or some equivalent word understood, object of tei/rousi (l. 255).
e)nqa/de, to be translated with e)lqo/nta (l. 257).—a)nh=ken, a)n-i/hmi.
e)c a)/krhs po/lios, with xei=ras a)nasxei=n. The temples of the gods were in the citadel; cf. E 446, Z 297.—On the form po/lios, § 103.
o)/fra, ‘until.’
e)nei/kw, fe/rw.
The sentence beginning e)/peita de/ is independent of the preceding construction.
kau)to/s § 44), ‘yourself too.’
o)nh/seai is future indicative.
de/, ‘for.’
me/nos me/ga oi)=nos a)e/cei, ‘wine makes the strength wax mighty.’
e)/th|sin, ‘compatriots,’ ‘fellows.’
a)/eire, ‘offer.’
ou)de/ ph| e)/sti, ‘for it is not at all possible,’ i. e. ‘permissible.’
pepalagme/non, agreeing with tina/ (‘anybody’) understood.

On the sentiment cf. Verg. Aen. II, 717-720:
Tu, genitor, cape sacra manu patriosque Penates;
me, bello e tanto digressum et caede recenti,
attrectare nefas, donec me flumine vivo abluero.

‘Do you, father, take in your hand the sacred emblems and the household Penates; for me, freshly come out of the great battle and carnage, it is impious to handle them until I shall have washed in running water.’
e)ni/, with lengthened ultima, § 38.
u(posxe/sqai, infinitive for imperative.
h)/nis, ‘yearlings,’ § 81.
ai)/ k' e)leh/sh|, § 198.
fo/boio, almost always ‘flight’ in Homer, not ‘fear.’ So fobe/omai means ‘flee,’ not as in later Greek, ‘fear.’
‘In the hope that he will listen to me as I speak.’ On the time denoted by ei)po/ntos, § 186.
xa/noi, optative of wish, introduced by w(/s ke. ke is very unusual with the optative of wish; some editors therefore change it to de/, but without MS. authority.
me/ga, with ph=ma: ‘the Olympian raised him to be a great burden.’
katelqo/nt'(a), like ei)po/ntos (l. 281), refers to a single act, and denotes time coincident with that of i)/doimi.
*)/aidos ei)/sw = do/mon *)/aidos ei)/sw (3.322).

‘I should think I had quite forgotten joyless woe in my heart,’ i. e. ‘I should think my heart quite free from joyless woe.’ fre/na is to be regarded as accusative of specification. An easier reading is that of Zenodotus, which has fi/lon h)=tor instead of fre/n' a)te/rpou.
poti/ has ultima long, § 38.
katebh/seto, tense, § 153.
oi(, dative of possession.
ta/s, the antecedent is gunaikw=n (l. 289).
e)piplw/s, second aorist participle of which indicative forms -e/plws, -e/plw exist; the Attic is e)pipleu/sas (first aorist).
eu)re/a, Attic eu)ru/n.
th\n o(do/n, accusative with h)/gage (l. 291); cf. A 496. The allusion to Sidon indicates that the poet was familiar with the story that Paris brought Helen to Troy by a roundabout way.

Herodotus (II, 113-116), who says he heard the story from Egyptian priests, narrates that Paris with Helen touched at Egypt too, to which land they were driven by adverse winds. Herodotus tells at length of their experience in Egypt: King Proteus on learning the story of Paris's wickedness decided to keep Helen and the treasures stolen from Sparta until Menelaus should call for them; he ordered Paris and his other companions to leave Egypt within three days. While Homer did not find this story suited to his purposes, he yet knew it, Herodotus thinks, as the reference to Sidon shows.

Herodotus adds (ib. 117) that according to another account (the Cypria) Alexander and Helen came from Sparta to Troy in three days (“on the third day”), with a fair wind and smooth sea. As this is evidently contradictory to the allusion in ll. 290-292, he argues that Homer could not have written the Cypria.
poiki/lmasin, ‘gay-colored patterns.’
a)/llwn, ablatival genitive after the comparative idea involved in nei/atos: ‘undermost of all.’ Compare the similar construction of a)/llwn, A 505.
w)/ice, oi)/gnumi.
The final syllables of both *kisshi/s and a)/loxos, although naturally short, receive the ictus. § 32, § 33.
e)/qhkan = e)poi/hsan, as often in Homer.

a)=con, a)/gnumi. Cf. Verg. Aen. XI, 484 f.:
frange manu telum Phrygii praedonis, et ipsum
pronum sterne solo, portisque effunde sub altis.
The Latin matrons pray to Athene for defense against Aeneas:
‘Break with thy arm the spear of the Phrygian pirate, lay him headlong on the ground, and under the high gates overwhelm him.’
a)ne/neue, ‘nodded upward,’ in token of dissent, as the Greeks do to-day.
Unlike the other children of Priam, Paris and Hector (ll. 305, 370) had houses of their own.

qa/lamon kai\ dw=ma kai\ au)lh/n indicate the complete Homeric house: (1) the interior and sleeping room, in particular the women's apartment; (2) the general reception hall (me/garon); (3) the courtyard. For description in detail and plan see Jebb's Homer: An Introduction to the Iliad and the Odyssey (Boston, 1894), pp. 57-62.
pa/roiqe douro/s, ‘at the end of the spear.’
xru/seos, on quantity of antepenult, § 30.
po/rkhs, ‘ring,’ ‘ferrule.’ The metal head of the spear was set in the wooden shaft; then a ferrule was bound around the juncture.
e(/ponta, ‘busy.’
a)spi/da kai\ qw/rhka, in apposition to teu/xe)(a), l. 321.
daimo/ni'(e), ‘brother, you are acting strangely’; cf. A 561.—ou) me\n kala\ ktl., ‘you have not done right to cherish this wrath.’ kala/ is an adverb.

e)/nqeo, second aorist indicative of e)n-ti/qemai. The ‘wrath’ is probably that which Hector supposes Paris to feel against his fellow Trojans; they hated him (3.454) and were quite indifferent to his fate in the duel with Menelaus (3.320-323); and Paris doubtless returned their feelings. Of course, one may understand that the Trojans' wrath toward Paris is meant, an interpretation old as the scholia.
327, 328. The underlying thought, which Hector does not express in words, is: “Yet you sit here, careless and indifferent.”
su\ d' a)\n maxe/saio ktl., ‘and you would quarrel with any other man, too, whomsoever you should see forbear from hateful war.’
a)/na, adverb meaning ‘up!’
puro/s, see note on B 415.
dhi/oio, scansion, § 28.
qe/rhtai, ‘be burned.’
neme/ssi, remarkable form from ne/mesis, equivalent to Attic )/eme/sei.
a)/xei+ protrape/sqai, ‘to give way to anguish.’
pareipou=s'(a) has its first syllable long because originally sounded parveipou=sa § 61.16). But the digamma is neglected, A 555.
ni/kh d' e)pamei/betai a)/ndras, ‘victory comes to men by turns.’ For a similar sentiment of Paris see 3.439 f.
du/w, aorist subjunctive, § 193.
kuno/s, appositive to e)mei=o. For signification cf. A 225, 3.180.— kakomhxa/noo, § 74.
kruoe/sshs, causing chilly fear, ‘horrid.’

w(/s m'(e) o)/fel'(e), a past impossible wish, § 203. The subject of o)/fele (= Attic w)/fele) is qu/ella (l. 346). m) (l. 345) is object of profe/rousa (l. 346). oi)/xesqai (l. 346) although present in form is past in meaning. Translate: ‘would that a dreadful blast of wind had borne me onward’ (literally ‘had gone bearing me’). Compare Helen's previous wish, not unlike this, 3.173, and Tennyson's reminiscence of the lines:
I would the white cold heavy-plunging foam,
Whirl'd by the wind, had roll'd me deep below,
Then when I left my home. A Dream of Fair Women.

a)po/erse: elision of o was prevented by the consonant sound that originally intervened between o and e; a digamma is inferred. Compare e)pieime/ne, A 149.—In construction, e)/nqa ... a)po/erse is the protasis of a past contrary to fact condition: ‘where the billow would have swept me away.’ The conditional force may be clearly seen if the idea be phrased thus: ‘I wish a whirlwind had carried me seaward, if the billows could have swept me away there before these deeds were done.’
A present impossible wish, § 203; GG. 470 b.

‘Who were sensitive to the censure and repeated reproaches of men.’ The clause o(\s h)/|dei is equivalent, in construction, to the protasis of a present contrary to fact condition. Compare e)/nqa ... a)po/erse (l. 348).— Why is o(/s long? § 61.23.
e)paurh/sesqai, ‘will reap the fruits’; cf. A 410. Supply ‘of his witlessness’ after the infinitive.
se\ ... fre/nas, § 180.
e)pi\ ... qh=ke, tmesis.
e)pe/ssutai, o)/fr'(a) ktl., a solitary instance of this construction; usually e)pe/ssutai is followed by the infinitive.
oi)kh=as, the ultima receives the ictus § 32). The word is best understood as = oi)ke/tas.
ga/r is a long syllable before voi=da § 61.23); h)/ is short § 25.1).
dama/ousin, § 151.
e)u\ naieta/ontas, ‘well-situated’ or ‘comfortable.’
pu/rgw|, the great tower over the Scaean gate, mentioned 3.153.
e)/ndon, within the me/gaoon.
ou)do/n, the threshold of the qa/lamos, in the rear of the me/garon. Cf. l. 316.
ei) d' a)/ge. See note on A 302.
For the omission of the noun with the genitives galo/wn, etc., cf. *)/ai+dos ei)/sw, l. 284.
e)peigome/nh, ‘with haste.’
mainome/nh| e)ikui=a, ‘like one distraught.’

th
 au)th
 o(do/n (for construction cf. A 496), ‘the same road’ as the one by which he had come to the palace. The article as used here, while possibly demonstrative, resembles the Attic; elsewhere (Od. 8.107, Od. 10.263, Od. 16.138) au)th
 o(do/n occurs, without the article, meaning ‘the same road.’
th=|, relative adverb.
Andromache seems to have left the tower (cf. l. 386 ff.) whence she had looked in vain over the field of battle for her husband; and as she turns homeward she meets him.
polu/dwros, ‘much giving.’ ‘bounteous’ (cf. h)pio/dwros, l. 251), which easily passes into ‘richly dowered.’ Cf. note on X 472.
*)heti/wn, nominative for genitive, attracted to the case of its following relative o(/s—a singular construction.
*(/ektori, equivalent to u(po\ *(/ektoros. See note on 3.301, a)/lloisi.
nh/pion au)/tws, ‘a mere infant.’

402, 403. Hector named his boy after the Trojan river *ska/mandros. but the people, out of gratitude to their great defender, called his child *)astua/nac, ‘city-lord,’ a name appropriate to the father. The name *(/ektwr itself may be from e)/xw and mean ‘upholder,’ ‘defender.’ In allusion to this signification Andromache says in her lamentation (24.730): e)/xes d' a)lo/xous kedna\s kai\ nh/pia te/kna, ‘thou didst defend honored wives and young children.’—On the quantity of the syllable before *skama/ndrion see note on B 465.
daimo/nie, ‘my husband, I like not your daring.’ Cf. l. 326 and A 561.
to\ so\n me/nos, ‘this might of yours’; cf. A 207.
qalpwrh/, ‘comfort’ (from qa/lpw, ‘warm’); on formation see § 156.2.—e)pi/-sph|s, e)f-e/pw.

This line and one below (429) suggested to Sophocles the words which he put into the mouth of Tecmessa (as noted in the scholium ad locum) when she addressed Ajax:
e)moi\ ga\r ou)ke/t' e)/stin ei)s o(/ ti ble/pw
plh\n sou=: su\ ga/r moi patri/d' h)/|stwsas dori/,
kai\ mhte/r' a)/llh moi=ra to\n fu/santa/ te
kaqei=len *(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras.
ti)s dh=t' e)moi\ ge/noit' a)\n a)nti\ sou= patri/s;
ti/s plou=tos; e)n soi\ pa=s' e)/gwge sw/|zomai. Ajax, 514-519. “I have nothing left whereunto I can look, save thee. Thou didst ravage my country with the spear, and another doom hath laid low my mother and my sire, that they should dwell with Hades in their death. What home, then, could I find, if I lost thee? What wealth? On thee hangs all my welfare.”—Translation of Sir Richard Jebb.
kate/khe, katakai/w.
e)/pi, adverb, ‘thereon.’
e)/xeen (xe/w), ‘heaped up.’
oi(/, relative; the antecedent is the demonstrative oi(/ of the following line.
*)/aidos ei)/sw, cf. l. 284.
kate/pefne, tense, § 128.
e)/p'(i), ‘with,’ i. e. ‘in charge of,’ ‘while tending.’
th/n repeats the object mhte/ra (l. 425).
Apollo is said to slay men, and Artemis women, that die by sudden —but not violent—death.
qalero/s, ‘blooming.’ ‘stalwart.’
mh\ ... qh/h|s § 149 (2)], ‘lest you make.’
Lines 433-439 are a weak ending of the splendid âppeal. Military directions sound strange indeed on the lips of Andromache.

The statements that one portion of the wall is scalable and that perhaps the Greeks have been directed to this part by an oracle (l. 438) allude to a story not found in Homer, but repeated in Pindar's eighth Olympian ode, ll. 40-57. Its substance is this: Apollo and Poseidon, when about to build a rampart around Troy, called a mortal, Aeacus, to their aid. After the wall was built, three dragons tried to scale it; two died in the attempt, but one succeeded, in the part where the hands of Aeacus had wrought. Then Apollo interpreted the portent to mean that Troy was destined to be taken at the place where the mortal had labored.
tri\s ... e)peirh/sanq' (i. e. e)peirh/santo): there is no other allusion in Homer to these three attacks; and in fact the battle at present is not near the city wall.
e)/nispe, i. e. e)/ni-spe, second aorist from e)nne/pw (e)n-se/pw). e)u\ ei)dw/s, with genitive, § 174 (4).
ou)de/ me qumo\s a)/nwgen, supply mi/mnein e)pi\ pu/rgw| (cf. l. 431).
a)rnu/menos, ‘seeking to guard.’
au)tou= agrees with an e)mou= implied in e)mo\n (kle/os).

447-449. This terrible foreboding of Hector is an indication of his present state of mind and possibly has no further significance. At any rate he seems to forget it later when he prays for his boy (ll. 476-481).
e)ummeli/w, § 69.

‘But no sorrow for Trojans hereafter wounds my heart so deeply nor for Hecabe herself nor for lord Priam nor for my brothers, who though many and brave will fall in the dust beneath their foes, as grief for you’ (supply e)moi\ me/lei).—The genitives *trw/wn, etc., including seu= (l. 454), are objective after a)/lgos.
ken (l. 452) ... pe/soien, § 206.
seu=, the MSS. have sei=) (or sei=o) here, which might be retained; but seu= is preferred by some editors to avoid elision before the following pause.
a)pou/ras, § 63.3.
*)/argei seems to mean here ‘Greece,’ in a general sense.
pro\s a)/llhs = u(po\ a)/llhs keleuome/nh.
*messhi/dos, if understood of the spring in Laconia, suggests the realm of Menelaus; while (gperei/hs suggests the home of Achilles, in southern Thessaly. These two genitives are ablatival.
kata\ ... xe/ousan, tmesis.
a)risteu/eske, followed by infinitive, is equivalent to a)/ristos h)=n.
xh/tei+, dative of cause.
a)mu/nein depends on toiou=d'(e), or rather on a oi(/ou which it implies; translate ‘such as,’ ‘able.’
kata\ ... kalu/ptoi, a wish.
e)/ti, ‘besides,’ i. e. in addition to your other distresses. Many editors prefer ge/ ti for g' e)/ti. Both readings are found in MSS.
With boh=s, puqe/sqai means ‘hear’; with e(lkhqmoi=o, ‘hear of.’ For the latter genitive cf. § 174 (1).
‘Seeing it nodding dreadfully from the peak of the helmet.’— deino/n is cognate accusative with neu/onta, which agrees with lo/fon understood.
krato/s, § 100.
ku/se, kune/w.—ph=le, pa/llw.

In this prayer (ll. 476 ff.) the Sophoclean scholia note a resemblance to the following lines which Ajax addresses to his child:
w)= pai=, ge/noio patro\s eu)tuxe/steros,
ta\ d' a)/ll' o(/moios: kai\ ge/noi' a)\n ou) kako/s. Ajax, 550 f.
‘My boy, I pray that you may be more fortunate than your father, but in all other respects like him; and you will not be base.’
pai=d' e)mo/n, appositive to to/nde (l. 476), while a)riprepe/a is a predicate adjective in agreement, after gene/sqai
*trw/essin, ‘among the Trojans’; cf. 2.483, h(rw/essin.
Instead of a)na/ssein an adjective or participle might be expected, corresponding with a)gaqo/n. As the construction stands, a)na/ssein depends on do/te (l. 476).
tis, ‘men’ in general.
ei(/poi, a prayer § 201).
a)nio/nta agrees with min, or a similar word, understood, object of ei)/poi: ‘may men say of him, as he returns from war.’
xersi/n, ‘arms,’ as 1.441.
dakruo/en, cognate accusative with gela/sasa.
e)le/hse, ‘was moved to pity.’
daimoni/h, ‘dear wife, I do not understand you.’
u(pe\r ai)=san, ‘beyond my doom,’ ‘before my time.’
pefugme/non e)/mmenai = Attic pefeuge/nai.
kako\n ... e)sqlo/n, in sense of ‘the coward’ and ‘the brave man.’
e)ph\n ta\ prw=ta ge/nhtai, ‘when once he is born.’
s' is for sa/.
au)th=s agrees with the implied genitive. Compare l. 446, au\tou=.
go/on, a noun.
go/on, a verb, commonly called second aorist of goa/w (l. 373).
min, although short, receives the ictus.
Paris was evidently stung by Hector's reproof (ll. 326-331), and wished to make amends by his readiness to enter the battle again.

‘And as happens when’ etc., the protasis of a present general condition, § 197. The simile (ll. 506-511) is imitated by Vergil, who applies the comparison to Turnus:
qualis ubi abruptis fugit praesepia vinclis
tandem liber equus, campoque potitus aperto
aut ille in pastus armentaque tendit equarum,
aut assuetus aquae perfundi flumine noto
emicat, arrectisque fremit cervicibus alte
luxurians, luduntque iubae per colla, per armos. Aen. XI, 492-497.

As when, his halter snapped, the steed Darts forth, rejoicing to be freed, And ranges o'er the open mead, Keen life in every limb: Now hies he to the pastured mares, Now to the well-known river fares, Where oft he wont to swim: He tosses high his head, and neighs: His mane o'er neck and shoulder plays.—Conington.
So luxurious Paris, proud of his fair looks and waving hair, prances off heedlessly to battle.
qei/h|, Attic qe/h|, § 150.
pedi/oio, § 171.
ei)wqw/s, e)/qwn.
e)urrei=os, contracted genitive from e)urree/os. The nominative is e)urreh/s, and the word is declined like a)lhqh/s.
potamoi=o, a kind of partitive genitive, in construction like pedi/oio (l. 507); or it may be compared with puro/s, B 415.
a)glai+/hfi, equivalent to dative § 155.1). The nominative o(\ d' (e/) has no predicate; e( (l. 511), which repeats o(\ d'(e/), is object of fe/rei, while gou=na is subject.
Note the galloping effect of the abundant dactyls.
a)delfeo/n, Attic a)delfo/n.
e)/mellen, ‘he was about,’ followed by future infinitive, as in Attic.
h)qei='(e), ‘my dear [brother].’
e)nai/simon, ‘in good time.’
o(\s e)nai/simos ei)/h, either the protasis of a less vivid future condition, or ei)/h is assimilated from the indicative to the mood of a)timh/seie (l. 522).
