‘For now again the foot-soldiers and chariots of the Trojans overtook him.’
meto/pisqe podw=n la/be, ‘seized him by the feet, behind.’

du/' *ai)/antes, the two Ajaxes were defending the corpse from behind, during the retreat. In the previous book (P 722 ff., 735) Menelaus and Meriones are said to have been carrying Patroclus on high in their arms; here, perhaps we are to imagine the body laid on the ground again.
qou=rin e)pieimenoi a)lkh/n, ‘clothed in impetuous strength,’ cf. A 149.
For quantity of ultima of kata/ and me/ga (l. 160) see § 38.
h)/rato (preferably written h)/reto), from a)/rnumai.
qwrh/ssesqai, limiting a)/ggelos h)=lqe, ‘had come as a messenger for his arming,’ ‘had come to bid him arm.’
Note that the ultima of *dio/s receives the ictus (l. 32); a slight pause must be made after the word.
h)nemo/essan, § 35, § 159.

e)p-iqu/ousi: a participle corresponding with a)muno/menoi (l. 173) might be expected; instead, the appositive form is abandoned and a finite verb introduced. The poem affords several parallels of this construction; they are interesting as showing the poet's attitude toward his work. He is drawing a picture in words, and hurried on by his imagination he neglects strictly logical construction. Cf. l. 537 and note.
a)na\ skolo/pessi, ‘on the palisade’ of Troy.

se/bas de/ se ktl., ‘and let awe come over your heart § 180] at the thought of Patroclus's becoming the sport of Trojan dogs.’ The construction is the same as after nemesi/zomai, accusative and infinitive.
soi\ lw/bh, supply e)/stai.
h)|sxumme/nos, ‘disfigured.’
i)/w, deliberative subjunctive, § 194.
ou) ... ei)/ae, ‘forbade.’
A remarkable line because it contains no correct caesural pause; one may not occur before ga/r § 14), and *(hfai/stoio pa/r' are inseparable.

On a)/llou ... oi)=da see § 174 (4).—tou= or o(/teu (relative ‘whose’) might be expected instead of the interrogative teu=. But compare a similar instance in Attic prose: h(/dist' a)\n a)kou/saimi to\ o)/noma ti/s (i. e. ‘of the man who’) ou(/tws e)sti\ deino\s le/gein ktl. (Xen. Anab. II, 5, 15.) [The common (but unsatisfactory) explanation of a)/llou ... teu is that the expression has been attracted from the accusative to the case of the following interrogative teu=.]
o(/ = o(/ti.
au)/tws, ‘just as you are,’ i. e. without armor.
Cf. note on 16.43.
Lines 202-231 have been translated by Tennyson under the title “Achilles over the Trench.”
di=a qea/wn, ‘goddess of goddesses.’
au)tou=, the cloud.

kapno/s, the smoke implies the presence of flame; cf. the use of ka/pnissan (B 399), ‘lighted fires’; and with the combined radiance (au)gh/, l. 211) of the fire itself and its reflection in the smoke the bright cloud on Achilles's head is compared.
thlo/qen, to the poet, remote from the island that he is describing, the gleam rises ‘from afar.’
oi(\ de/, ‘the townspeople.’ For the meaning of the rest cf. B 385.
a)/steos e)k sfete/rou, i. e. from their walls and towers.
periktio/nessin i)de/sqai § 211), ‘for their neighbors to see.’
ai)/ ke/n pws, ‘in the hope that.’
a)rh=s a)lkth=res, cf. l. 100.
a)po\ tei/xeos, ‘at a distance from the wall.’ Cf. I 87 and p. 83.

With a)rizh/lh supply gi/gnhtai. A somewhat free version (partly taken from Tennyson's lines) is: ‘and “like the clear voice when a trumpet shrills” on account of life-rending enemies that beleaguer a town.’ The trumpet is blown to warn the townspeople against the foe; so the agency expressed by dhi/wn u(/po is indirect; later writers would here rather use dia/ with the accusative [Monro, Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 204 (3)]. The trumpet was never used in battles of Homeric heroes; apparently the poet drew upon the life of his own day for a striking illustration.
Note the scansion ( § 28, § 70).
How account for the long ultima of a)/ion? § 37.
o)/pa is feminine (cf. A 604); so xa/lkeon must here be used as an adjective of two endings.
pa=sin o)ri/nqh qumo/s, “the minds of all were startled” (Chapman).
deino/n, ‘terribly,’ with daio/menon (l. 227).

a)mfi/, ‘about,’ used vaguely; a more definite word would be u(po/: cf. the phrase u(po\ douri\ damh=nai (3.436, 4.479, 17.303), ‘be subdued under the spear,’ and u(po\ douri\ pe/rqai (16.708), ‘be sacked under the spear.’ The locative sense ‘around’ is not unsuited to o)xe/essi, however. Translate, ‘beneath their own chariots and spears.’ The situation is illustrated by a quotation from 16.378, 379, where likewise there was great confusion:
u(po\ d' a)/cosi fw=tes e)/pipton prhne/es e)c o)xe/wn, di/froi d' a)nakumbali/azon.

‘And under the axles [of their own chariots] the men fell headlong from the cars, and the chariots fell rattling over.’ Here (18.231) there is the additional idea that the men were transfixed by their own (or possibly one another's) spears in the accident of falling.
lexe/essi, same as fe/rtrw| (l. 236).
a)e/konta ne/esqai, ‘to go unwilling,’ i. e. to set before its time. The long third day of battle that began with *l—the twenty-sixth day of the poem—is ending (cf. p. 114).
u(f' a(/rmasin ktl., ‘the swift horses that were under the chariots.’ ‘From under,’ a tempting translation, would be u(f' a(rma/twn (cf. u(pe\c o)xe/wn, *q 504), a metrically impossible expression.
This self-called assembly was in the plain (l. 256).
pa/ros (Attic pri/n), with infinitive, like Z 348.
o)rqw=n d' e(stao/twn depends on a)gorh/: ‘and they stood up during the assembly.’ It was no time nor place for sitting, as the custom was in an a)gorh/.
e(stao/twn agrees with a genitive, ‘of them,’ understood.
de/, ‘although.’
o(/ra (Attic e(w/ra) pro/ssw kai\ o)pi/ssw, cf. A 343.
a)mfi\ ... fra/zesqe, i. e. periske/yasqe.
de/=ga/r.
tei/xeos, the wall of Troy.
r(hi+/teroi polemize/men, in construction like a)rgale/os a)ntife/resqai, A 589.
One night only—and that just before this twenty-sixth day—had the Trojans spent in dangerous proximity to the Achaean ships, so far as the account in our Iliad informs us (last part of *q).
Supply h(ma=s as subject of ai(rhse/men.
‘Such is his furious spirit, he will not desire.’
me/nos *)/arhos date/ontai, ‘divide the might of Ares,’ i. e. share the successes and rebuffs of war.
tis, ‘many a man.’
gnw/setai, ‘shall know him’ from sad experience.—a)spasi/ws ktl., ‘joyfully shall he reach sacred Troy, whoever escapes.’

*trw/wn, with pollou/s (l. 271).—ai)\ ga\r dh/ ktl., ‘I pray that such words [w(=de, ‘thus,’ as I have said] may be far from my hearing.’ A scholiast neatly paraphrases: ei)/qe dh\ tou=to ou)x o(/pws mh\ (‘not only not’) i)/doimi, a)lla\ mhde\ (‘not even’) a)kou/saimi.
nu/kta me/n has as correlative prw=i d'(e/) (l. 277).

ei)n a)gorh=| sqe/nos e(/comen, ‘in the gathering place [of Troy] we shall hold back our troops.’— sqe/nos=du/namin, stratia/n (scholiast). The word is not so used elsewhere by Homer, but the use is not without parallel in Attic poetry.
sani/des t' e)pi\ th=|s a)rarui=ai, ‘and the two-leaved doors that fit upon them.’
e)zeugme/nai, ‘yoked,’ fastened with bolis (o)xh=es). See Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, p. 105, where the great gate of Tiryns is described.
tw=| d' (e/), Achilles, unnamed as before, l. 257.
peri\ tei/xeos, ‘for the [city] wall,’ like l. 265.
h)laska/zwn, intensive form; to be associated with h)la/skousin, B 470, and a)la/omai, ‘wander.’
ei)/sw, within the city.
pri/n min ktl., in construction like A 29.
tau=t' (a) ktl., § 121.
Hector disdainfully applies a shameful word, a)lh/menai (from ei)/lw), to the retreat proposed by Polydamas (ll. 254, 255).
e)elme/noi, ei)/lw.
me/ropes: note the ictus on the short ultima in spite of the fact that no pause follows, an evident reminiscence of the familiar mero/pwn a)nqrw/pwn A 250, etc.
muqe/skonto, ‘used to speak of [the city] as’; with double accusative.
do/mwn, genitive of separation after e)capo/lwle, ‘have been lost out of the houses.’
perna/men) (a), ‘sold,’ in trade; to support the besieged city and pay the allies (cf. note on I 402).
tele/essin = ta/cesin.
e)grh/gorqe (e)gei/rw), perfect imperative active (probably), second person plural, ‘keep awake.’ The form is equivalent to e)grhgo/rate. Compare pe/posqe (3.99).

To cast a slur on Polydamas, Hector suggests that his counsel betrays over-anxiety about saving his property; and as the course that Polydamas advises will lead only to the destruction of the city and the consequent loss of everything, Hector proposes with fine irony that advocates of this course at once share their goods with the mass of the Trojans, who—rather than the Achaeans—ought to be allowed to enjoy them, if the goods are bound to perish anyway.
tw=n, relative; translate by conjunction (ga/r) and demonstrative: ‘for it is better that every man of them [tw=n] should enjoy them.’
e)gei/romen, aorist subjunctive.
para\ nau=fin, ‘from beside the ships.’
ai)/ k' e)qe/lh|si, add ma/xesqai.
ke fe/rh|si, an emphatic future, here contrasted with the optative, ke feroi/mhn, on which less stress is laid. Monro, Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 275 (b).

‘Ares “is our common lord” [Chapman] and often slays the wouldbe slayer.’ Compare Z 339, ni/kh d' e)pamei/betai a)/ndras, with note; and Od. 11.537, e)pimi\c de/ te mai/netai *)/arhs, ‘Ares rages indiscriminately.’ A similar sentiment is found in Cicero, Pro Milone, 21, 56.
With au)ta\r *)axaioi/ the narrative continues the scene described in ll. 231-238; before, the mournful procession was pictured; now the chief figures are evidently in the lodge of Achilles.
a(dinou= e)ch=rxe go/oio, ‘led the choking cry of sorrow.’—For a(dinou= see note on B 87.
w(/s te (always two words in Homer), ‘like.’—For quantity of te see § 38.
u(/po, ‘by stealth.’
ei), ‘in the hope that.’

e)n mega/roisin, ‘in the home of my father’ (Peleus). Nestor tells (11.765 ff.) how he and Odysseus went to Phthia, in the time before the Trojan war, to enlist warriors; and there they secured not only Achilles, but Patroclus as well; Menoetius, the father of the latter, was likewise in Phthia at the time. This occasion is alluded to also in I 253. Why Patroclus was brought up away from his home, Opus, is told in 23.84 ff. When a young boy, he accidentally killed a companion in a quarrel; and his father brought him, an exile from home in consequence, to Phthia, where King Peleus kindly received him and made him the companion and squire of his own son.
perikluto\n ui(o/n, ‘his son grown famous.’
e)kpe/rsanta and laxo/nta (lagxa/nw), with ui(o/n (l. 326).
lhi/dos ai)=san, ‘allotment of booty.’ Evidently it was later than this that Thetis imparted to Achilles his destiny.
o(moi/hn, here ‘the same.’
ei)=m) (i) has future meaning as in Attic Greek.
au)/tws, ‘as you are,’ cf. l. 198.
kamo/mesqa, ‘won with toil.’
lou/seian a)/po, a verb of cleausing, takes two accusatives; cf. 16.667 f. and note.
bro/ton, to be distinguished from broto/n.
khle/w|, two syllables; similarly, e)nnew/roio (l. 351) must be read with four syllables § 43).
lexe/essi, to be thought of as something different from the improvised lexe/essi of l. 233.
e(a_nw=|, the a (long) proves this to be the adjective, ‘enveloping.’
e)/prhcas kai\ e)/peita, ‘really then you have worked your will.’ Zeus speaks with irony; he was not unaware of the part played by Here, after all; cf. l. 168 and ll. 181-186.

h)= r(a/ nu ktl., ‘is it true then, as it seems, that the long-haired Achaeans are your own children?’ i. e. because you care for them as for your own flesh and blood. The idiom r(a ... e)ge/nonto, ‘were all the time, it now appears,’ is familiar: cf. 3.183, 16.33.
mu=qon, here ‘question.’

‘Surely now [me\n (= mh\n) dh/], even a man [kai\ broto/s tis], I suppose [pou], although he is mortal and knows not so many counsels [as I]. is likely to accomplish [his purpose] with regard to a fellow man.’—That a)ndri/ is dative of disadvantage is suggested by the parallel expression. *trw/essi ... kaka\ r(a/yai (l. 367).
pw=s dh\ e)gw/ g'(e) belongs to o)/felon (l. 367): ‘why then ought not I.’
a)mfo/teron, adverbial. ‘Both because [indicated by dative] ... and because [ou(/neka].’
That the poet imagines the workshop of Hephaestus on Olympus is shown by ll. 148 and 616.
For some famous works of Hephaestus see note on A 608.
e(lisso/menon, ‘bustling.’
speu/donta, ‘busily at work.’
pa/ntas, ‘in all.’
‘Placed golden wheels beneath the support [or ‘feet’] of them each.’
u(po/ belongs to qh=ken.
puqme/ni is dative after u(po/, locative in origin.

sf'(i) with its appositive e(ka/stw| is dative of interest.—A spinning basket for wool, provided with wheels—given to Helen by Egyptian Alcandre—is mentioned, Od. 4.125-135. Such contrivances with wheels date back to the old Phoenicians (according to Helbig, Hom. Epos^{2}, p. 108, footnote 13, who compares among other illustrations I Kings vii, 27-38).
oi(=au)tw=|.
qei=on dusai/at' a)gw=na, ‘might enter the assembly of the gods.’
qau=ma i)de/sqai, cf. l. 83.
to/sson, adverbial, ‘so far.’
e)/xon te/los=tetelesme/noi h)=san. ‘And they were [so far =] almost completed, only the cunningly wrought ears were not yet fixed on.’
‘These he was preparing to fit, and was forging the rivets.’
i)dui/h|si prapi/dessin, cf. A 608.
a)mfiguh/eis, cf. A 607.
384 = Z 253, where see note.
tanu/peple, for meaning see Introduction, 20.
pa/ros ge ktl., ‘hitherto, at least, you have not at all been used to visit us often.’
cei/nia [dw=ra], ‘entertainment’ = ceinh/ia, l. 408.
posi/n, ‘for the feet.’
w(=de, ‘so,’ ‘as you are,’ with a gesture of hurry, nearly equivalent to ‘at once.’
Hephaestus, in his workshop, very likely does not see Thetis, but shouts out the following reply to Charis.
For deinh/ te kai\ ai)doi/h see 3.172.
e)/ndon, is ‘in my hall.’
395-397. A different account from that given in A 591.
i)/san, here from oi)=da, not ei)=mi.
o(/pla, ‘tools’ of a smith, here.
pe/lwr, ‘monster’ because big and strange in looks.
a)mfi/, adverb § 168), ‘on both sides.’
qu/raze, ‘forth’ from his workshop into the hall (me/garon) where Thetis was; cf. ll. 393, 394.

zwh=|si neh/nissin e)ikui=ai, ‘like living maidens.’ Yet there is no reason to believe that the poet was familiar with the sculptor's art; quite the contrary, for this had not yet been developed in Greece. (See E. A. Gardner's Handbook of Greek Sculpture, pp. 68, 69.) These golden maidens —like the gold and silver hounds, immortal, that guarded either side of the door of Alcinous's palace (Od. 7.91-94), or like the intelligent ships of the Phaeacians (Od. 8.556-563) that needed neither pilots nor rudders—are simply pictures of the poet's fancy. They belong in the same fairyland with the ‘automatic’ tripods (ll. 373 ff.) and bellows (ll. 468 ff.).
a)qana/twn de\ qew=n ktl., ‘and they have knowledge of handiwork from the immortal gods.’
u(/paiqa, ‘at the side of,’ to support his tottering steps.
e)/rrwn, not simply moving, but ‘limping,’ ‘moving with difficulty’ or pain. Cf. I 364, 377.
424, 425. The same words were used by Charis (ll. 385, 386).
ei) tetelesme/non e)sti/n, ‘if it can be accomplished.’
e)k pase/wn § 70), ‘more than all goddesses beside.’
a(lia/wn, cf. l. 86.
da/massen, ‘made subject,’ ‘forced to wed.’ Cf. l. 85. The goddess Here assumes the responsibility in 24.59 ff.:
au)ta\r *)axilleu/s e)sti qea=s go/nos, h(\n e)gw\ au)th\ qre/ya te kai\ a)ti/thla (‘nursed’) kai\ a)ndri\ po/ron para/koitin (‘wife’), *phlei=.
polla\ ma/l' ou)k ktl., ‘very much against my will,’ because she knew in advance, a scholiast says, the troubles that would follow her marriage.
a)/lla de/ moi nu=n, complete with *zeu\s a)/lge) e)/dwken (l. 431).
dw=ke, subject, Zeus.

gene/sqai te trafe/men te reminds one of A 251, tra/fen h)d' e/ge/nonto. tra/fen, however, is passive in form, while trafe/men is the second aorist active infinitive, but intransitive and equivalent to the aorist passive in meaning.
th=s (genitive of cause) a)xe/wn, ‘grieving on account of her.’— fre/nas e)/fqien, like fqinu/qeske fi/lon kh=r, A 491.
polla\ kaka\ r(e/canta, ‘after he had made much havoc,’ to be translated after *menoiti/ou ... ui(o/n.
ta\ sa\ gou/naq' i(ka/nomai, ‘I have come to these knees of yours,’ i. e. ‘I beseech you.’ Cf. A 407, etc.
a(\ ga\r h)=n oi( [o(/pla], ‘for the arms that he had.’
dunai/mhn, Attic Greek would express the wish with the indicative rather § 202): ei) ga\r e)duna/mhn. ‘Would that I were able to hide him far from horrid-sounding death.’—For w(=de see w(s (l. 466).
i(ka/noi, protasis of condition.
w(=de (l. 464) ... w(s, ‘as surely as.’
oi(=a/ tis, ‘so wonderful that many a man’ shall marvel.

qauma/ssetai is very likely aorist subjunctive in a relative clause of purpose (not an Attic construction), although, so far as form goes, the verb may be future indicative § 145) as well.—For pole/wn (also O 680, etc.) see § 106.
pa=sai, ‘in all,’ like pa/ntas, l. 373.
pantoi/hn ... a)utmh/n, ‘blasts of every degree,’ i. e. violent or gentle or any grade between.

‘To assist § 211] him now when working fast, and now again after whatever manner Hephaestus desired and the work was being finished’; i. e. and now in turn to accommodate his wish and the demands of the work.

e)qe/loi and a)/noito are protases of the past general condition. a)/noito, however, is a suspicious form because the initial vowel is short, although it ought to be long; a proposed emendation is a)nw/goi, ‘demanded’ (van Herwerden).—Van Leeuwen, Enchiridium, § 257.

div.head: The shield of Achilles
div.p:
In shape, the shield may have been of the Mycenaean type (for which Reichel argues), covering the person from head to foot (Introduction. 23), or it may have been smaller, and round, the well-known later form. The poet says that it was composed of five layers (ptu/xes), but gives no further information as to the material, unless the passage in *u (ll. 270-272) be cited, the genuineness of which was suspected even in antiquity:
e)pei\ pe/nte ptu/xas h)/lase kullopodi/wn,
ta\s du/o xalkei/as, du/o d' e)/ndoqi kassite/roio,
th\n de\ mi/an xrush=n.
‘For five layers the lame god had forged, two of bronze, and two in side, of tin, and one of gold.’

Of whatever value the lines may be, they indicate at least a feeling that the five layers were composed of metal, rather than of the usual material, ox-hide. This has been the prevailing view from ancient times; and indeed metal layers are not out of harmony with Hephaestus's other works: the shield-strap of silver (l. 480), the helmet-plume of gold (l. 612), and the leggings or greaves of tin (l. 613). It is usual to assume that the five layers varied in diameter, the largest lying undermost and the others following in order of size. The smallest was a round boss on the outside of the shield. The edges thus formed five concentric rings, and the central boss was encircled by four zones. It is a shield of this pattern that has suggested to archaeologists the common distribution of the scenes on Achilles's shield into five fields.

Reichel, who gives a new interpretation to a)/ntuc, maintains that the a)/ntuga tri/plaka (ll. 479, 480) is a threefold rounded surface (gewölbte Fläche). This, he thinks, means three layers of bronze of decreasing sizes, which probably covered five layers of hide (l. 481). So he has three concentric fields, instead of five, on which to distribute the scenes. Such a shield of hide covered with bronze more nearly resembles the normal Homeric form: the shield of Ajax, for example, may be compared (note on 16.106). But in many other respects Reichel's views about the shield of Achilles are decidedly antagonistic to those generally received.

It has been debated whether the pictures on the shield are altogether a creation of the poet's fancy, or whether they had a basis in fact. On the whole, the most reasonable conclusion is that actual models of the various scenes did exist and had been seen by the poet—whether Phoenician or Egyptian works of art, or Greek imitations, or, as is not improbable, original Greek works of the Mycenaean type. The technique that the poet had in mind is quite probably that seen in the Mycenaean dagger blades, a bronze plate on which are inlaid figures in gold, electrum (an alloy of gold and silver), and a black enamel. (See Tsountas and Manatt. The Mycenaean Age, pp. 201, 202; Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, pp. 229-232.)

The position of the various pictures on the shield is not clearly indi cated by the poet. The ocean, to be sure, he distinctly locates (l. 608) around the rim; and it is a natural inference that the heaven, earth, and sea (ll. 483-489) occupy the center. Beyond this, however, there is no certain clue. On the three zones between the ocean and the central disk the other pictures are to be arranged—from the center outward, as some contend, or from the ocean inward, according to others. Of chief importance to observe is the antithetical arrangement, not only of different scenes in pairs, but even of different parts of the same scene.
The poet's object is evidently to present a view of contemporary life— of the world as he knew it. Conspicuous by their absence are scenes of the sea and ships.

[Among important or recent works on the whole subject: Helbig, Das homerische Epos^{2}, pp. 395-416; Murray, History of Greek Sculpture^{2}. vol. i. chap. iii; E. A. Gardner, Handbook of Greek Sculpture, pp. 69-72; Reichel, Homerische Waffen^{2} (Wien, 1901), pp. 146-165; A. Moret in Revue archèologique, vol. xxxviii (mars-avril, 1901), Quelques scènes du Bouclier d'Achille et les tableaux des tombes égyptiennes. The last named is interesting for its illustrations.]

a)/ntuga ... tri/plaka, ‘threefold rim.’ The reference may be to three thicknesses of metal about the rim to give strength; or to a threefold ornament of metal rings or bands about the circumference of the shield (Helbig, Hom. Epos^{2}, pp. 385, 386).
e)\k d' (e/), ‘and from it he let hang’; ba/lle, here rendered freely, is understood.
*)wari/wnos, MSS. *)wri_/wnos, ‘of Orion.’
h(/ t' au)tou= stre/fetai, ‘which turns in the same place.’
In the knowledge of the Homeric Greeks this northern constellation (Ursa Maior) alone did not set; the other northern stars seem not to have been reckoned.
The city in peace, which is placed in contrast with the city in war (ll. 509-540), contains in itself two opposed scenes: the happy marriage (ll. 491-496) and the trial (ll. 497-508).
ga/moi, ei)lapi/nai, etc., the plural seems to refer here, as often, to different parts of but one object; a marriage, a feast, etc.
h)gi/neun (a)gine/w) for h)gi/neon, § 42.
polu/s, ‘loud.’
boh\n e)/xon, cf. note on 16.105.
qau/mazon, ‘gazed in wonder.’

The trial scene begins. No attempt is made in these notes to set forth all the possible interpretations of ll. 497-508. For further explanations reference may be made to Schömann's Antiquities of Greece, English translation by Hardy and Mann (London, 1880), The State, pp. 27, 28; to Walter Leaf, Journal of Hellenic Studies, vol. viii, pp. 122 ff.; and to Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiquities. pp. 407-409. The whole description of the trial scene is so vague and confused that a question has arisen whether the poet was not trying to describe some actually existing work of art of which he but imperfectly understood the meaning. A similar criticism has been applied to others of the scenes also.
ei)n a)gora=|, ‘in the gathering place.’
ei(/neka poinh=s, see notes on I 632, 633.
o(\ me\n eu)/xeto ktl., ‘the one man claimed that he had made payment in full, but the other denied that he had received anything.’
‘And both were eager to get a decision before a referee.’—The literal meaning of pei=rar in this instance is probably ‘end.’
a)mfi\s a)rwgoi/, literally ‘dividedly helping’ (cf. B 13 for a)mfi/s): ‘divided in approval.’ ‘taking sides.’
ge/rontes, ‘elders,’ who formed the council.
There was but one scepter, which a herald put into the hand of the elder who was about to speak his judgment. Cf. A 234 ff., 3.218.— khru/kwn, ‘from the heralds.’
toi=si, ‘with these [continuing the plural idea, skh=ptra] then they sprang up and in turn gave their decisions.’
du/w xrusoi=o ta/lanta, not a very large sum in Homer's time. Cf. note on I 122.

‘To give to him among them [the elders] who should speak the most righteous judgment.’ Probably the two talents were deposited at the beginning of the trial, one by each litigant; they seem to be intended for the elder whose decision prevails.

The probable interpretation of the somewhat confused narrative of the siege scene is as follows: The enemy's army in two divisions (du/w stratoi/, l. 509) is besieging a city; they are considering (1) whether to continue their attacks with the hope of ultimately sacking the city, or (2) whether to propose terms of peace, the condition being, after an ancient custom, equal division of property (l. 511) in the city between besiegers and besieged. The citizens, however, who are quite unwilling to come to terms (l. 513), form an ambush near a stream (l. 521), where the enemy's cattle must come for water. The ambush is successful, they capture the cattle (l. 528) and kill the herdsmen (l. 529). The enemy, who are sitting in council, hear the commotion, and hurry (ll. 530-532) to the spot; whereupon a fierce battle is joined (ll. 533-540).

Probably the poet had in mind an actual picture of a siege, in which the city occupied the center of a group, and the enemy held either side; so he speaks of two armies. See the picture in Dr. A. S. Murray's restoration (History of Greek Sculpture, chap. iii) or Helbig's Plate I (Hom. Epos).
di/xa ktl., they were divided (di/xa = ‘in two ways’) in counsel.

a)/ndixa pa/nta da/sasqai. Similarly (X 117-120) Hector debates with himself whether he shall try to make terms with the Greeks by proposing to divide equally between them and the Trojans the property of Troy.
e)/ergen, cf. I 404.
oi(\ d' (e/), the townspeople, who were being besieged.
lo/xw|, ‘for an ambush.’
515 r(u/at'(o), ‘were defending’ § 142.4, b).
e)festao/tes, with a)/loxoi and te/kna, an agreement in sense; for te/kna includes ‘boys.’
oi(\ d' i)/san, ‘and the men of the city were going forth’ into ambush.
e(/sqhn (e(/nnumi), third person dual of the pluperfect; cf. e(/sso, *g 57.
a)mfi/s, ‘apart,’ not associated with the fighters (Van Leeuwen).
laoi\ d' u(/p'(o), ‘and the men beneath,’ i. e. depicted below the gods, who were of towering stature.
‘And when at length they came where there was opportunity [ei)=ke] for them to lie in ambush.’
ei)=ke = Attic e)nexw/rei, ‘it was possible.’
toi=si d'(e/), ‘and for them’—the men in ambush.
a)pa/neuqe ... law=n, ‘at a distance from the men’ (in ambush).
de/gmenoi, o(ppo/te, ‘biding until,’ like I 191. The flocks and herds were the property of the besieging army.
oi(\ de/, the sheep and cattle.
oi(\ me/n, the townsmen who were in ambush.
ta/ refers to the same cattle as oi(\ de/, now regarded as ‘things.’
ta/mnont' a)mfi/ [for a)mfita/mnont'(o)], ‘cut off,’ ‘made booty of.’
e)/pi, ‘in charge’ of the cattle.
oi(\ d'(e/), the besiegers, whose cattle were being captured.
polu\n ke/ladon para\ bousi/n, ‘great hubbub over the cattle.’
ma/xhn must be translated with sthsa/menoi, ‘joining battle’; its position would suggest that it be taken with e)ma/xonto as well, as cognate accusative.

e(/lke (subject, kh/r), in place of which e(/lkousa might be expected; but the poet is busy picturing the scene in striking phrase; he does not take the trouble to heed logical construction (Cauer, Homerkritik, p. 261). Cf. l. 175 and note.
podoi=in § 172), ‘by the feet.’
w(mi/leun, subject, the men.

e)ti/qei = e)/teuc)(e) (l. 483), poi/hse (l. 490). It is probable that the series of pictures beginning with this line is intended to illustrate occupations of the various seasons (ll. 541-589). Spring is represented by the plowing (ll. 541-549), summer by the reaping and harvest feast (ll. 550-560), autumn by the vintage (ll. 561-572), and winter by the herding (ll. 573589). The last scene is also marked as belonging to winter by the mention of the ‘noisy river’ (potamo\n kela/donta, l. 576), for in Greece the rivers are swollen only at the end of the rainy season of autumn (Reichel).
toi\ de/, ‘and others.’
a)n' o)/gmous, ‘along the furrows.’
a)rhrome/nh| ktl., ‘and it was like real plowed land, although it was made of gold.’
pe/ri, ‘exceeding great’ wonder.
met' o)/gmon, ‘after the swath,’ i. e. ‘in swaths.’
pa/rexon, ‘supplied’ sheaves, to the binders.
The feast is prepared with due reference to the sacrificial side (cf. i(ereu/santes), which is regularly seen in Homeric banquets.

‘[Women] were sprinkling white barley in abundance [on the meat] for the reapers' dinner.’ In the Odyssey also (Od. 14.77) we read that Eumaeus, the swineherd, roasted pork for Odysseus; then he served it, all hot; ‘and he sprinkled white barley’ thereon (o(\ d' a)/lfita leuka\ pa/lunen).
a)na/, ‘throughout it.’
‘And it [the vineyard] was set [or ‘bristled’] everywhere with poles of silver.’

With kuane/hn ka/peton understand e)/lassen, for the meaning of which cf. A 575, I 349.—ku/anos was evidently used like the many-hued gold and the tin and the silver, for inlaying; it has been shown to have been a blue glass paste (cf. Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, pp. 117, 118).
au)th/n, the vineyard.
a)tala\ frone/ontes, for meaning see foot-note on Z 400.
fe/ron, to the wine vat.
i(mero/en, a ‘yearning’ melody, cognate accusative with kiqa/rize. The usual translation is ‘lovely’ tune.

u(/po, ‘to its accompaniment’; the lyre accompanied his song.—The Linus song was a plaintive melody, upparently widely known in very early times. “Linos is the same as *ai)/linos, the refrain of the Phoenician lament (ai lênu, ‘woe to us’) which was introduced into Greece, where it was supposed to mean ‘Woe, Linos.’ Hence the mythical name, Linos. The lament was sung throughout the Semitie world by the women, ‘weeping for Tammuz’” (Sayee, Ancient Empires of the East, Herodotos, 1-111, p. 168). So much for the origin of the name. The meaning of the song to the Greeks themselves is more important. The Argive story (Pausanias, I, 43, 7; cf. II, 19, 8) ran that Linus was the son of Apollo and Psamathe, daughter of a king of Argos; the boy was exposed by his mother for fear of her father and was torn to pieces by shepherd dogs. The story symbolizes the tender bloom of nature which droops and dies before the glowing heat of Sirius, the dog-star.
571, 572. toi\ de\ ktl., ‘while the others [youths and maidens] stamping the ground in unison accompanied the boy with song and plaintive cry, tripping with their feet.’
xrusoi=o, genitive of material.
ko/prou, ‘cow-yard.’
lafu/sseton, irregular for lafusse/thn, imperfect, third person dual.
au)/tws, cf. B 342.
dake/ein, ‘as to biting,’ infinitive of specification. The dogs, refusing to bite, were keeping out of the lions' way.
staqmou/s ktl., “stables, cottages, and cotes” (Chapman). The cottages were roofed (kathrefe/as), the cotes (shkou/s) very likely not.
xoro/n, ‘dancing place.’ Some render by ‘dance.’
a)llh/lwn ktl., ‘taking one another's hands by the wrist.’
lepta\s o)qo/nas, ‘fine garments’ of linen.

ei(/at'(o), pluperfect of e(/nnumi. The youths' tunics, too, were probably made of linen. It would seem that in the process of weaving, the linen threads were sometimes moistened with oil, to make them pliable and shining. So ‘slightly shining with oil’ means that these garments had not yet lost the impress of their dressing of oil, that they were brandnew.
e)c, ‘dangling from.’
o(te\ me/n, correlative with a)/llote d'(e/) (l. 602), ‘sometimes’ ... ‘and at other times.’
qre/caskon, see tre/xw.

e)pistame/noisi, ‘cunning.’— The meaning is this: the boys and girls at one time would grasp one another's hands, form a circle, and whirl around like a potter's wheel; at another time they would form parallel lines facing each other; then they would run to meet or perhaps pass through each other's line.
e)pi\ sti/xas, ‘in rows,’ ‘in lines,’ like 3.113.
a)llh/loisin, the connection is obscure: interpreting as a)ntime/twpoi a)llh/lois gigno/menoi (scholium) one may translate: ‘forming [in rows] face to face with each other.’
terpo/menoi, with o(/milos, agreement according to sense.
molph=s e)ca/rxontos, supply a)oidou=, ‘as the minstrel struck up his song.’
h(=ken, ‘let fall,’ ‘let flow down.’

knhmi=das ktl., ‘greaves of pliant tin.’ So greaves as well as baldric (of silver, l. 480) and helmet plume (of gold, l. 612) and shield were extraordinary and more splendid than commonly. See Introduction, 30.
teu/xea marmai/ronta, Vergil's arma radiantia (Aen. VIII, 616).
This line marks the beginning of the twenty-seventh day of the poem—the fourth day of battle, which is the last that the Iliad contains. The day is not ended until the twenty-second book (X) is done.
h(\ d'(e/), Thetis.
e)a/somen = e)a/swmen.
e)pei\ dh\ prw=ta, ‘since once for all,’ like A 235.

w(s ... w(/s, like A 512, 513.—With the sentiment a scholiast compares Od. 16.294 (= Od. 19.13): au)to\s ga\r e)fe/lketai a)/ndra si/dhros, ‘steel alone draws a man to itself,’ i. e. even the sight of weapons fires men. Compare note on 18.34.
oi(=) e)pieike\s ktl., ‘such as 'tis meet for the works of the immortals to be, but for no mortal man to finish.’
moi, ‘before my eyes,’ or ‘ah me!’ Cf. 18.61.

ui(o/n is naturally and simply taken as object of kaddu=sai (katadu=sai) in the next line; like katadu=sa *dio\s do/mon (8.375), ‘entering the house of Zeus.’ Cf. min ... e)/du, l. 16. Some editors prefer to make it divide with nekro/n (l. 26) the function of object of a)eiki/sswsi.
e)\k d' ai)w\n pe/fatai (root fen), ‘for his life is slain and fled’ (e)/k).— saph/h|, supply nekro/s as subject.
tw=|, ‘for him,’ i. e. ‘from him.’
mui/as, in apposition to fu=la (l. 30), instead of muia/wn, as B 469.
kh=tai, probably for an original ke/etai = kei/etai, subjunetive of kei=mai.
ai)ei\ tw=|d' e)/stai ktl., ‘always shall his flesh be sound [as now] or even better’ than now; for the gods are all-powerful; qeoi\ de/ te pa/nta du/nantai (Od. 10.306).
a)poeipw/n, with ictus on o. § 39. Cf. smerdale/a i)a/xwn (l. 41).
kata\ r(inw=n, ‘down through the nostrils.’ For the embalming see note on 16.456.
The sense is: even those that formerly remained behind among the collected ships on this occasion went to the assembly (l. 45).
43, 44. ‘Both those that were pilots and held the rudders of the ships and those that were stewards.’
de/, ‘although,’ like 18.248.
Diomedes had been wounded by Paris in the foot with an arrow (11.377); Odysseus had been hit by Socus in the side with a spear (11.437).
meta\ prw/th| a)gorh=|, ‘in the front of the assembly,’ a place of distinction.
56, 57. h)= a)/r ti ktl., ‘as it now appears [a)/r], was this strife [to/de] really [h)=] better for us both, for you and for me, when we two’ etc.
61, 62. tw=|, ‘then.’—o)da\c e(/lon ktl., ‘would have bitten the immeasurable earth, at the hands of their enemies’; the poet has in mind the throes of death.
e)meu= a)pomhni/santos, cf. I 426.
me/n, ‘to be sure.’
to/, ‘this,’ i. e. the matter of our strife; supply h)=n.
Cf. note on 16.60.
ou)de/ ti/ me xrh/, cf. I 496, 16.721.

i)aue/men, the poet seems to have in mind the boastful words of Polydamas (18.259), when he puts this expression into the mouth of Achilles. —a)lla/ tin' oi)/w ktl., ‘but I think many a one will joyfully bend his knees to rest.’ Compare with the idea here expressed 18.270 f. The strain of flight on the Trojans' part is imagined as intense.
ai)yhrh/n, adjective in sense of adverb, ‘quickly.’

dw=ra: these are the gifts which were once before (in I) offered to Achilles through Odysseus, and rejected by him. But now (in T) Odysseus, accompanied by the sons of Nestor and other Greeks, has brought them from Agamemnon's lodge to Achilles, in the assembly. The poet enumerated them a few lines before this:
e(pta\ me\n e)k klisi/hs tri/podas fe/ron ou(/s oi( u(pe/sth,
ai)/qwnas de\ le/bhtas e)ei/kosi, dw/deka d' i(/ppous:
e)k d; a)/gon ai)=ya gunai=kas a)mu/mona e)/rga i)dui/as
e(/pt', a)ta\r o)gdoa/thn *brishi/da kallipa/rh|on.
xrusou= de\ sth/sas *)oduseu\s de/ka pa/nta ta/lanta
h)=rx', a(/ma d' a)/lloi dw=ra fe/ron kou/rhtes *)axaiw=n (T 243-248).
Agamemnon then sacrificed and swore a solemn oath that he had not laid hand on Briseis (ll. 249-266). Cf. I 264-276.
ei)s a)ge/lhn: Achilles seems to have had a number of horses taken from the enemy, apparently chariot-steeds whose masters he had slain.
a)mf' au)tw=| xume/nh (xe/w), similar in meaning to *patro/klw| perikei/menon (l. 4).
*pa/trokle, note the short penult § 4).—moi deilh=| ktl., ‘dearest to my wretched heart.’
deilh=| of course agrees with moi.—For construction of qumw=| compare A 24.
a)\y a)niou=s'(a), ‘on my return’; she has been absent since A 348.
w(/s moi ktl., ‘how evil after evil always waits on me!’
a)/ndra, perhaps Mynes (l. 296); but Homer does not inform us.
moi mi/a ... mh/thr, cf. 3.238.

With kasignh/tous (l. 293) a participle in agreement—like dedai+gme/nous—after ei)=don (l. 292) would be expected; instead the poet breaks off the grammatical sequence (making an “anacoluthon’) and begins a new sentence at this point: oi(\ pa/ntes, ‘they all.’
klai/ein, to be taken closely with e)/askes (l. 295).
a)/cein: editors commonly supply ‘Achilles’ as subject of this infinitive and of dai/sein (l. 299); the sudden change of subject is not at all un-Homeric.
le/padn'(a), ‘breast-bands,’ broad strips of leather passing about the breasts and shoulders of horses, like collars, and fastened to the yoke. See illustration in the Vocabulary.
e(/san, ‘put,’ ‘set,’ commonly taken as aorist of i(/hmi, may also come from e(/nnumi or e(/zw.
e)f' i(/ppoiin, ‘on the chariot,’ as usual.
‘Now bethink yourselves how to save your charioteer in some other [i. e. ‘better’] way’ than you cared for Patroclus.
sawse/men is probably a mixed aorist infinitive § 153). By ‘charioteer’ Achilles means himself, although strictly the word designates Automedon.
zeu/glhs, perhaps the cushion under the yoke to ease the horses' necks. See the Vocabulary.
A reminder of Thetis's words, 18.96.
qeo/s, cf. note on l. 417.
nw=i de\ kai/ ktl., ‘for we two would race even with the blast of Zephyrus.’ their father, according to 16.150.
qew=| te kai\ a)ne/ri, it is the dying Hector who reveals their names: *pa/ris kai\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, X 359.

e)rinu/es ktl., ‘the Erinyes restrained his voice,’ for, says the scholiast, they are watchful against violations of the law of nature. There is no doubt that Homer has lately been lapsing into fairy-land.
o(/ = o(/ti.
pri\n *trw=as a(/dhn e)la/sai pole/moio, ‘until I have given the Trojans quite enough of war’; a(/dhn (originally an accusative) e)la/sai means literally^{4} to drive to satiety.’
See note on T 1.
pefuzo/tes, ‘panic-stricken’; cf. fu/za, I 2.
*foi=bos *)apo/llwn, who had assumed the likeness of Trojan Agenor (as related 21.600).

au)to\s qnhto\s e)w/n agrees with the subject of diw/keis (l. 8); qeo\n a)/mbroton, with the object me (l. 8). ‘And have you not even yet discovered [me = me, an instance of prolepsis] that I am a god?’ asks Apollo in derision.
Another taunting question: ‘really now, are you not at all interested in the battle with the Trojans, whom you have routed?’
*trw/wn po/nos = to\ kata\ tw=n *trw/wn e)/rgon (scholium). *trw/wn seems to be objective genitive.
a)/len, ei)/lw.
toi mo/rsimos, ‘at your hand doomed to die.’
h)= ktl., ‘else surely’ etc.
ti/sin, accusative of ti/sis.
tisai/mhn ... parei/h, probably both verbs would be imperfect indicatives in Attic Greek § 207.1), as protasis and apodosis of a present contrary to fact condition.
me/ga frone/wn, ‘in high spirits.’
Note quantity of ultima of seua/menos.—Regularly two horses draw the Homeric chariot; to one of such a pair Achilles is compared.
titaino/menos pedi/oio, ‘stretching over the plain’ § 171), i. e. galloping at full speed.
laiyhra/, for laiyhrw=s.
pedi/oio, as in l. 23.
w/s t' a)ste/r) (l. 26), … o(/s r(a ktl., ‘like the star that rises in the late summer-time.’
o)pw/rhs, genitive of “time within which.”
te/tuktai = e)sti/.

Imitated by Vergil, Aen. X, 273 f.:
Sirius ardor,
Ille sitim morbosque ferens mortalibus aegris.
‘The heat of Sirius—that brings thirst and plagues to wretched men.’
a)nasxo/menos, object understood, xei=ras.
e)gegw/nei (from ge/gwna), ‘he called out.’
moi, dative of person interested: ‘I pray you.’
a)ne/ra tou=ton, ‘the man yonder,’ your foe.

sxe/tlios, an exclamation: ‘implacable’ (Achilles)! Cf. I 639.— ai)/qe qeoi=si ktl., a grim wish, the sting lying in o(/sson e)moi/ (l. 42). It amounts to ei)/qe e)xqro\s toi=s qeoi=s ge/noito (scholium).
Lycaon and Polydorus have both been slain by Achilles in the course of the present day's battle.
a)le/ntwn (ei)/lw), genitive absolute with *trw/wn.
h)= t' ... e)/peita, ‘surely in that case.’
polla/, a ‘large dowry’; see note on l. 472.
pro\s d'(e/), ‘and besides.’ pro/s is an adverb here.—‘Have pity on me, unfortunate that I am [to\n du/sthnon], while I yet live.’
e)pi\ gh/raos ou)dw=|, ‘on the threshold of old age,’ i. e. at the end of life, when one's race has been run; the threshold from which one steps into death.
e)p-ido/nta, ‘after beholding’ many evils, which are enumerated in the following lines.
e(lkhqei/sas, cf. Z 465.
nuou/s, ‘daughters-in-law.’
prw/th|si qu/rh|sin, ‘at the front gate,’ the entrance into the courtyard (au)lh/), guarded by great folding doors (qu/rh|sin); also referred to below (l. 71), e)n proqu/roisi.
a)\n (l. 66) ... e)ru/ousin, future indicative § 190).
tu/yas h)e\ balw/n, ‘smiting’ (perhaps with a sword) ‘or hitting from afar’ (as with a hurled spear); so the words are commonly distinguished; cf. note on O 745.
oi(/, ‘these,’ i. e. the dogs.
pe/ri, like 16.157.
k'(e) (l. 70) ... kei/sont'(ai), § 190.—ne/w| de/ te ktl., ‘but for a young man it is in all respects becoming’ etc.
pa/nta, subject of e)sti/, to be supplied.
o(/tti fanh/h|, ‘whatever appears.’

ko/lpon a)nieme/nh, ‘undoing the bosom’ or ‘baring the bosom.’ Perhaps with her left hand Hecabe unclasped her peplus at the right shoulder; then with the right hand (e(te/rhfi) she lifted up her breast. Her left breast remained covered. On women's dress see Introduction, 17.
e(te/rhfi, literally ‘with her other’ (hand).
ta/de, ‘this breast of mine.’
e)pe/sxon, in meaning the same as e)pisxw/n, I 489.
fi/le te/knon, agreement according to sense, as below (l. 87), qa/los, o(/n.
mhde\ pro/mos ktl., ‘and do not stand as champion against this foe.’ Cf. l. 38.
sxe/tlios, cf. l. 41.
ou)d' a)/loxos polu/dwros, supply klau/setai.—For polu/dwros cf. note on Z 394.
a)/neuqe ... me/ga nw=in, ‘very far from us.’
polla/, for quantity of ultima see § 38.
bebrwkw\s kaka\ fa/rmak'(a) = Vergil's “mala gramina pastus” (Aen. II, 471).
e(lisso/menos peri\ xeih=|, ‘coiling around in his hole,’ cf. A 317.
The speech of Polydamas occurs in 18.254 ff.
u(/po, ‘during.’
th/nd'(e), the night just past.

a)/nthn, with an understood e)lqo/nta, agreeing (as does kataktei/nanta) with e)me/, the understood subject of ne/esqai: it would be far better for me to meet Achilles ‘face to face’ and then to slay him and return, or to be slain by him in a glorious struggle.

au)tw=| may be dative of agent with o)le/sqai (cf. *)axilh=i damasqei/s, l. 55); or it may be taken with e)moi/ (l. 108) in the sense, ‘or myself to be slain.’—The force of ken is not obvious, for the infinitive does not stand in indirect discourse. The reading may be wrong.
A long protasis begins here and continues through l. 121; there the construction abruptly ends. The poet neglects to supply the apodosis.
a)nti/os e)/lqw, like a)nti/os e)lqw/n, B 185, with genitive.
*(ele/nhn kai\ kth/maq' (= kth/mata), objects of dwse/men (l. 117), which is an infinitive in indirect discourse after u(po/sxwmai.

h(/ t' e)/pleto nei/keos a)rxh/, ‘which [i. e. the carrying off of Helen and the treasures] was the beginning of the strife.’ The relative agrees with the predicate noun; its antecedent is the general idea that has preceded, rather than any particular word or words.
117, 118. *)atrei+/dh|sin, indirect object of dwse/men.
a)/gein expresses purpose.—Before a(/ma d' a)mfi/s understand ei) de/ ken u(po/sxwmai, ‘and if I promise that at the same time we will divide the other treasures equally with the Achaeans.’

a)mfi/s means here (as 18.502, B 13) ‘into two [op posed] parts.’ The same sort of proposition for raising a siege was alluded to in 18.511; and perhaps, as a scholiast suggests, the half of the wealth of Troy is the poinh/ which Agamemnon announced that he would fight for (3.290).
*trwsi/n, ‘from the Trojans.’
meto/pisqe, ‘afterward.’
gerou/sion o(/rkon, ‘an oath sworn by the elders’ in behalf of the people.—With e(/lwmai understand ei) de/ ken.
This verse, wanting in the best MS., Venetus A, and others, may have crept in from 18.512.

‘I fear I shall come and supplicate him, while he will not pity me,’ Hector's hurried way of saying, ‘I fear that when I come’ etc., ‘he will not pity me.’ With this use of the independent subjunctive with mh/, implying fear, compare B 195, 16.128, 18.8, and GMT. 261. But according to Kühner-Gerth § 394.4, b), mh\ ... i(/kwmai is a hortatory subjunctive, like du/w. Z 340, i)/dwm)(ai), X 450; the meaning then would be: ‘let me not’ or ‘I will not come and supplicate him, for he will not pity me.’
au)/tws, ‘just as I am,’ i. e. unarmed.
‘By no means may I now chat with him, “beginning at the oak or rock,” as a maid and a lad gossip.’

a)po\ druo\s ou)d' a)po\ pe/trhs o)arize/menai is a gnomic expression (paroimi/a) which seems to allude to old folk-stories (e. g. how the first men grew out of trees and rocks). A scholiast interprets it, lhrw=des a)rxaiologi/as dihgei=sqai, which amounts pretty nearly to ‘make silly gossip over ancient stories.’ Some prefer to interpret the words literally of a maid and a young shepherd talking ‘from an oak or rock’ where they are sitting.
ei)/domen (i. e. ei)dw=men), cf. Z 340 and § 193.
*phlia/da meli/hn, cf. 16.143 f.
fobhqei/s, ‘in flight.’

Cf. Verg. Aen. XI, 721 ff.:
quam facile accipiter saxo sacer ales ab alto
consequitur pennis sublimem in nube columbam,
comprensamque tenet pedibusque eviscerat uncis.
‘As easily as the falcon, bird of augury, from his high cliff overtakes in flight a dove soaring in the clouds, and seizes and holds her, and rends her with his crooked talons.’
o)cu\ lelhkw/s (la/skw), ‘with shrill cry.’
tarfe/'(a), ‘again and again.’
e)rineo/n, mentioned Z 433.
They ran along the wagon-road under the city-wall; yet the road seems to have been somewhat distant from the wall.
For quantity of ultima of a)nai+/ssousi see note on B 465.
qe/rei+, ‘in the summer.’
e)p' au)ta/wn ... e)ggu/s, ‘near by them.’
With feu/gwn supply o(\ me/n, i. e. Hector

possi/n, ‘in the foot-race.’ Cf. Verg. Aen. XII, 764 f.:
neque enim levia aut ludicra petuntur
praemia, sed Turni de vita et sanguine certant,

said of the struggle between Aeneas and Turnus.
No trivial prize is play'd, for on the life
Or death of Turnus, now depends the strife.—Dryden.
to/ is demonstrative, agreeing with a)/eqlon. A free rendering is ‘there.’
a)ndro/s limits a)/eqlon, a prize “in grateful honour of the mighty dead” (Pope). The allusion is to funeral games.
dama/ssomen, for meaning cf. 16.438.
*tritoge/neia: this epithet, best rendered ‘Tritogeneia,’ was not quite understood by the Greeks themselves. See note on B 103.
qumw=| pro/froni, ‘in earnest.’
The poet who describes this race can hardly have thought of the heroes as armed with the big, heavy shields.
o)/resfi = e)n o)/resi or dia\ o)re/wn.
Homer uses dia\ with accusative where Attie Greek uses the genitive. Cf. note on B 57.
a)lla/, ‘yet’ the dog.

194-196. ‘And as often as he made for the Dardanian gate, to dash before it [i. e. ‘to take refuge’] under the well-built towers, in the hope that’ etc. o(rma/w with the genitive is illustrated also in 4.335, *trw/wn o(rmh/seie, ‘make for the Trojans.’—It is possible, however, to understand a)i/casqai as complementary infinitive, so that the construction becomes, ‘and as often as he started to rush before the Dardanian gates’; then pula/wn would limit a)nti/on.—For *dardania/wn see note on B 809.
oi(, ‘from him.’
‘Just so often Achilles headed him off [parafqa/s] before [propa/roiqen] he escaped, and drove him back [a)postre/yaske] to the plain.’
poti\ pto/lios, ‘on the side of the city,’ i. e. on the inside.

Cf. Verg. Aen. XII, 908-914:
Ac velut in somnis, oculos ubi languida pressit
nocte quies, nequiquam avidos extendere cursus
velle videmur, et in mediis conatibus aegri
auccidimus, non lingua valet, non corpore notae
sufficiunt vires, nec vox aut verba sequuntur:
sic Turno, quacumque viam virtute petivit,
cuccessum dea dira negat.
And as, when heavy sleep has clos'd the sight,
The sickly fancy labours in the night:
We seem to run; and destitute of force,
Our sinking limbs forsake us in the course:
In vain we heave for breath; in vain we cry:
The nerves unbrac'd their usual strength deny,
And on the tongue the faultering accents die:
So Turnus far'd, whatever means he try'd,
All force of arms, and points of art employ'd,
The fury flew athwart, and made th' endeavour void.—Dryden.
du/natai, supply tis.
o(/ ... to/n ... o(/, ‘the one’ ... ‘the other’ ... ‘the other.’
o(/, Achilles; to/n, Hector; ou)d' o(/s, ‘nor the latter’ (Hector).
‘How would Hector have escaped death’—not ultimately, of course, but—‘even up to this time unless’ etc.?
a)ne/neue, ‘nodded “no.”’
e(/lke de\ me/ssa labw/n, ‘and taking them [ta/lanta, the balances] by the middle, he raised them up.’ The heavier fate was the doomed one.
w)/|xeto, subject, ai)/simon h)=mar, i. e. kh/r.
217. nw=i e)/olpa ... oi)/sesqai ktl., ‘I think that we two shall carry off great glory’ etc.
pefugme/non gene/sqai, cf. Z 488.
220 ma/la polla\ pa/qoi, ‘should give himself ever so much trouble.’
h)qei='(e), cf. Z 518.

ste/wmen, second aorist subjunctive of i(/sthmi. A preferable spelling would be the regular sth/omen § 149), with h pronounced short, as in dh/ios often; some MSS. in fact read ste/omen. The form in the text must be pronounced with synizesis.
gnwtw=n, ‘brothers,’ as in 3.174.
noe/w fresi/ = e)n nw=| e)/xw.
o(/s, irregularly lengthened.
s'(e) ... fobh/somai, ‘will flee from you.’
e(/loimi, in sense of ‘slay’; its passive is a(loi/hn.
qeou\s e)pidw/meqa (e)pi-di/dwmi), ‘let us take the gods to ourselves’ as witnesses: ‘let us make’ them ‘our’ witnesses.
a(rmonia/wn, used only here in the figurative meaning, ‘compact.’
filh/-menai, § 131.
e(/teron, ‘either you or I’; cf. E 288, 289.

pantoi/hs ktl., cf. Matthew Arnold's Sohrab and Rustum:
Speak not to me of truce, and pledge, and wine!
Remember all thy valour; try thy feints
And cunning!
dama/ei, future § 151).
h)leu/ato, a)le/omai.
ou)d' a)/ra pw/ ti ... h)ei/dhs, ‘and after all, it seems, you do not know’ etc. Cf. note on 3.183.
h)= toi e)/fhs ge, ‘to be sure [or ‘although’] you thought you did.’ Cf. 16.61, 3.215.

e)pi/klopos ... mu/qwn, ‘deceitful of speech’; with tis, ‘a man of cunning words.’ You think you can frighten me by your bold speech so that I shall run, as before; and then you may transfix me as I flee; but you shall not (l. 283); I will face you squarely now (l. 284).
i)qu\s memaw=ti (moi), ‘as I press straight on’ to meet you.—do/ru is understood with e)/lasson.
ei)/ toi e)/dwke qeo/s, in ironical reference to ll. 270 f., where Achilles boasts of Athene as his ally.
w(s ... komi/saio, for construction see note on 18.107.
ou)d' a)/ll) e)/xe mei/linon e)/gxos: what had become of his second spear, if he carried one, the poet does not say. See note on 16.477.
In 11.32-35 Agamemnon's shield is described; ‘and on it were twenty bosses of tin, all white.’ In this description there is a suggestion as to the meaning of leuka/spida.
h)= ga/r ktl., ‘long since, it seems, this must have been the pleasure of Zeus’ etc. The comparative fi/lteron means that this doom of Hector ‘rather’ than any other fate was the pleasure of Zeus.
‘But [only] when I have done some great deed and one for men hereafter to learn of.’ Cf. B 119.
How may one account for the quantity of to/? § 37.
a)lei/s, ‘gathering himself together,’ from ei)/lw.
pro/sqen ... ka/luyen, for meaning compare note on E 315.
tetrafa/lw|, see Introduction, 33.
a(\s ... i(/ei ... qamei/as, ‘which [plumes] Hephaestus let fall thick’ etc.
a)pe/lamp'(e), supply se/las, ‘radiance,’ as subject—unless the verb be used impersonally.
o(/ph| ei)/ceie ma/lista, to find ‘where it [xrw/s] would best give way’ to his spear. Or the verb may be used impersonally (cf. 18.520), ‘where there was the best opportunity.’
This difficult line seems to contain two expressions, parallel in meaning, either of which may be eliminated without affecting the sense:
(a) tou= de\ kai\ a)/llo me\n e)/xe xro/a xa/lkea teu/xh, ‘now bronze armor protected his body in other parts’ [literally ‘as for the rest’].
(b) tou= de\ kai\ to/son me\n e)/xe xro/a xa/lkea teu/xh, ‘now bronze armor protected nearly all [literally ‘so far protected’] his body.’
Construction (b) has been explained in a note on 18.378; it occurs also in 4.130. The combination of the two is found again in 23.454.
fai/neto d'(e/), subject, xrw/s: ‘but his flesh was exposed’; we say, ‘he was exposed.’—h(=| klhi=des ktl., ‘where the collar-bones part the neck from the shoulders.’
laukani/hn, ‘at the gullet,’ may be regarded as an appositive to au)xe/n'(a) (l. 324). This construction has been from ancient times recognized as difficult.
i(/na te ktl., Vergil's qua fata celerrima (Aen. XII, 507).
o)/fra ktl., the purpose is not that of the spear (meli/h, l. 328), but of the fate (moi=ra, l. 303) that directed it.
333, 334. toi=o d' a)/neuqen ktl., ‘while distant from him I—his avenger, far mightier [than you]—was left behind at the hollow ships.’
me (l. 342) ... lela/xwsi (lagxa/nw), ‘make me to share in,’ ‘may give me my portion’ of fire. For Homeric burial customs see note on 16.456.
gou/nwn, cf. l. 338.

346-348. ‘Would that anger and rage drove me—even me—to slice your flesh and eat it raw, for what you have done me, as surely as there is none that will ward the dogs from your head!’ For the construction compare 18.464-466, with notes.
sth/sws'(i) (i(/sthmi), ‘weigh.’
ou)d' w(\s ktl., ‘not even at this price’ shall your mother place you on a funeral bed.
pa/nta, agreeing with se understood.
proti-o/ssomai, ‘I gaze upon’ you.
toi/ ti qew=n mh/nima, ‘a cause of wrath against you on the part of the gods.’
qew=n, subjective genitive. The sense is, consider lest my death shall stir the gods to wrath against you.
Cf. note on 16.857.
plhsi/on a)/llon, cf. B 271.
malakw/teros a)mfafa/esqai, is ‘softer to handle.’
tis, ‘many a man.’
e)pei/, first in the line, in spite of the short initial syllable § 36).
kaka\ po/ll' ... o(/s' ou), ‘more evils than.’
ei) d' a)/get'(e), cf. note on A 302.
kai\ *(/ektoros ktl., the genitive absolute here expresses concession.
a)/klautos, ‘unwept,’ in the ceremonial way.
The subject of katalh/qont'(ai) is indefinite: “they,” i. e. ‘the dead.’ qano/ntes.
mh/deto, with two accusatives, ‘devised ... for.’
podw=n limits te/nonte, ‘the tendons of both feet.’
e)ch=pten, ‘attached thereto.’
ma/stice/n r() e)la/ein, supply i(/ppous as subject of the infinitive, which is intransitive, ‘he whipped his steeds to a run.’
tou= d' ... e(lkome/noio, with koni/salos, ‘and from him as he was being dragged a cloud of dust arose.’
kalu/ptrhn, see Introduction, 21.
kwkutw=| ... oi)mwgh=|, datives of manner and means, ‘were overcome with wailing and lamentation’; the former is used of the women, as the scholiast says, the latter of the men.
tw=| is neuter: ‘and it was quite like to this, as if’ etc. The sense is: such cries of grief were heard as would be raised if all beetling Troy were blazing in fire from the citadel down.

ko/pron, ‘dirt’ or ‘dust.’ The expression kulindo/menos kata\ ko/pron has many ancient parallels, e. g. Jeremiah vi, 26: “O daughter of my people, gird thee with sackcloth, and wallow thyself in ashes.” Micah i, 10: “In the house of Aphrah roll thyself in the dust.”
sxe/sqe, ‘hold off.’
li/sswm'(ai), § 193.
toio/sde, ‘such as I,’ ‘as gray as I.’
tw=n, genitive of cause. Compare Hector's words to Andromache, Z 450-454.
ou(= ... a)/xos, ‘grief for whom’ (objective genitive).
w(s o)/felen, what sort of wish? § 203.
tw=| ke koressa/meqa, ‘then we should have satisfied ourselves,’ ‘have had our fill.’
a(dinou= ktl., see note on 18.316.
bei/omai, probably parallel with be/omai. See note on 16.852.
deide/xat'(o), for the form see I 224 and 671.
*(/ektoros limits pe/pusto § 174.1).
di/plaka porfure/hn, cf. 3.126.
So when Euryalus's mother heard of his death (Verg. Aen. IX, 476), excussi manibus radii, ‘the shuttle fell from her hands.’
i)/dwm'(ai), for subjunctive see § 193.
o(/tin'(a) = Attie a(/tina § 124).
451, 452. e)n de/ moi ktl., ‘and in my own breast my heart bounds up to my mouth.’
ai)\ ga\r a)p' ou)/atos ktl., cf. note on 18.272.

min katapau/sh| a)ghnori/hs a)legeinh=s, lest he ‘have checked him from his woful valor.’ Andromache uses a)legeinh=s with reference to herself, meaning th=s e)moi\ luphra=s (scholium), ‘that causes me distress,’ because it carries Hector into danger.
to\ o(\n me/nos ktl., ‘yielding in that mighty spirit of his to none.’— me/nos is accusative of specification.
de/smata is a general word, to which a)/mpuka (l. 469), etc., are in apposition. Apparently the poet gives here the complete head-dress of an Homeric woman.

a)/mpuka seems to indicate the same as stefa/nh (cf. 18.597), a metal diadem, especially of gold. Helbig, explaining differently from Studniczka, illustrates kekru/falon and plekth\n a)nade/smhn from Etruscan monuments, suggesting that the former was a high, stiff cap, around which was wound the twisted band (plekth\ a)nade/smh), both useful and decorative (Das homerische Epos^{2}, pp. 219-226).
krh/demnon, see Introduction, 21.
*)heti/wnos, see Z 395.

e(/dna, gifts of cattle, etc., originally paid by the suitor to the bride's father, to win his bride. In the course of the Homeric age—centuries long—the practice of buying the bride, which is here distinctly referred to, underwent a change, as did many other ancient Homeric customs. It is certainly true that the Homeric poetry continued into a time when the old custom was abandoned and that of historic Greece the rule; that is, into a period when, so far from having to purchase his bride, the suitor received a dowry along with her at the time of marriage. To the older period belongs the adjective a)lfesi/boiai (18.593). But to the new custom there are distinct references in X 51,
polla\ ga\r w)/pase paidi\ ge/rwn o)noma/klutos *)/alths,
and I 147 f., e)gw\ d' e)/pi mei/lia dw/sw polla\ ma/l), o(/ss) ou)/ pw/ tis e(h=| e)pe/dwke qugatri/.
(Cf. Cauer, Homerkritik, pp. 187-195.)
a)tuzome/nhn a)pole/sqai § 212) ‘dazed unto death,’ i. e. so that she was like one dead.

a)pourh/sousin, § 63.3.

‘Pulling one by the cloak, and another by the tunic.’

494, 495. ‘And among them, when they are touched with pity, one puts a cup to his [i. e. the boy's] lips for a little time, and moistens his lips, to be sure, but does not moisten his palate.’ For meaning of e)pe/sxen cf. l. 83 of this book and I 489; for the tense see § 184.

With this line the description of the orphaned boy returns to Astyanax. From l. 487 to l. 499 the description has been of a general character, and is certainly inapplicable to any probable situation of Priam's grandson Astyanax, even if he should lose his father. Aristarchus was for removing these lines altogether.
a)\n ... pa/qh|si, ‘he shall suffer,’ § 192.
o)/felos, for construction cf. ph=ma, *g 50.
ei)=nai, ‘that they may be.’

div.head: Book 24 (*w)
div.p: It is in the evening of the thirty-eighth day of the poem that Priam comes to ransom Hector.
e)/n = e)/ndon.

eu(=r'(e), subject, Priam.
480, 481. ‘And as when dense blindness of heart seizes a man, so that he slays a fellow in his fatherland and comes to the land of strangers.’
a)mu=nai expresses purpose.
i)h=s e)k nhdu/os, of Hecabe (Hecuba).
kai\ au)to/s, ‘even alone.’
au)to/n, supply me.

xei=r) = xei=re: ‘to take to my lips the hands of the man that has murdered my sons.’ Compare l. 478. Others understand xei=r) = xei=ra (or read xei/r) = xeiri/), and translate: ‘to reach [with] my hand to the mouth [or ‘chin’] of the man’ etc., comparing A 501.
e)lusqei/s, ‘rolled up.’ “Low on earth” (Pope).
katakei=sqai, ‘to sleep,’ undisturbed.
‘For no good comes of’ etc.

‘To whomsoever Zeus gives of these, when he has mingled them’ (i. e. the good and the bad gifts).
terpike/raunos, § 59.—On this story of the jars is perhaps founded the Epimetheus-Pandora myth, that appears first in Hesiod, Works and Days, ll. 69-104.
e)p'(i/), ‘extending over,’ ‘among.’
ei)=nai, imperfect infinitive, ‘were.’
‘All the territory that Lesbos bounds’ (e)nto\s e)e/rgei).
a)/nw (limiting e)e/rgei) = ‘upward,’ from the south, Lesbos being a southern boundary.

kai\ *frugi/h kaqu/perqe, ‘and Phrygia on the east,’ according to a scholiast; the poet “bounds the kingdom of Priam on the south by Lesbos, on the east by Phrygia, and on the north by the Hellespont.”

tw=n, the inhabitants of the region just defined, genitive (here only) with keka/sqai: ‘among people of this region you used to rank first, they say, in wealth and sons.’—On keka/sqai cf. ei)=nai (l. 543).
pri\n kai\ kako\n ktl., cf. A 29. For the subjunctive cf. § 191.
su\ de\ tw=nd' a)po/naio, ‘and may you have joy of this’ (ransom).
e)/asas, ‘spared.’
Bracketed because missing in many MSS., and evidently added by somebody who misunderstood the meaning of e)/asas (l. 557) and thought the sense must be somehow completed.
se/, an instance of anticipation (prolepsis): ‘I know that a god led you hither.’ Cf. note on B 409.
e)a/sw, in meaning like e)/asas, l. 557.
kai\ i(ke/thn ktl., ‘even though you are a suppliant.’
kh/ruka, Idaeus, crier of the aged king (toi=o ge/rontos).
doi/h, subject, Achilles.
kai\ tw=nd'(e), ‘even of these treasures,’ in an offering to the dead.
e)/nqen, ‘from which.’
toi/xou tou= e(te/rou, see note on I 219.
th=| per ktl., ‘although her twelve children’ etc.
teke/ein, understand Leto as subject.

614-617. These lines look like a later addition to the story just recited; for nothing has previously been said which would lead one to believe that Niobe herself was turned to stone; in fact the point of the whole recital lies in the statement that Niobe forgot her sorrow enough to eat food (l. 613). And how could a stone eat food? as a scholiast pertinently suggests. The Alexandrians (Aristophanes, Aristarchus) rejected the lines altogether.

A later myth does make Niobe herself one of those turned to stone. The scholiast, repeating her story, adds: “So Zeus took pity on Niobe who was weeping over such a great misfortune and changed her to stone, as even up to the present time she is seen by all on Phrygian [th=s *frugi/as] Sipylus, shedding fountains of tears.” Pausanias (2d century A. D.) was acquainted with this Niobe, and repeats the story of the tears (I, 21, 5; VIII, 2, 3), evidently alluding to a stream of water trickling down over a face of natural rock. But it seems to be hardly possible to-day to identify “with any approach to certainty or even probability” such a Niobe as he describes. The (formerly) so-called Niobe of Mt. Sipylus is really a sculpture representing “Mother Plastene,” i. e. Cybele [cf. Frazer, Pausanias's Description of Greece (London, 1898), vol. iii, pp. 552-555].
e)rrw/santo, here ‘dance’ § 184).
qew=n e)\k kh/dea pe/ssei, ‘she nurses her god-given sorrows.’
o(/ssos e)/hn oi(=o/s te, ‘how tall and how handsome he was.’
le/con, root lex, ‘make me to lie down,’ ‘give me a bed.’

With this long wakefulness of Priam a scholiast compares the vigil of Odysseus, who, while piloting his raft, went without sleep for seventeen days, and then swam with the aid of a life-buoy (Leucothea's veil) for three days continuously (Od. 5.278, 279, 388 ff.).
ai)qou/sh|, see notes on l. 673 and Z 243.—The lodge of Achilles grows in grandeur, as the poet proceeds. It is described as if furnished like the Homeric prince's palace, in many respects.
The ta/phtas were spread on the r(h/gea (cf. note on 16.224); on these Priam was to sleep, with woolen blankets to draw over him (kaqu/perqen e(/sasqai).
le/co, intransitive; compare the transitive le/con, l. 635.
ei) ... dh/, ‘since really,’ like A 61.
r(e/zwn is equivalent to the protasis of a condition.
kexarisme/na qei/hs, ‘you would do welcome things,’ ‘you would gratify me.’
ke goes with qei/hs.
e)e/lmeqa, ei)/lw
thlo/qi d' u(/lh ktl., ‘and the wood is far to bring.’
dainui=to, present optative, formed without thematic vowel.
e)n prodo/mw| do/mou: this expression locates the ai)/qousa of l. 644 immediately before the entrance to the large room of Achilles's lodge.
ou)/ nu/ ti ktl., ‘have you not the least fear of trouble [kako/n]. [to judge] by the way that you yet sleep’?
ei)/asen, ‘spared,’ as before.
sei=o ktl., ‘and for your life,’ genitive of price with doi=en a)/poina.
pai=des toi ktl., ‘those sons [of yours] left behind.’

On the morning of the thirty-ninth day of the poem Priam comes to Troy, with Hector's body. For nine days preparations for the burial are making and wood for the pyre is hauled. The next two days are occupied with Hector's burial and the funeral feast. (Cf. note on A 8.) The Iliad ends with the words (l. 804) w(\s oi(/ g' a)mfi/epon ta/fon *(/ektoros i(ppoda/moio.

The rhythm of the Greek hexameter depends on the time occupied in pronouncing successive syllables, and is quite independent of word accent. It resembles, therefore, modern music rather than English poetry. There is, indeed, a regular recurrence of metrically stressed syllables § 8), but rhymed syllables are rare and perhaps accidental.
A short syllable contains a short vowel; this may be followed by a single consonant, either in the same word or in the next.
A syllable may be long either by nature or by position:
1. By nature, if it contains a long vowel or a diphthong. E. g. h)xh/, teuxeu/sh|.
2. By position, if its vowel, although naturally short, is followed by two (or three) consonants or a double consonant (z, c, y).

f, x, and q do not have the value of double consonants. E. g. in A 10, nou=son a)na\ strato\n w)=rse kakh/n, o)le/konto de\ la_oi/, the final syllable of a)na/ and the penult of o)le/konto are long by “position.”
It does not matter whether the two consonants are both in the same word with the short vowel or not. One may end the word, and the other begin the next; or they may both begin the next word.

Although a mute and a following liquid generally have the value of two consonants ( § 3.2), and in combination with a preceding short vowel regularly make a long syllable, it occasionally happens that such a syllable is short if the liquid is l or r. E. g. the ultima of ptero/enta is not lengthened in the often repeated line, A 201, etc., kai/ min fwnh/sa_s e)/pea ptero/enta proshu/da_. Cf. 3.414, sxetli/h, of which the first syllable is short.

Each verse contains six feet, corresponding to bars in music; and each foot, except the last, consists of one long syllable followed by two short ones, or of two long syllables. Two short syllables are equivalent in value to one long.
A foot is thus indicated, graphically: -uu or --; or in musical notation, if a long syllable be represented by a quarter note, one quarter and two eighths, or two quarters.
The sixth foot always consists of two syllables; and these may be both long, or one long (the first) and one short.

The first syllable of each foot is emphasized in oral reading.Emphasizing the first syllable is a classroom technique; modern scholars no longer recommend this. --Perseus This stress of the voice is called ictus (Latin for ‘blow,’ ‘beat’ in time); it can be indicated with an accent mark. The syllable that receives the ictus is called the thesis (Greek qe/sis, a ‘setting down,’ as of the foot in marching); the rest of the foot —either one long syllable or two short syllables—the arsis (Greek a)/rsis, a ‘lifting,’ as of the foot in marching).
Roman writers referring these terms to the falling and rising inflection of the voice used them in exactly the reverse way. Some modern books continue the Roman use.

The foot that consists of a long and two short syllables is called a dactyl. Two long syllables in one foot compose a spondee. One long and one short syllable, found only in the sixth foot § 7), make a trochee.
The whole verse (e)/pos) is called dactylic hexameter; sometimes, from its subject, heroic hexameter.

In the first five feet the poet used dactyls or spondees at his pleasure, but dactyls seem to have been preferred in certain places, e. g. in the third foot, and in the fourth foot before the bucolic diaeresis § 19). The fifth foot, in particular, is generally a dactyl; yet here too a spondee is not uncommon; such lines are called spondaic lines, and are said to occur, in Homer, in the proportion of one to eighteen. They are much less frequent in Vergil.
Lines containing no dactyls are very rare.

Pauses.—If a word ends within a foot (i. e. if the foot is cut in two), the interruption is called caesura (Latin for ‘cutting’). If the end of a word coincides with the division between two feet (i. e. with the bar of musical notation), the coincidence is called diaeresis (Greek diai/resis, ‘division’).

It is at these points, after a caesura or a diaeresis, that the voice may pause in reciting a verse. But unless a caesura or diaeresis coincides with a natural pause in sense, it is generally neglected; where such a coincidence does occur, however, the principal caesura or principal diaeresis is said to be found. Every verse contains at least one pause—almost always a principal caesura.

Following is a metrical scheme indicating the commonest position of the principal caesura and diaeresis:
-w -w -|u|u -w | -w -x
The sign *l denotes a rest equivalent to one short syllable.
A caesura can not occur before enclitics or other words that can not begin a sentence (ga/r, de/, a)/ra, etc.), or after proclitics.
If a caesura occurs after the thesis of a foot, it is called masculine; if in the arsis, that is, between two short syllables, it is called feminine.

The third foot generally contains the principal caesura. The feminine caesura is more frequent than the masculine in this foot, the proportion between the two being approximately 4 to 3 (based on La Roche's figures). For examples of the feminine caesura see B 400-410; of the masculine, A 1 and 8.
A not uncommon pause is the masculine caesura of the fourth foot. E. g. A 3 (after yuxa_/s) and A 7 (after a)ndrw=n).
Such verses (indicated in § 17) often have a pause after the thesis of the second foot also. E. g. A 106, ma/nti kakw=n, ou)/ pw/ pote/ moi to\ krh/guon ei)=pas, or -u u- | - - uu - | - -uu -u.

Diaeresis is not so important as caesura in constituting a pause. The principal diaeresis, when it occurs, is commonly found between the fourth and fifth feet. This is known as the bucolic diaeresis, because it was a favorite with the bucolic poets, of whom the most famous was Theocritus (third century B. C.). How significant it is in Homer may be seen from the fact that the narrative sometimes comes to a complete stop at this point, and a new subject is introduced, as in A 348 and 430.

Less common than the bucolic diaeresis is the one that sometimes occurs between the first and second feet. E. g. A 32, a)ll' i)/qi mh/ m' e)re/qize saw/teros w(/s ke ne/hai., or - uu | - uu-u u-uu - u u-u.
A caesura that was almost always avoided by the Greek epic poets is the feminine caesura of the fourth foot. But compare B 479,
*)/arei+ de\ zw/nhn, ste/rnon de\ *poseida/wni, -uu - -- | -- u u---u.

To accustom the ear to the rhythm of the Greek dactylic hexameter it is advisable to read the lines aloud from the very beginning of the study of Homer. The natural flow of the hexameter, in perfect time, soon becomes a matter of instinct and requires little conscious foresight.

-uu- - -u u-- -u u-u
(For -ew pronounced as one syllable see § 43.)

Lines 43-47 of A thus:
w(\s e)/fat' eu)xo/menos, tou= d' e)/klue *foi=bos *)apo/llwn,
bh= de\ kat' *ou)lu/mpoio karh/nwn xwo/menos kh=r,
to/c' w)/moisin e)/xwn a)mfhrefe/a te fare/trhn:
e)/klagcan d' a)/r' o)i+stoi\ e)p' w)/mwn xwome/noio,
au)tou= kinhqe/ntos: o(\ d' h)/i+e nukti\ e)oikw/s.
- uu -uu- - -uu -u u--
- u u ---u u-- -uu- -
- --u u- --uu- u u--
--- u u-u u -- -uu-u
