The caesura of line 46 is slight; observe the bucolic diaeresis. For long -a_ of fifth foot see § 33, and for short -oi of third foot see § 25.1.

Important to observe: (a) Elisions are indicated by the apostrophe § 40) and need give no further concern. (b) When, at the beginning of a word, a breathing is written over the first of two consecutive vowels (as in o) i stoi/), the vowels are of course pronounced as separate syllables.

Hiatus (Latin for ‘gaping’) occurs when a word ending in a vowel immediately precedes another which begins with a vowel. It may be avoided, of course, by elision, as e)/fat'(o) eu)xo/menos. It is chiefly found under the following conditions:

1. If the first of the two words ends in a long vowel or a diphthong which is regarded and used as a short syllable. This shortening of a final long vowel or diphthong in the arsis, before an initial vowel of the following word, is very common. E. g.
A 14, e(khbo/lou )/*Apo/llownos
A 15, xruse/w| a)na\ … (-ew| is pronounced as one syllable; cf. § 43).
3.164, ou)/ti/ moi ai)/ti/h e)ssi/: qeoi/ nu/ moi ai)/tioi/ ei)sin
a. Final -ai and -oi, though short in determining word accent, are metrically long except under the condition just noted.
2. If the first word ends in -i (dative singular of third declension) or -u. E. g. B 6, *)agamemnoni ou)=lon. *w 387, su/ e)ssi. But many such instances (e. g. A 393) must be referred to § 25.3.
3. If the first word is followed by a natural pause ( § 16, § 19, 20). E. g.
(a) Feminine caesura of third foot:
A 27, h)\ nu=n dhqu_/nonta | h)\ u(/steron au)=tis i)o/nta.
(b) Masculine caesura of third foot:
A 114, kouridi/hs a)lo/xou, | e)pei\ ou)/ e(qe/n e)sti xerei/wn.
(c) Bucolic diaeresis:
B 3, a)ll' o(/ ge mermh/rize kata\ fre/na | w(s *)axilh=a.
(d) Diaeresis after first foot:
I 247, a)ll' a)/na | ei) me/mona/s ge ktl.
After the formula au)ta\r o(/ at the beginning of a line hiatus is several times found (as in A 333), although there is actually no pause in sense.
4. If the first word ends with the thesis of a foot, even when no natural pause occurs at that point. E. g. A 30,
Hiatus is not regarded when elision has already taken place. E. g.
A 2, mu_ri/) *)axaioi=s a)/lge) e)/qhken.

Hiatus seems to occur in some places where it really did not exist in the original words of the poet. This is because he or his predecessors pronounced an initial letter, usually digamma (v), which later disappeared (cf. § 61). E. g.
A 7, *)atrei+/dhs te va/nac ktl.

div.head: Shortening of long syllables
div.p: In accordance with the principle of § 25.1, even a long vowel or a diphthong within a word is sometimes shortened in the arsis of a foot, before another vowel. E. g. B 415
Not infrequently such a vowel or diphthong is written short in the text, if the meter requires it. So two spellings of the same word may be found. E. g.

ne/as (A 487), nh=as (A 12). u(o/s (A 489), ui(o/s (A 9). *)/areos (T 47), *)/arhos (B 110). w)ke/a (B 786) for w)kei=a. e(/atai (3.134), h(/at'(ai) (B 137). *phle/os (16.203), *phlh=os (I 147). o)loh=|s (X 65), o)loih=|si (A 342). ke/at'(o) (24.610), kei/ato (11.162).
Even before a single consonant, a vowel originally long is sometimes shortened in the arsis. E. g. *)Apo/llwn 1.43, 1.14, 2.344, 2,348, 6.320, 1.15.
The vowel thus shortened (cf. § 30) may be written short, giving rise to two spellings of the same word (cf. § 29). E. g. me/n, mh/n (and ma_/n). Similarly a)ta/r and au)ta/r.
de/ used as a continuative ‘then’—including “de/ in apodosis”—is equivalent in force to a weakened dh/. Whether the two words are really identical in origin, however, is disputed.

div.head: Lengthening of short syllables
div.p: A short final syllable is sometimes used for a long syllable in the thesis of a foot if a metrical pause follows. E. g. A 19, A 153.
Not rarely the ictus itself seems to lengthen a short final syllable, even when no pause follows. E. g. A 45, B 39, B 169.
Compare A 342, B 233, etc.
Initial syllables of words that could not otherwise be introduced into the hexameter are sometimes lengthened by the ictus. E. g. A 265.
The vowel thus lengthened is often written long in the text. E. g.

A 2, ou)lome/nhn (Attic o)lome/nhn). A 155, bwtianei/rh| (bo/skw, ‘feed,’ and a)nh/r). A 252, h)gaqe/h| (a^)ga-, ‘very’). B 77, h)maqo/entos (a^)/maqos, ‘sand’). B 89, ei)arinoi=sin (e)/ar, ‘spring’). B 448, h)ere/qontai (a^)ei/rw, ‘raise’). B 460, doulixodei/rwn (dolixo/s, ‘long’).
Compare ei)n a)gorh=| (I 13) for e)n a)gorh=|.
The initial syllable of the first foot is sometimes lengthened apparently by the ictus alone. E. g. 3.357, dia/. X 379, e)pei/.

In many instances where a short syllable seems to be used for a long, closer examination shows that it is really long by position. The value of a consonant (especially digamma) often remains, even when the letter itself has disappeared from the text. E. g. A 416. So too 3.2, 230, etc.

Whether the initial consonant of w(s, ‘like,’ was v or y is uncertain. At any rate, it had disappeared in the Homeric age; its value was retained, however, in formulas like the one quoted, which were inherited from older time.
A short final vowel may make a long syllable when the next word begins with a liquid
l, m, n, r—or digamma, or sigma. E. g. A 233.

These same consonants § 38) are sometimes found written double, within a word, lengthening a preceding short syllable on which the ictus rests. E. g. A 173, e)pe/ssutai. A 278, e)/mmore. A 420, a)ga/nnifon for a)ga/-snifon. B 170, e)usse/lmoio. B 452, a)/llhkton. *g 34, e)/llabe. T 35, a)po[vv]eipw/n.
A 7, *)axilleu/s, but A 1, *)axilh=os. A 145, *)odusseu/s, but A 138, *)odush=os. The longer spellings of the last two words may be original.

div.head: Elision
div.p: Final vowels that are superfluous to the meter are elided before words beginning with a vowel, in the following instances, and the elision is marked by an apostrophe:
1. -a^, -e, -o, of the various parts of speech. E. g. A 2, mu_ri/)(a), a)/lge)(a) (= Attic a)/lgh). A 23, q'=te. A 32, m)(e). A 33, e)/fat'(o). A 52, ba/ll)(e) = e)/balle.
2. -i^. E. G. B 132, ei)w=s)(i). Except the final -i of peri/, ti/ and its compunds: o(/ t' stands for o(/ te, never for o(/ ti. E. g. A 244, o(/ t'(e). Cf. § 123.7.
3. -ai of various verb endings. E. g. A 117, bou/lou)(ai). A 546, e)/sont'(ai). B 137, h(/at'(ai).

4. -oi of the dative singular of personal pronouns. E. g. A 170, s)(oi). Perhaps 3.235, kai/ t'(oi). I 673, m)(oi). The context proves that the dative of the pronoun is intended in the first and third examples.

div.head: Contraction
div.p: Very many forms that would be contracted in Attic Greek are found uncontracted in the text of Homer. E. g. A 1, a)/eide (= Attic a)=|de). A 8, cun-e/hke (= Attic sun-h=ke, from sun-i_/hmi). A 30, *)/argei+. A 49, a)rgure/oio (= a)rgurou=). A 76, e)re/w (= e)rw=).
Besides the familiar contractions of Attic Greek, the MSS. show a peculiar one: eu for eo. E. g. A 37, meu (Attic mou). I 54, e)/pleu (for e)/pleo).

div.head: Synizesis
div.p: Allied to contraction is Synizesis (Greek suni/zhsis, ‘settling together’). This occurs when two neighboring vowels, regularly pronounced separately, must be pronounced as one syllable, to suit the meter. E. g. A 1, -ew (of *phlhia/dew) must be pronounced as one syllable (but cf. § 68). So too A 15, -e/w| (of xru_se/w|). A 18, qeoi/. A 131, dh\ ou(/tws. A 340, dh\ au)=te. A 540, dh\ au)=. For the last three examples the MSS. read, respectively, d' ou(/tws, d' au)=te, d' au)=, readings which perhaps had better be retained, if d'=de/=dh/ § 31).

div.head: Crasis
div.p: Crasis (Greek kra=sis, ‘mingling’) occurs when a final vowel or diphthong is contracted with a vowel which begins the next word. In Homer as now written it is rare. E. g. A 465, ta)=lla (= ta\ a)/lla). B 238, xh)mei=s (= kai\ h(mei=s). Z 260, kau)to/s (=kai\ au)to/s). T 413, w)/ristos (= o( a)/ristos).

tou)/neka (A 96, etc.) for tou= e(/neka is regarded by some editors as an example of crasis; by others it is written tou/neka, as if for tou= )neka (e(/neka) juxtaposed. So ou(/neka (A 11, etc.) is explained both ways.

div.head: Apocope
div.p: By Apocope (Greek a)pokoph/, ‘cutting off’) is denoted the loss of a final vowel before a word beginning with a consonant. No apostrophe marks the omission. The chief Homeric instances are a)/n, ka/t, pa/r, and a)/r (for a)na/, kata/, para/, and a)/ra). E. g. A 143, a)/n. A 8, a)/r.
a)/n and ka/t suffer euphonic changes before certain consonants. E. g. 16.726, a)\m po/non. B 160, ka\d de/. *p 106, ka\p fa/lar)(a). 18.24, ka\k kefalh=s. In composition: E 343, ka/b-balen.

div.head: Syncope
div.p: The suppression of a short vowel within a word is called Syncope (Greek sugkoph/, ‘cutting short’). E. g.
A 13, qu/gatra for qugate/ra. A 202, ti/pt'(e) for ti/ pote. A 275, a)poai/reo for a)poaire/eo.

div.head: Some important particles
div.p: 1. a)/ra (also found as a)/r' , a)/r, r(a, r('), ‘as may be believed,’ ‘of course,’ ‘as it seems,’ ‘so,’ ‘then,’ etc.
2. nu(n), an enclitic, ‘now’ (inferential), ‘then,’ ‘pray,’ etc. Homer uses the temporal nu=n also.
3. ke(n), an enclitic, equivalent to Attic a)/n (cf. § § 189 ff.).

div.head: N movable
div.p: -n movable is found not only before words beginning with a vowel, but also before consonants if a long syllable is required by the meter. E. g. A 77.

div.head: Doubling of certain consonants
div.p: 1. p is found doubled in the relatives o(ppo/te, o(/ppws, o(ppo/teros, etc. o(po/te and o(/pws also occur, as in Attic.
2. t may be doubled in o(/t(t)i.
3. s may occur double in to/s(s)os, o(/s(s)os, me/s(s)os, and other words.
4. An etymological reason very often exists for the double consonant, as may be illustrated in the case of double sigma.
Double sigma of the following words results from the retention of a final sigma of the stem: A 42, be/les-sin. A 82, tele/s-sh|. A 83, sth/qes-sin.

On the analogy of verbs like tele/s-sh| (the stem teles- appears in the noun te/los), although without a similar etymological reason, are formed futures and aorists such as: A 153, maxesso/menos. A 54, kale/ssato. A 76, o)/mosson. A 100, i(lassa/menoi.
Double sigma of the following words arises from the assimilation of a lingual mute to the following sigma: A 368, da/ssanto (dat-santo). A 537, sumfra/ssato (sun-frad-sato). B 44, possi/ (pod-si).
Many of these words (§ § 52-54) have epic forms with one sigma also.

Many double sigma forms in Homer are familiar as double tau forms in Xenophon: A 34, qala/sshs. A 80, krei/sswn. A 483, diaprh/ssousa, Attic diapra_/ttousa. B 51, khru_/ssein. B 87, melissa_/wn, Attic melittw=n. B 440, qa=sson.

div.head: Neglect of euphonic change
div.p: In some words, before m, the mutes d, q, and others are retained unchanged. E. g.
A 124, i)/dmen, Attic i)/smen. B 341, e)pe/piqmen.

div.head: Metathesis of letters
div.p: Some words containing r have a vowel, usually a, either preceding it or following it, at the pleasure of the poet and the demands of the meter. The transfer of order is called Metathesis. E. g. A 25, kratero/n, A 178, kartero/s. A 225, kradi/hn, B 452, kardi/h|.
terpike/raunos (A 419, etc.) is probably in its first part derived from tre/pw (by metathesis) and means ‘hurler of the thunderbolt.’

div.head: Digamma
div.p: The letter digamma, v, which belonged originally to most—if not all—Greek alphabets, means literally double gamma, from its form v. Its value was that of the English w; when vocalized, it became u. When epic poetry began to flourish, it was a living sound; but in the progress of the ages during which the Iliad and Odyssey were transmitted, it seems to have disappeared from the Ionic dialect; and when at last these poems were written down, no sign was used to indicate a sound with which the scribes themselves were possibly unacquainted. Nevertheless traces of the letter survive in lengthened syllables and in instances of hiatus which otherwise would be irregular; compare § 27, § 37, 38.

div.head: Initial Digamma
div.p:
Full lists of words that once were spelled with digamma, with or without other lost consonants, may be found in large grammars and lexicons. The following illustrative list is selected from instances in A and B; the words are grouped in order of roots or stems:
1. (e))va/ndane, h(/ndane (A 24), vhdu/ (B 270). The original spelling was svad-: cf. Lat. suāvis, Eng. ‘sweet.’
2. va/lis (B 90).
3. va/nac (A 7), vana/sseis (A 38).
4. va/stu (B 803). Cf. Lat. Vesta(?).
5. viva/xw: vhxh/essa (A 157).
6. ve (A 406), voi (A 104), veqen (A 114), etc., pronoun of third person; vh=|sin (A 333), etc., from vo/s, possessive pronoun of third person; also e(voi=si (A 83), etc., from e(vo/s. There were original forms in sv-: cf. Lat. suus.
7. veiarinh=| (B 471) for vearinh=|. ve/ar=Lat. vēr.
8. ve/qnea (B 87).
9. vei/kosi (B 748), e)vei/kosin (A 309), Lat. vīgintī.
10. ve/kaqen: veka- thbele/ta_o (A 75), etc.
11. ve/kasta (A 550).
12. vekw/n: a)-ve/kontos (A 301).
13. ve/lpomai: e)pi-ve/lpeo (A 545), e)ve/ldwr (A 41). Cf. Lat. voluptās, etc.
14. vei/lw: ve/lsai (A 409).
15. veli/ssw: velikw/pida (A 98), a)mfi-veli/ssa_s (B 165).
16. veipe/ (A 85), prose/veipen (A 105), ve/pos (A 108). Cf. Lat. vōx, etc.
17. vei/rw: vere/w (A 204). Cf. Lat. verbum, Eng. ‘word.’
18. ve/rga (A 115). Cf. Eng. ‘work.’
19. verussa/menos (A 190).
20. ve/nnu_mi: e)pi-veime/ne (A 149), vei/mata (B 261) for ves-mata. Cf. Lat. vestiō, vestis, Eng. ‘wear.’
21. vi=fi (A 38). Cf. Lat. vī.
22. vi_/emai, ‘be eager,’ ‘press on’; vi_eme/nwn (B 154), not to be confused with forms of i(/hmi.
23. vidw/n (A 148). voi=sqa (A 85), vi/dmen (A 124), vidui/h| (A 365). vei/saito (B 215), e)veisa/menos (B 22). Cf. Lat. videō, Eng. ‘wit.’
24. ve/voiken (A 119), vevoikw/s (A 47), (e))vevi/kthn (A 104), and various compounds (A 97, 131, 547).
25. vi_/lion (B 216).
26. vi=ris (B 786).
27. vi=son (A 163), e)vi/sa_s (A 306).
28. voi/kw| (A 30), voi=ko/nde (A 606). Cf. Lat. vīcus, Eng. ‘wick’ (War-wick).
29. voi=non (A 462), voi/nopa (A 350). Cf. Lat. vīnum, Eng. ‘wine.’
Traces of digamma, not initial, appear in:
1. dei/die (18.34), for de/dvie. dei/doika (A 555), for de/dvoika. e)/ddeisen (A 33), for e)/dveisen.—deidi/ssesqai (B 190), for dedvi/ssesqai.—dve/os (A 515).—dveino/s (3.172).
2. dvh/n (A 416), dvhro/n (I 415).
A vocalized digamma appears in some words. E. g.
1. A 459, au)e/rusan, from a)/n (‘up’) plus (e))ve/rusan (‘drew’); by assimilation of n to v, a)vve/rusan.
2. E 289, X 267, etc., talau/ri_non, from tala- (root tal), ‘endure,’ and r(i_no/s (stem vri_no-), ‘ox-hide shield.’
3. A 356, etc., a)pou/ra_s, originally a)povra_/s, aorist participle of which the present does not occur; future, X 489, a)pourh/sousin, originally apovrh/sousin.

4. I 273, a)phu/ra_ is a relic of an original a)pe/vra_, second aorist indicative (of which a)povra_/s was the participle). The original form was misunderstood by the later poets of the Homeric age, who regarded it as imperfect of a supposed present, a)p-aura/w. So arose the misformation a)phu/rwn, A 430 (third plural) and I 131 (first singular).

div.head: Homeric eta for alpha long
div.p: In place of the Attic alpha long (by nature) eta (h) is commonly found in Homer. E. g. A 45, fare/trhn, Attic fare/tra_n. A 54, a)gorh/nde, Attic ei)s a)gora_/n. A 562, prh=cai, Attic pra=cai.

Masc. Fem.

G. D.

G. -a_/wn, -e/wn, -w=n
D. -h|si(n), -h|s

One frequent feminine noun ends in -a_: qea_/, qea=s, Attic h( qeo/s. A few proper names also have nominatives in -a_s (masculine) and -a_ (feminine); e.g. B 104, *(ermei/a_s. Such nouns of course have datives in -a| and accusatives in -a_n.
A few masculine nouns end in -a^. E. g. A 175, mhti/eta^. A 511, nefelhgere/ta^. B 107, *que/st'(a^).

The genitive ending -ew, which is always pronounced as one syllable § 43), seems to have been substituted in the text, not uncommonly, for the elided -a_'(o), which was the earlier ending. E. g. the first line of the Iliad very likely ended originally, *phlhi+a/da_) *)axilh=os.
A contracted genitive ending -w is sometimes found. E. g. Z 449, e)ummeli/w.
The genitive plural ending -e/wn is regularly pronounced as one syllable (like Attic -w=n). E. g. A 273, boule/wn. A 495, e)fetme/wn.

In the dative plural the longer ending is by far the more common. -h|s is in many instances only the elided form of -h|si, and might be written -h|s). E. g. Z 250, the best MS. reads ai)doi/h|s' a)lo/xoisi, not ai)doi/h|s ktl.
A few datives end in -ais. E. g. A 238, pala/mais.

The genitive ending -oo, shortened from -oio ( § 28, § 29), is restored to the text in some instances by modern editors. E. g. B 325, o(/o (Attic ou(=). Z 344, kakomhxa/noo. I 64, e)pidhmi/oo.
For vocatives in -os cf. § 169.

The dative plural ending -oisi(n) is by far more common than -ois. The latter is, in many instances, only the elided form of -oisi and might be so written. E. g. A 307, oi(=s' e(ta/roisin might be written for oi(=s ktl.
In epic are found the regular la_o/s (A 10, la_oi/), nho/s (A 39, nho/n), i_(/la_os (A 583), etc., for which Attic Greek has lew/s, new/s, i_(/lews.

Masc. and Fem. Neut.

The accusative singular of consonant stems regularly ends in -a, plural in -as. E. g. frh/n (fren-), fre/na (A 193), fre/nas (A 115).

Barytones in -i^s and -u^s, with stems ending in t, d, or q, properly conform to this rule § 79); but sometimes they have accusatives singular in -in and -un, agreeing with the familiar exception of Attic Greek (GG. 115). E. g. e)/ris (e)rid-) has e)/rida (3.7) and e)/rin (Od. 3.136). ko/rus has ko/ruqa (18.611) and ko/run (16.215). xa/ris has xa/rin only.

The accusative singular of vowel stems regularly ends in -n, plural in -[n]s. E. g. po/lis (poli-), po/lin (A 19), po/li_s for poli-ns (accusative plural, restored in B 648, I 328, etc.). po/lias too occurs § 103). h)=nis (h)ni-) has accusative plural h)/ni_s (Z 94, 275, 309).
The two endings of the dative plural often occur in the same word. E. g. ku/wn (kun-) has ku/n-essin (A 4), and ku-si/n for kun-sin (18.179).

Some datives plural occur in three forms. E. g. pou/s (pod-) has po/d-essin (3.407), pos-si/ (B 44; cf. § 54), and by loss of d the Attic posi/ (Z 505). be/los (beles-) has bele/essin (O 727), be/les-sin (A 42; cf. § 52), and by loss of one s the Attic be/lesin (11.657).
The unusual suffixes -ssi and -esi are seen in some rare forms of the dative plural.

The so-called syncopated nouns of Attic Greek, mh/thr, path/r, quga/thr, a)nh/r, etc., are sometimes syncopated in epic, sometimes not. E. g. qu/gatra (A 13), qu_gate/ra (E 371). a)/ndras (B 362), a_)ne/ras (A 262).

1. Pronouns that are always enclitic according to Homeric usage are left unaccented in the table, § 110.

div.head: Reflexive Pronouns
div.p: The personal pronouns may be used reflexively, and then they sometimes have forms of au)to/s in agreement; but the two words are always separate. E. g. A 271, e)/m' au)to/n (Attic e)mauto/n).

div.head: Possessive Pronouns
div.p: Possessive pronouns are e)mo/s, ‘my’; teo/s or so/s, ‘your’ (singular); e(o/s or o(/s, ‘his own,’ ‘her own’; nwi+/teros, ‘of us two’; sfwi+/teros, ‘of you two’; a_(mo/s or h(me/teros, ‘our’; u_(mo/s or u_(me/teros, ‘your’ (plural); sfo/s or sfe/teros, ‘their own.’
fi/los, ‘dear,’ has the force of ‘own’ in many places; e. g. A 569, B 261, 3.31.

o(/, h(/, to/, familiar as the article of Attic Greek, is generally a demonstrative or relative pronoun in epic. When so used, the forms that are commonly proclitic in Attic are accented in the accompanying text (o(/, h(/, oi(/, ai(/). E. g.

1. Demonstrative use: A 120, leu/ssete ga\r to/ ge pa/ntes, ‘for you all see this.’ A 272, ou)/ tis tw=n, oi(\ nu=n brotoi/ ei)sin, ‘no one of those who are now mortals.’ A 20, ta/ t' a)/poina, ‘this ransom’ (that I hold).

2. Used substantively, the demonstrative is often not to be distinguished from a personal pronoun. E. g. A 9, o(\ ga/r, ‘for he.’ 1.29, th\n d' e)gw\ ou) lu_/sw, ‘but her I will not free.’ A 43, tou= d' e)/klue *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, ‘and him Phoebus Apollo heard.’ A 55, tw=|, ‘for him’ (cf. § 176).

3. A noun is sometimes added, in apposition. E. g. 1.348, h(\ d' a)e/kous' a(/ma toi=si gunh\ ki/en, ‘and she, the woman,’ etc.; but to avoid awkwardness, one may say, ‘and the woman.’ So too A 409, B 402.
4. Relative use: A 36, to/n = Attic o(/n, ‘whom.’ A 72, th/n = Attic h(/n, ‘which’ (prophecy). A 125, ta\ ... ta/ = Attic a)\ ... tau=ta. A 249, tou= = Attic ou(=. A 336, o(/ = Attic o(/s.

Sometimes o(/, h(/, to/, is used like the Attic article. E. g. A 70, ta/ t' e)o/nta, ‘the present.’ A 6, ta\ prw=ta (cf. Xen. Anab. I, 10, 10, to\ prw=ton). 3.109, o( ge/rwn shows the ‘generic’ use of the word; so too I 320, o(/ t' a)ergo\s a)nh/r.
(a) Suspiciously like the Attic use are A 33, o( ge/rwn, A 35, o( geraio/s, etc.
(b) Observe that in this use the forms that are proclitic in Attic are left unaccented in this text.

Besides o(/, h(/, to/, Homeric demonstratives are o(/de (Latin hīc), ou(=tos (iste), and kei=nos (ille), which is commoner than e)kei=nos. E. g. A 234, nai\ ma\ to/de skh=ptron, ‘verily, by this scepter,’ that I hold (hōc scēptrum). A 573, loi/gia e)/rga ta/d' e)/ssetai, ‘sorry doings these here [where I am] will be’; ‘there will be sorry doings here.’ For kei=noi (= illī) see A 266.

ou(=tos, like Latin iste, may express contempt. E. g. Z 352. tou/tw d' ou)/t' a)\r nu=n fre/nes e)/mpedoi ou)/t' a)/r' o)pi/ssw e)/ssontai, ‘this fellow neither has sound sense now, nor will ever get it.’ 18.285, su\ me\n ou)ke/t' e)moi\ fi/la tau=t' a)goreu/eis, ‘this speech of yours [with a tone of contempt] no longer pleases me.’

div.head: Interrogative and Indefinite Pronouns
div.p: In most cases the interrogative ti/s, ti/, and the indefinite tis, ti, have the same forms in Homer as in Attic.

1. Special Homeric forms of the interrogative (equivalent Attic forms in parenthesis):
Sing. G. te/o, teu= (tou=, ti/nos)
Plur. G. te/wn (ti/nwn)
D. Od. 10.110, toi=sin? (ti/sin)

2. Of the indefinite:
Sing. G. teo, teu (tou, tino/s)
D. tew| (tw|, tini/)
Plur. A. Neut. Od. 19.218, a)/ssa (a)/tta, tina/)

div.head: Relative Pronouns
div.p: The inflection of o(/s, h(/, o(/, shows the peculiarities of the first and second declensions that have already been noted.
1. For o(/o, genitive singular, see § 74.
2. e(/hs for h(=s is read in the MSS. in 16.208.

3. te is often found following the relative pronoun or adverb. Unless it makes the statement more general, it is apt to have no perceptible force, simply serving to fill out the meter. E. g. A 86, w(=| te. A 238, oi(/ te.
4. o(/s sometimes serves as a demonstrative. E. g. A 405, o(/s r(a, ‘then he.’
5. The cognate adverb is w(s, ‘as.’ Cf. § 116. When this word follows its noun and means ‘like,’ it is accented. E. g. B 190, kako\n w(/s. Cf. § 37.
6. Homer uses w(/s te (always two words) in the sense of ‘as’ and ‘like.’
7. The neuter o(/ or o(/ te is often used as a conjunction, ‘that,’ ‘in that,’ ‘because’; it is then equivalent to o(/ti (o(/tti). E. g. A 120, o(/, ‘that.’ A 244, o(/ t'(e), ‘because.’ see § 40.2.

Besides Attic forms of o(/s tis (or o(/stis), h(/ tis, o(/ ti, these peculiar Homeric forms occur in the MSS. (equivalent Attic forms in parenthesis):
Case Masculine Neuter, where different
Singular: Nom. o(/tis (Attic o(/stis) o(/tti (o(/ ti)
Gen. o(/tteo, o(/tteu, o(/teu (o(/tou, ou(=tinos)
Dat. o(/tew| (o(/tw|, w(=|tini)
Acc. o(/tina (o(/ntina) o(/tti (o(/ ti)
Plural: Nom. -- a(/ssa, o(/tina (a(/tta, a(/tina)
Gen. o(/tewn (o(/twn, w(=ntinwn)
Dat. o(te/oisi(n) (o(/tois, oi(=stisi)
Acc. o(/tinas (ou(/stinas) a(/ssa (a(/tta)

div.head: Verbs
div.p: The syllabic and temporal augments are often omitted. E. g. A 4, teu=xe. A 6, diasth/thn (= di-esth/thn). A 10, o)le/konto (= Attic w)/llunto). A 56, o(ra=to (= e(w/ra_).
Monosyllabic verbs that lack the augment are circumflexed. E. g. A 34, bh=.

div.head: Perfect and Pluperfect
div.p: The so-called Attic reduplication is commoner in Homer than in later Greek: E. g. B 218, sunoxwko/te (better sunokwxo/te) from sun-e/xw. B 799, o)/pwpa, from o)p-; see o(ra/w.

div.head: Second Aorist
div.p: The reduplicated second aorist, of which the Attic h)/gagon is also an example, is very common in Homer. E. g. A 100, pepi/qoimen, from pei/qw. A 256, kexaroi/ato, from xai/rw.

Two verbs, e)ni/ptw, ‘rebuke,’ and e)ru_(kw, ‘restrain,’ reduplicate their second aorist stems at the end (instead of at the beginning) by repeating the final consonant preceded by a: h)ni_/pape, h)ru_/kake.

div.head: Thematic and Non-Thematic Forms
div.p: In some tenses of both -w and -mi verbs the endings are attached to the stem or theme by means of a connecting vowel which may be called the thematic vowel. This vowel is o (w in the subjunctive) before m and n, and e (h in the subjunctive) in other situations. Verbs thus formed are said to belong to the thematic inflection; while all verbforms which lack this vowel o/e or w/h are said to be of the non-thematic inflection. E. g.
Thematic: lu_-so/-menos, de/x-e-sqai, a)/gein (a)ge + en), e(/l-w-mai.
Non-thematic: le/lu-tai, i(sta/-menos, e)/sth, e)lu_/-sa-o.
Non-thematic forms are much commoner in Homer than in later Greek. E. g.

A 23, de/xqai (second aorist middle infinitive of de/xesqai). T 10, de/co (imperative). B 420, de/kto (indicative). B 794, de/gmenos (participle). A 532, a)/lto (second aorist of a(/llomai). B 107, forh=nai (present active infinitive of fore/w). I 171, fe/rte (imperative of fe/rw). X 265, filh/menai (present active infinitive of file/w).

On the other hand, some forms that are nonthematic in Attic belong to the thematic inflection in Homer. E. g. I 164, didoi=s for dido/-eis (Attic di/dws). O 613, e)pw/rnu-e. Compare Z 523, meqiei=s for meq-ie/-eis (the Attic has both i_(/hs and i_(ei=s).

div.head: Personal endings: Active Voice and Aorist Passive
div.p: Especially noteworthy endings, which are further explained in § 13, are printed in bolder type.

Primary Tenses of the Indicative and All Subjunctive Tenses:
Person Ending
Singular: 1. -mi
2. -si, -s, -sqa
3. -ti(n), -si(n)
Dual: 2. -ton
3. -ton
Plural: 1. -men
2. -te
3. -[n]si(n), -a_si(n)

In the singular and in the third person plural the verb exhibits a variety of endings, already familiar from Attic Greek, when the personal ending proper either (a) is wanting, e. g. lu_/sw (A 29), te/thka (3.176), or (b) loses its separate identity by coalescing with the thematic vowel or tense suffix, e. g. dw/sousi (A 123) for dw-so-nsi, e)k-pe/rswsi (A 164) for e)k-per-sw-nsi, teqarsh/ka_si (I 420) for teqarsh-ka-nsi.

The personal ending -a_si, which is distinct from the verb ending just illustrated, is seen in such forms as e)ggega/a_sin (Z 493), perfect of e)ggi/gnomai, and beba/a_si (B 134), perfect of bai/nw. -a^sin occurs twice (Od. 7.114 and Od. 11.304).
-sa_si is seen in i)/sa_si (I 36) for i)d-sasi, from oi=da.

Secondary Tenses of the Indicative and All Optative Tenses:
Person Ending
Singular: 1. -n, -mi in optative
2. -s, -sqa
3. Wanting
Dual: 2. -ton
3. -thn (-ton, three times)
Plural: 1. -men
2. -te
3. -n, -san
See also the note to section 133.

Imperative:
Person Ending
Singular: 2. -qi
3. -tw
Dual: 2. -ton
3. -twn
Plural: 2. -te
3. -ntwn (except e)/stwn)
See also the note to section 133.
1. -mi belongs not only to the indicative of the so-called -mi verbs and to the optative, but also to some subjunctives. E. g. A 549, e)qe/lwmi (= Attic e)qe/lw). 24.717, a)ga/gwmi (=a)ga/gw).
2. -si of the second person singular is preserved in e)ssi/ (A 176, etc.) only, from ei)mi/. This form and its Homeric equivalent ei)s (‘thou art’) are enclitic.

3. -sqa (very rarely -qa) is more common in Homer than in Attic Greek, occurring in the indicative, subjunctive, and optative. E. g. A 85, oi)=sqa (for oi)d=qa or oi)d-sqa). A 397, e)/fhsqa. A 554, e)qe/lh|sqa. *w 619, klai/oisqa. The first two forms are Attic also.
4. -eias, -eie(n), and -eian, of the aorist optative, are regular in Homer as in Attic. But in a few instances -ais, -ai, and -aien occur. E. g. A 255, ghqh/sai.
5. -ti(n) is preserved in e)sti/(n) only.

6. -si(n) of the third person singular occurs not only in the indicative of -mi verbs but also in some subjunctives. E. g. A 129, dw=|si (= Attic dw=|). A 324, dw/h|sin (= dw=|). A 408, e)qe/lh|sin (= e)qe/lh|). B 366, e)/h|si (= h)=|). 3.353, e)rri_/gh|si (second perfect of r(i_ge/w). I 701, i)/h|sin (= i)/h|).

7. The imperfect and aorist of the non-thematic inflection sometimes have third persons plural ending in -a-n, -e-n, or -u-n. E. g. A 273, cu/nien (=cun-i_/esan). A 391, e)/ban (=e)/bhsan). A 533, a)ne/stan (= a)n-e/sthsan). 4.222, e)/dun (= e)/du_san). The vowel before -n is short.

8. The third person plural aorist (first and second) passive sometimes ends in -e-n. E. g. A 57, h)/gerqen (= h)ge/rqhsan, from a)gei/rw). A 200, fa/anqen (= e)fae/nqhsan, Attic e)fa/nqhsan). A 251, tra/fen (= e)tra/fhsan). A 531, die/tmagen (from dia-tmh/gw).
9. -qi of the imperative belongs to the non-thematic inflection. E. g. Z 363, o)/rnuqi (present of o)/rnu_mi). A 37, klu=qi (second aorist of [klu/w]). A 586, te/tlaqi (perfect of aorist e)/tlhn).

10. The pluperfect has -ea and -ee(n) or -ei(n) in the first and third persons singular, respectively. E. g. 14.71, h)/|dea (from oi)=da). 18.404, h)/|deen. A 70, h)/|dei. A second person singular h)ei/dhs (from oi)=da) occurs in X 280. h)/|dhsqa, the Attic, is found once in the Odyssey (Od. 19.93).
§ 137. Active Infinitive Endings, including Aorist Passive:
1. a. -e/menai and -ein occur in the thematic inflection. E. g. A 151, e)lqe/menai (= e)lqei=n). A 277, e)rize/menai (= e)ri/zein). A 60, a)ponosth/sein.
b. -menai is found in the non-thematic inflection. E. g. A 98, do/menai (= Attic dou=nai). A 187, o(moiwqh/menai (= o(moiwqh=nai, aorist passive).

2. -e/men and -men, shortened forms of the preceding endings, are common. Before words beginning with a vowel they may be regarded as elided forms (and written -e/men' , -men)) E. g. A 78, xolwse/men (or xolwse/men)). A 323, a)ge/men (a)/gein) A 283, meqe/men (Attic meq-ei=nai), second aorist of meqi/hmi.
3. -nai is found after long vowels and diphthongs. E. g A 134, a)podou=nai. A 226, qwrhxqh=nai (aorist passive). See 7, below.
4. A wrongly formed ending -e/ein appears in some second aorists. E. g. B 414, bale/ein (= balei=n). 3.236, i)de/ein (= i)dei=n).
5. -sai (also -ai after liquids) of the first aorist active occurs as in Attic. E. g. A 19, e)kpe/rsai. A 67, a)mu=nai. H 261, ktei=nai.
6. The forms of the present infinitive of ei)mi/ are: e)/mmenai (for e)s-menai), e)/menai, e)/mmen, e)/men, ei)=nai.
7. The infinitives of ei)=mi are: i)/menai, i)/men, i)e/nai (the only in finitive in -e/nai).

div.head: Personal endings: Middle and Passive Voices (except the Aorist Passive, for which see § § 133-137)
div.p: Especially noteworthy endings, which are further explained in § 142, are printed in bolder type.

Primary Tenses of the Indicative and All Subjunctive Tenses:
Person Ending
Singular: 1. -mai
2. -sai, -ai
3. -tai
Dual: 2. -sqon
3. -sqon
Plural: 1. -mesqa, -meqa
2. -sqe
3. -ntai, -atai

§ 139. Secondary Tenses of the Indicative and All Optative Tenses:
Person Ending
Singular: 1. -mhn
2. -so, -o
3. -to
Dual: 2. -sqon
3. -sqhn
Plural: 1. -mesqa, -meqa
2. -sqe
3. -nto, -ato

§ 140. Imperative:
Person Ending
Singular: 2. -so, -o
3. -sqw
Dual: 2. -sqon
3. -sqwn
Plural: 2. -sqe
3. -sqwn
For the second person singular, see also the note to section 133.
§ 141. Infinitive: -sqai

1. Sigma of -sai and -so is regularly lost between two vowels, except as noted in 2 (below). The MSS. show contraction in some of the resulting forms (cf. a). E. g. A 74, ke/leai (present indicative of ke/lomai). A 401, u(pelu_/sao (first aorist indicative of u(po-lu/omai). A 418, e)/pleo (second aorist indicative of pe/lomai). A 32, ne/hai (present subjunctive of ne/omai). A 207, pi/qhai (second aorist subjunctive of pei/qomai). A 232, lwbh/saio (aorist optative of lwba/omai). A 210, e(/lkeo (present imperative of e(/lkomai). Z 229, du/nhai (present subjunctive of the -mi verb, du/namai). Od. 4.388, du/naio (present optative).

a. Examples of contraction: A 203, i)/dh| for i)/dhai (the equivalent Attic form is the active i)/dh|s, which is perhaps a better reading). A 160, metatre/ph| for metatre/peai (possibly this should be written metatre/pe)).

2. In the indicative and imperative of the non-thematic inflection, sigma of -sai and -so is usually retained. E. g. A 393, du/nasai. X 85, i(/staso (imperative). 16.585, kexo/lwso (pluperfect). These forms are the same in Attic.

a. But here too sigma is often lost between two vowels. E. g. 16.497, ma/rnao (imperative) for ma/rnaso (cf. Attic i(/staso). A 76, su/nqeo (imperative) for su/n-qeso (Attic sunqou=). 16.585, e)/ssuo (second aorist or pluperfect). E 284, be/blhai (= be/blhsai, perfect). And sigma of -so is regularly lost in the first aorist. Cf. u(pelu_/sao (above), and I 645, e)ei/sao.
3. Examples of -mesqa: A 140, metafraso/mesqa. A 444, i(laso/mesqa.
4. -atai and -ato (for -ntai and -nto) are found in the following instances:

a. Added to some themes of the perfect and pluperfect indicative, ending in a vowel. E. g. A 239, ei)ru/atai. A 251, e)fqiaq', i. e. e)fqi/ato. B 90, pepoth/atai. *g 183, dedmh/ato. A 657, beblh/atai. *c 28, beblh/ato, and I 3, bebolh/ato (= e)be/blhnto).

b. In a few non-thematic presents and imperfects of the indicative, chiefly h(=mai and kei=mai. E. g. B 137, h(/at'(ai)= e(/atai. I 628, e(/atai (for e(/- instead of h(/- see § 29). 18.509, h(/ato (= h(=nto). 18.515, r(u_/at'(o) (imperfect).

c. Added to themes of the perfect and pluperfect indicative ending in a consonant; then a smooth or middle mute is regularly changed to the corresponding rough before the ending. The formation is illustrated by Xenophon's a)ntiteta/xatai (Anab. IV, 8, 5)=a)ntitetagme/noi ei)si/. E. g. B 25, e)pitetra/fatai. *p 481, e)/rxatai (e)/rgw, ‘hem in’). Cf. 23.284, e)rhre/datai (e)rei/dw). The Attic equivalents are periphrastic forms.
d. -ato for -nto is regularly found in the optative mood. E. g. A 256, kexaroi/ato. A 257, puqoi/ato.

div.head: Subjunctive formed with Short Thematic Vowel
div.p: Tenses which in the indicative lack the thematic vowel § 130) use in the subjunctive e or o, not h or w. This applies to the active endings -eton, -omen, -ete; and to the middle (or passive) endings -omai, -eai, -etai, -o/meqa, -o/mesqa. E. g. B 440, i_)/omen (Attic i)/wmen), of which the present indicative is i)/men. A 363, ei)/domen (Attic ei)dw=men), of which the second perfect indicative is i)/dmen.
This formation is chiefly illustrated by two important classes of verbs.

I. Second aorists of the non-thematic type:
Indicative Subjunctive
e)/qemen (Od. 3.179) qei/omen (A 143)
[a)peqe/mhn] a)poqei/omai (18.409)
kate/bhmen (cf. Od. 9.83) katabh/omen (K 97)
[e)da/mhte] (pass.) damh/ete (H 72)

II. First aorists, active and middle:
Indicative Subjunctive
e)xw/sato (A 64) xw/setai (A 80)
e)ru/ssamen (Od. 4.577) e)ru/ssomen (A 141)
bh/samen (A 756) bh/somen (A 144)
[i_(la/ssao] i(la/sseai (A 147)
[h)gei/ramen] a)gei/romen (A 142)

The sigmatic aorist subjunctives, xw/setai, etc., differ in no way from future indicatives, from which they may be distinguished by the context alone. So, too, care must be taken to distinguish aorist subjunctives of liquid verbs, a)gei/romen, etc., from present indicatives with which they may agree in spelling.

It is not impossible to regard some verbs in -seis, -sei, and -sousi as subjunctives. Ancient inscriptions show that among the Ionians originally the first aorist subjunctive (in -sw, -seis, etc.) did not differ in form from the future indicativeCf. Cauer's Iliad, Praefatio, pp. xxxv f.; so in some instances (for which see § 190) an apparent future indicative may be actually an archaic subjunctive. E. g. A 175, oi(/ ke/ me ti_mh/sousi. Cf. I 155, 297.

bou/letai (A 67), if a present subjunctive, should have a long thematic vowel, since the corresponding indicative form (bou/letai) is thematic. bou/lht', with elision of -ai, has been proposed as an emendation.
e)rei/omen (A 62) or e)rh/omen. ‘let us ask,’ may be regarded as subjunctive of [e)/rhmi]. It is commonly referred to e)re/w.

§ 149. Themes in -a, -e, or -o, of which the second aorist indicative is non-thematic (i. e. the -mi forms e)/bhn, e)/qemen, [e)ki/xhn], e)/gnwn, e)/domen, etc.) form the second aorist subjunctive by lengthening the final vowel of the theme before the endings -w, -h|s, -h|, etc.: a becomes h; e becomes ei before o and w, but h in other situations, although some editors write it h always; o becomes w. E. g. (1) From e)/bhn (ba-): bh/w, -bh/h|, -bh/omen. (2) From e)/qemen (qe-): qei/w (qh/w), qh/h|s, qh/h|, qei/omen (qh/omen), and in the middle -qei/omai (-qh/omai). (3) From [e)ki/xhn] (kixe-): kixei/w (kixh/w), kixei/omen (kixh/omen). (4) From e)/gnwn (gno-): gnw/w, gnw/h|s, gnw/h|, gnw/omen, gnw/wsi. (5) From e)/domen (do-): dw/h|, dw/omen, dw/wsi(n), also dw=|si and dw/h|sin (= dw/h|).
(a) Under this head belongs also the second aorist passive, e. g., of da/mnhmi, e)da/mhn (dam-e-): damei/w (damh/w), damh/h|s, damh/h|, damh/ete.
(b) The contracted Attic forms also sometimes appear in the text.

div.head: Noteworthy Tense Formations
div.p: In general, the tense suffixes are the same in Homer as in Attic Greek.
Present and Imperfect. Many presents end in -ei/w E. g. telei/w (teles+iw, i. e. yo), Attic tele/w. A 5, e)telei/eto, Attic e)telei=to. pnei/w (Attic pne/w) is probably for pnev-w.

note.—Very many contract verbs in -a/w, which were not contracted in the earlier epic tongue, often appear in the MSS. in so-called “assimilated” or (according to others) “distracted” forms. E. g. for a)ntia/ousan (A 31), e)stixa/onto (B 92), e)la/ein (X 400), and maima_/wn (O 742), the MSS. have respectively a)ntio/wsan, e)stixo/wnto, e)la/a_n, and maimw/wn. Such artificial forms, which probably were due to the influence of the Attic contractions (a)ntiw=san, e)stixw=nto, e)la=n, maimw=n) on the epic dialect, are replaced throughout the accompanying text by the original uncontracted forms.

§ 151. Future. Sigma of the future suffix may be dropped between two vowels (cf. § § 91, end; 142, 1). E. g. A 61, dama=| for dama/sei. A 204, tele/esqai. A 344 and B 366, maxe/ontai. *z 368, dama/ousin. *x 67, e)ru/ousin.
For double sigma forms in future and aorist see § 52, § 53, 54.

§ 153. Mixed Aorist. Some sigmatic aorists have the thematic vowel (instead of -a-) before the personal endings; so they have sigma in common with first aorists, and -o- or -e- in common with second aorists. E. g. A 428, a)p-ebh/seto (bai/nw). A 496, a)n-edu_/seto (du/w). 3.103, oi)/sete, and 3.120, oi)se/menai, imperative and infinitive, respectively, from oi)- (present fe/rw). 3.105, a)/cete, and 24.663, a)ce/men, imperative and infinitive, respectively, of a)/gw. I 617, le/ceo, imperative of root lex, ‘lie.’ 3.250, o)/rseo, imperative of o)/rnu_mi.

§ 154. Special Tense Suffixes. 1. (-e)-skon, (-e)-sko/mhn as an iterative suffix is found in some forms of the imperfect and aorist indicative. E. g. A 490, pwle/sketo, ‘he used to frequent.’ A 492, poqe/eske, ‘he used to yearn for.’ I 331, do/skon (second aorist of di/dwmi), ‘I repeatedly gave.’
2. -qo- or -qe- is a suffix of no special meaning, serving to lengthen the stem. E. g. A 219, sxe/qe (Attic e)/sxe). A 491, fqinu/qeske, i. e. fqinu + qe + ske (iterative).

div.head: A few important noun and adverb suffixes
div.p: 1. -fi(n), properly instrumental, gives the force of a genitive or dative, singular or plural. E. g. B 363, frh/trhfin (dative). B 388, a)mfi\ sth/qesfin (dative). B 794, nau=fin (genitive plural). I 618, a(/ma d' h)o/i fainome/nhfin (dative singular), ‘with the appearance of dawn.’

2. -qen signifies ‘from.’ E. g. A 195, ou)rano/qen. Often it gives the force of a genitive, especially in pronouns: A 180, se/qen. A 525, e)c e)me/qen. An adverbial example is A 247, e(te/rwqen, ‘from the other side,’ ‘over against him.’
3. -qi is a locative suffix. E. g. I 300, khro/qi, ‘in the heart.’ An adverbial example is A 243, e)/ndoqi.
4. -i, an old locative ending, is seen medial in *puloi-gene/os (B 54), ‘born at Pylos’; xamai-eu=nai (16.235), ‘making their beds on the ground’; and final in oi)/koi (A 113).
5. -de denotes ‘whither.’ E. g. A 54, a)gorh/nde, ‘to an assembly.’ A 169, *fqi_/hnd'(e). A 185, klisi/hnde. An adverbial example is e)nqa/de (A 367), ‘hither.’
The suffix is seen appended to a genitive, *)/aido/sde (16.856), ‘to Hades's.’

div.head: Some Suffixes used in Forming Nouns from Verb Stems (Primary Suffixes)
div.p: 1. -twr, -tor, -thr, denoting the agent: h(gh/twr (h(ge/omai), ‘leader’; kosmh/twr (kosme/w), ‘marshaler’; a_)rhth/r (a_)ra/omai), ‘one who prays,’ ‘priest.’

2. -ti-s, -si-s; -tu_/-s; -wlh/, -wrh/, make feminine nouns denoting actions: a)na/blhsis (a)naba/llomai), ‘postponement’; fa/tis (fhmi/), ‘saying’; bohtu_/s (boa/w), ‘outcry’; pauswlh/ (pau/w), ‘pause’; e)lpwrh/ (e)/lpomai), ‘hope.’
3. -tro-n makes a neuter noun denoting an instrument: a)/rotron (a)ro/w), ‘plow.’

div.head: Some Suffixes added to Noun Stems (Secondary Suffixes)
div.p: Masculine patronymics end in -ia/-dhs, -i/-dhs, -a/-dhs, and -i/wn: *phlhia/dhs, *phlei+/dhs, *phlei+/wn (*phleu/s), ‘son of Pe leus’; *qestori/dhs (*qe/stwr), ‘son of Thestor’; *mega/dhs, ‘son of Megas’; *kroni_/wn, ‘son of Cronus.’
§ 158. Feminine patronymics end in -i/s (gen. -i/dos) and -i_/nh: *bri_shi/s (*bri_seu/s), ‘daughter of Briseus’; *xru_shi/s (*xru_/shs), ‘daughter of Chryses’; *eu)hni_/nh, ‘daughter of Evenus.’

An important adjective suffix, added to noun stems, is -eis, -essa, -en (-vent-). Adjectives so formed signify that with which something is equipped or furnished: skio/eis (skih/), ‘shady’; h)xh/eis (h)xh/), ‘echoing’; xari/eis (xa/ris), ‘graceful.’

div.head: Prefixes
div.p: The following, in effect, form superlatives:
a)ri-: a)ripreph/s, ‘very conspicuous.’
e)ri-: e)ri/ti_mos, ‘very precious.’
za- (from dia-): za/qeos, ‘very holy.’
da-: dafoino/s, ‘very red.’
a)ga-: h)ga/qeos (h)- for a)-; cf. § 35), ‘very holy;’ a)ga/nnifos, ‘very snowy.’
The following are negative:
a), a)n: a)[v]e/kwn (e(kw/n), ‘unwilling’; a)ne/stios, ‘hearthless.’
nh-: nhmerth/s (a(marta/nw, h(/marton), ‘unerring’; nhl(e)h/s (e)/leos), ‘pitiless.’

Prepositions were originally adverbs of place or time. This primitive force is very common in epic poetry. E. g. A 39, e)/pi, ‘overhead.’ A 48, me/ta, ‘in[to] the midst.’ A 233, e)/pi, ‘thereon,’ ‘besides.’ A 462, e)/pi, ‘thereon.’

Often the adverb must be translated in close connection with a verb, although several words may intervene. Epic poetry exhibits a period in word-formation when the adverbial prefix had not yet become attached to its verb, as is regularly the case in Attic Greek. This separation, if separation may be said of things not yet united, is commonly called tmesis (Greek tmh=sis, ‘a cutting’). E. g. A 25, e)pi\ ... e)/tellen, ‘enjoined upon.’ A 67, a)po\ ... a)mu=nai, ‘to ward off.’ A 98, a)po\ ... do/menai, ‘to give back.’

div.head: Accent of prepositions or adverbs
div.note: Following Cauer's Iliad, Praefatio, pp. xxxix-xliv.
div.p: Wherever prepositions retain their primitive adverbial force they are accented; and dissyllabic prepositions that have the force of adverbs are accented on the penult. E. g. A 142, e)/n, e)/s. A 39, e)/pi. A 258, pe/ri.
When separated from a following verb by tmesis, the preposition regularly has the accent familiar in Attic Greek. E. g. A 25, e)pi\ ... e)/tellen.

Dissyllabic prepositions that follow their noun or verb are accented on the penult (i. e. they suffer anastrophe of accent). And under similar circumstances the monosyllables ei)s, e)n, and e)c, receive an accent. E. g. A 162, w(=| e)/pi po/ll' e)mo/ghsa, ‘for which I toiled much.’ A 350, qi=n' e)/f) a(lo\s polih=s, ‘to the strand of the hoary sea.’ B 39, qh/sein ga\r e)/t' e)/mellen e)/p) a)/lgea ktl., where qh/sein ... e)/p) is for e)pi-qh/sein. A 125, poli/wn e)/c, ‘out of the cities.’ A 222, dw/mat' e)/s.

But a monosyllabic preposition is not accented when placed between two nouns (or a noun and adjective) in agreement. Under similar circumstances the accent of a dissyllabic preposition is retracted only when the former noun is more important.

If a preposition belongs to an omitted e)sti/ or ei)si/, it retains its primitive accent as an adverb. E. g. A 174, pa/r' e)moi/ ge kai\ a)/lloi, i. e. pa/reisi. A 515, ou)/ toi e)/pi de/os, i. e. e)/pesti. E 740, e)/n (= e)/nesti).

In the accompanying text a)na/, dia/, a)mfi/, and a)nti/ are accented as in Attic; that is, they never have their accent retracted even when they are plainly adverbs or follow their case § 166). E. g. A 310, a)na/.
But in 16.772, a)/mf) is written to avoid ambiguity. And a)/na (cf. Z 331) is written in the sense of a)na/-sthqi, ‘up!’

div.head: Syntax
div.p: We consider the important or exceptional uses of cases. No attempt is here made to illustrate all the common uses, familiar from Attic Greek.
The nominative singular is sometimes used as a vocative or accompanies a vocative. E. g. 3.276 f., *zeu= pa/ter ... *)he/lio/s q' o(\s ktl. B 8, ou)=los *)/oneire.
The nominative is used in exclamations. E. g. B 38, nh/pios, ‘foolish king!’ A 231, dhmobo/ros basileu/s. I 630, sxe/tlios. *p 422, ai)dw/s.
The partitive genitive may denote space within which action occurs. E. g. B 785, die/prhsson pedi/oio, ‘they passed over the plain.’ So 3.14, Z 507.

The partitive genitive may denote the part touched or taken hold of. E. g. A 197, canqh=s de\ ko/mhs e(/le *phlei/wna, ‘and she caught the son of Peleus by his yellow hair.’ So A 323, xeiro/s. *p 762, kefalh=fin.
The partitive genitive may follow adverbs of place E. g. 3.400, th| ... poli/wn e)u\ naiomena_/wn, ‘to some place in cities well peopled.’ So A 432.

The genitive, in a use allied to the partitive, sometimes indicates a person (or thing) about whom (or which) something is heard, learned, known, etc. E. g. (1) After punqa/nomai: A 257, ei) sfw=in ta/de pa/nta puqoi/ato marname/noiin, ‘if they should learn all this about you two contending.’ So X 438, *(/ektoros. (2) After dida/skomai: 16.811, didasko/menos pole/moio, ‘learning about war.’ (3) After gignw/skw: B 348 f. pri\n kai\ *dio\s ai)gio/xoio
div.l: gnw/menai, ei)/ te yeu=dos u(po/sxesis, ei)/ te kai\ ou)ki/, ‘even before they know about aegis-bearing Zeus, whether his promise be a deception or not.’ (4) After oi)=da: 18.192, a)/llou d' ou)/ teu oi)=da, ‘I do not know about anybody else.’ Z 438, qeopropi/wn e)u\ ei)dw/s, ‘well versed in prophecies.’ I 440, ou)/ pw ei)do/q' (ei)do/ta) ... ptole/moio, ‘not yet familiar with war.’

div.p: The genitive, besides the constructions of the genitive proper, has the functions of an ablative also; under the ablatival genitive, familiar from Attic Greek, are included the relations of comparison and separation. E. g. A 186, fe/rteros se/qen, ‘mightier than you.’ A 113, *klutaimnh/strhs probe/boula, ‘I prefer [her] to Clytaemnestra.’ A 258, pe/ri [e)ste\] *danaw=n, ‘are superior to the Danaans.’ A 224, lh=ge xo/loio, ‘ceased from anger.’ A 359, a)ne/du_ polih=s a(lo/s, ‘rose from the hoary sea.’ A 401, u(pelu_/sao desmw=n, ‘loosed from under his bonds.’ A 30, thlo/qi pa/trhs, ‘far from native land.’

The dative of interest (including “advantage or disadvantage”) is very common; it is often found where the English idiom requires a possessive adjective or noun. E. g. A 55, tw=| ga\r e)pi\ fresi\ qh=ke qea_/, ‘the goddess laid it on his heart’ (‘on the heart for him’). A 104, o)/sse de/ oi(, ‘and his eyes.’ A 188, oi(= h)=tor, ‘his heart.’

Besides the constructions of the dative proper (“to” or “for” relations), the dative has the functions of (a) a locative case and (b) an instrumental case. E. g. (a) A 24, qu_mw=|, ‘in the heart.’ A 45, w)/moisin, ‘on the shoulders.’ (b) A 77, e)/pesin kai\ xersi\n a)rh/cein, ‘will help with words and hands.’ B 199, skh/ptrw| e)la/sasken, ‘would strike with the staff.’

With the instrumental use are included the relations of (a) cause, (b) accompaniment, and (c) manner. E. g. (a) 3.453, ou) me\n ga\r filo/thti/ g' e)/keuqon a)/n, ‘for they would not have hidden [him] out of friendship surely.’ (b) A 277, e)rize/menai basilh=i, ‘to strive with a king.’ 3.174, ui(e/i sw=| e(po/mhi, ‘I followed your son.’ (c) A 418, tw=| se kakh=| ai)/sh| te/kon, ‘so I gave you birth “under an evil star,”’ cum calamitāte (Kühner-Gerth, § 425.6). 3.2, klaggh=| ... i)/san, ‘advanced with clamor.’

The accusative, without a preposition, is often used as a limit of motion. This use includes persons as well as places and things. E. g. A 139, o(/n ken i(/kwmai, ‘to whomsoever I come.’ So A 240, ui(=as. A 317, ou)rano/n.

§ 180. sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros.—Not infrequently a verb takes two objects in the same case (commonly accusative, but the dative is found also), of which the former indicates a whole, the latter a part to which the action of the verb is limited. E. g. A 362, ti/ de/ se fre/nas i_(/keto pe/nqos; ‘why has grief come to your heart’ (‘to you, to the heart’)? 16.289, to\n ba/le decio\n w)=mon, ‘he hit him on the right shoulder.’

div.head: Meanings of the tenses
div.p: While the tenses as a rule describe action as in Attic Greek, the following uses deserve special notice.
The historical present is not found in Homer. All presents are real presents and must be translated as such.
The future middle takes the place of the future passive (which occurs in dah/seai and migh/sesqai only). E. g. A 204, tele/esqai, ‘will be fulfilled.’

The gnomic aorist, commonly used in general statements, is to be translated by the English present. E. g. A 218, o(/s ke qeoi=s e)pipei/qhtai, ma/la t' e)/kluon (aorist) au)tou=, ‘whosoever obeys the gods, him especially they harken to.’ t'(e) marks the general statement here, as often.
The aorist middle sometimes has a reflexive or passive sense. E. g. 16.294, li/pet'(o), ‘was left.’

The aorist participle does not always denote time prior to that of the leading verb, but often the same time. E. g. A 148, u(po/dra i)dw\n prose/fh, ‘with a sullen look he addressed.’ A 596, meidh/sa_sa ... e)de/cato ... ku/pellon, ‘with a smile she took the cup.’
So too when the participle stands in a construction after the verb: A 380 f., toi=o d' *)apo/llwn
div.l: eu)came/nou h)/kousen, ‘and Apollo heard him as he prayed.’ B 182, cune/hke qea=s o)/pa fwnhsa_/shs, ‘he heard the voice of the goddess as she spoke.’
div.p: Note that in all these instances the aorist emphasizes the single act.

The perfect denotes a present condition and is to be rendered by the English present. E. g. A 37, a)mfibe/bhkas, ‘guardest.’ A 125, de/dastai, ‘is divided.’ A 173, e)pe/ssutai, ‘is moved thereto.’ A 228, te/tlhkas, ‘you have courage.’ A 239, ei)ru/atai, ‘defend.’ A 278, e)/mmore, ‘shares in.’ B 90, pepoth/atai, ‘are in flight’ (a lasting condition), while B 89, pe/tontai means ‘fly,’ an action which if continued or repeated produces the condition described by the perfect.
Similarly the pluperfect is to be translated by the English past. E. g. A 221, bebh/kei, ‘was gone’ (= went quickly). B 93, dedh/ei, ‘was ablaze.’ B 95, tetrh/xei, ‘was in confusion.’

div.head: The moods: peculiar Homeric uses
div.p: Homer has six distinct ways of making independent future statements. They illustrate different degrees of vividness:
1. The future indicative alone.
2. The future indicative with ke (or rarely a)/n), § 190.
3. The subjunctive (generally aorist) alone, § 191.
4. The subjunctive with ke or a)/n, § 192.
5. The optative alone, § 205.
6. The optative with ke or a)/n, § 206.
Of these the first, third, fourth, and sixth are the more common; the first and sixth alone survived in ordinary Attic Greek.

div.head: Indicative
div.p: The future indicative with ke (or a)/n) is a construction denied to the earliest period of the epic by some scholars, who maintain (a) that the verbs of A 175 (ti_mh/sousi), I 155, and some other places are intended for aorist subjunctives § 146); (b) that undoubted instances of the future indicative with ke or a)/n (e. g. A 139, kexolw/setai, future perfect) may be attributed to later Homeric poets, who imitated a construction which they falsely understood to be future indicative with ke, and which was in reality the aorist subjunctive. This view presents obvious difficulties, since it involves the question of the earlier and later parts of the epic.

Other scholars accept the construction f the future in dicative with ke in all the apparent instances, and point out that it differs from the future indicative alone only in the contingent force which is added by the particle. E. g. A 175, oi(/ ke/ me ti_mh/sousi, ‘who in that case [i. e. if you flee] will honor me.’ It is often difficult to render the particle without awkwardness, however.

div.head: Subjunctive
div.p: The subjunctive, used in an independent sentence, has a force nearly equivalent to that of the future indicative. It is commonly found in negative sentences (with ou)). E. g. Z 459, kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|sin, ‘and some day men will say.’ A 262, ou) ga/r pw toi/ous i)/don a_)ne/ras ou)de\ i)/dwmai, ... ‘nor shall l see.’

The subjunctive in an independent clause is often accompanied by ke or a)/n. E. g. A 137, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, ‘then I myself will take’ (a prize). A 184, e)gw\ de/ k' a)/gw *bri_shi/da, ‘but I shall [in that case] lead away Briseis.’ A 205, ta/x) a)/n pote qumo\n o)le/ssh|, ‘one day soon he shall lose his life.’ 3.54, ou)k a)/n toi xrai/smh| ki/qaris ta/ te dw=r' *)afrodi/ths, ‘there shall not avail you, then, the lyre and those gifts of Aphrodite.’

As in Attic Greek the subjunctive of the first person, used alone, may express an exhortation. The first person plural is common. Examples of the first person singular are: Z 340, a)ll' a)/ge nu=n e)pi/meinon, a)rh/ia teu/xea du_/w, ... ‘let me put on my armor of war.’ So X 418 and 450. Compare A 26, mh\ ... kixei/w, ‘let me not find’ etc., a threat.

The dubitative or deliberative subjunctive is used in a question of appeal, usually in the first person. An example of the third person is A 150, pw=s ti/s toi pro/frwn e)/pesin pei/qhtai *)axaiw=n, ‘how shall any man of the Achaeans heartily obey your bidding?’

The independent subjunctive is sometimes used with mh/ to express a concern lest something may take place. A wish to avert the object of fear is contained in the construction. See B 195, 16.128, 18.8, with notes.

The dependent subjunctive in a final clause may be accompanied by ke (a)/n). E. g. A 32, a)ll' i)/qi, mh/ m) e)re/qize, saw/teros w(/s ke ne/hai, ... ‘in order that you may go,’ Attic i(/na i(/h|s or something similar. So too B 385. Cf. Attic o(/pws a)/n with the subjunctive.

The dependent subjunctive in protasis may be used without ke or a)/n, both in (a) future conditions and in (b) present general conditions—a use almost unknown to Attic Greek. E. g. (a) A 340 f., ei) ... ge/nhtai (Attic e)a_/n). X 86, ei) ... katakta/nh|. (b) A 80, krei/sswn ga\r basileu/s, o(/te (Attic o(/tan) xw/setai a)ndri\ xe/rhi, ‘for the king is mightier, when he becomes enraged at a man of meaner rank.’ A 163 f., o(ppo/t'(e) ... e)kpe/rsws)(i), for Attic o(po/tan with subjunctive.
1. Examples with ke (a)/n) are: (a) A 128, a)poti_/somen, ai)/ ke/ (Attic e)a_/n) poqi *zeu\s
div.l: dw=|si etc. (b) A 166, h)/n pote ... i(/khtai. *g 25 f., ei)/ per a)\n ...

div.p: The dependent subjunctive is often introduced by ai)/ (ei)/) ke(n), ‘if haply,’ ‘in the hope that,’ ‘on the chance that.’ E. g. A 66 f., ai)/ ken ...
div.l: bou/letai (subjunctive), see § 147. A 207, ai)/ ke pi/qhai, ‘in the hope that you will obey.’ B 72, a)ll' a)/get', ai)/ ke/n pws qwrh/comen ktl., ... ‘in the hope that we may arm’ etc.
div.p: 1. After a secondary tense this subjunctive is commonly changed to the optative. E. g. B 96 ff., e)nne/a de/ sfeas
div.l: sxoi/at'(o) ktl., ... ‘if haply they would refrain from shouting.’

div.p: § 199. After verbs of attention, care, and effort, Homer does not express the aim (as the Attic Greek does) by o(/pws with the future indicative; instead, he regularly uses object clauses (with w(s, o(/pws) containing the subjunctive in the primary sequence, and generally the optative in the secondary sequence. E. g. 3.110, leu/ssei, o(/pws o)/x' a)/rista ... ge/nhtai, ‘he looks to see how the very best result may come.’ B 3 f., mermh/rize ... w(s *)axilh=a
div.l: ti_mh/sai ktl., ‘he considered how he might honor Achilles.’

div.p: But o(/pws with the future indicative occurs (a) in simple relative clauses and (b) in dependent interrogative clauses. E. g. (a) A 136, a)/rsantes kata\ qu_mo/n, o(/pws a)nta/cion e)/stai, ‘suiting [the gift] to my heart, in whatever way it shall be equivalent.’ (b) I 251, fra/zeu, o(/pws *danaoi=sin a)lech/seis kako\n h)=mar, ‘consider how you shall ward from the Danaans the day of evil.’ A 343 f., see note ad locum. (The construction of Od. 1.57, qe/lgei, o(/pws *)iqa/khs e)pilh/setai, is exceptional, in indicating a real purpose.)

div.head: Optative
div.p: The optative without ke or a)/n is common in future (possible) wishes. E. g. A 18, u_(mi=n me\n qeoi\ doi=en ktl., ‘may the gods give to you’ etc. A 42, ti_/seian. B 259, mhke/t'(i) ... e)pei/h, a form of curse. 16.30, mh\ ... la/boi ktl. *s 107, w(s ... a)po/loito ktl.

The optative is sometimes found in present unattained (impossible) wishes also, where Attic Greek uses the imperfect indicative—not an Homeric construction. E. g. 16.722, ai)/q' , o(/son h(/sswn ei)mi/, to/son se/o fe/rteros ei)/hn, ‘oh that I were as much superior to you as I am your inferior!’ (Cf. § 207.)

Impossible wishes are also expressed, as in Attic, by w)/felon, etc., with the present or aorist infinitive. E. g. 3.40, ai)/q' o)/feles a)/gono/s t' e)/menai ktl., ‘oh that you were unborn!’ etc.; so A 415 f.; 3.173; I 698. The imperfect w)/fellon, etc., likewise occurs (Z 350, 18.19, X 481).

The optative may express a concession or mild command. E. g. 3.74, nai/oite *troi/hn, ‘you may dwell in Troy’; cf. 3.257, nai/oimen. 3.255, tw=| de/ ke ni_kh/santi gunh\ kai\ kth/maq' e(/poito, ‘let the woman and the treasures fall to whoever conquers.’ Cf. 24.149, and Xen. Anab. III, 2, 37. This use is probably to be classified under the optative of wish.
The potential optative sometimes occurs without ke or a)/n. E. g. 19.321, ou) me\n ga/r ti kakw/teron a)/llo pa/qoimi ‘for I could suffer nothing worse besides.’

Far more common than the preceding is the potential optative with ke or a)/n, the Attic construction. E. g. 2.12, nu=n ga/r ken e(/loi po/lin eu)rua/guian, ‘for now he may take the broad-wayed city.’ 3.52 f., ou)k a)\n dh\ mei/neias a)rhi/filon *mene/la_on: gnoi/hs x' , oi(/ou ktl. See note.

The potential optative with ke or a)/n is sometimes found referring to present or past time in situations where the Athenians would have used the imperfect or aorist indicative with a)/n—for example, in the conclusion of contrary to fact conditions. The exact translation of such optatives must be determined by the context. Compare the similar use of the optative in present impossible wishes, § 202. E. g. A 232, h)= ga\r a)/n, *)atrei+/dh, nu=n u(/stata lwbh/saio, ‘else, Agamemnon, you would surely have been insolent now for the last time.’ See notes on B 81, yeu=do/s ken fai=men ktl. 3.220, fai/hs ken. 5.311 f.,
kai/ nu/ ken e)/nq' a)po/loito a)/nac a)ndrw=n *ai)nei/a_s,
ei) mh\ a)/r' o)cu\ no/hse ... *)afrodi_/th.

1. In a few instances present contrary to fact conditions, as it would seem, are expressed with the optative in both protasis and apodosis. They are therefore identical in form with the less vivid future. E. g. 9.515-517, and probably 16.71-73, 22.20. See notes.

The dependent potential optative with ke (a)/n) may be introduced by ei), ‘if’; but the Attic construction—without a)/n—is common. E. g. A 60, ei)/ ken qanato/n ge fu/>goimen, ‘if we should possibly escape death,’ equivalent to Attic ei) ru/goimen, protasis of the less vivid future condition.

The dependent optative is found in indirect questions, in the secondary sequence. E. g. 3.316 f.,
klh/rous ... pa/llon
o(ppo/teros dh\ pro/sqen a)fei/h xa/lkeon e)/gxos ‘they shook lots [to see] which of the two should first hurl his bronze spear’; here a)fei/h represents a deliberative subjunctive of the direct question, a)fh/h| (Attic a)fh=|).
The optative of indirect discourse, representing the indicative of direct discourse, is almost unknown in the simple epic dialect. Examples are rare and are nearly all confined to the Odyssey.

div.head: Infinitive
div.p: The more familiar uses of the infinitive as nominative and as accusative (in Homer always without the article), and in indirect discourse, being common to both Attic and Homeric Greek, need no special comment.

The infinitive is commonly explanatory and often expresses purpose. This meaning as well as that mentioned in § 212 is a survival of an original dative force—the “to” or “for” relation of a verbal noun in the dative case to other words in the sentence. Such infinitives are found in Homer after verbs, nouns, adjectives, and adverbs. E. g. A 338, kai/ sfwin do\s a)/gein, ‘and give her to these two to lead [i. e. ‘for leading’] away.’ 18.83, etc., qau=ma i)de/sqai, ‘a marvel to behold.’ A 107, fi/la ... manteu/esqai, ‘dear to prophesy.’ 24.662 f.
thlo/qi d' u_(/lh a)ce/men, ‘and the wood is far to bring.’ Cf. notes on A 589 and Z 460.

The infinitive sometimes expresses result, although it is often impossible to dissociate the idea of purpose, too. E. g. A 8, ti/s t' a)/r sfwe qew=n e)/ridi cune/hke ma/xesqai; ‘who then of the gods brought these two together in strife to contend?’

The infinitive is often used with the force of an imperative in commands, prayers, and decrees. E. g. A 20, pai=da d' e)moi\ lu=sai/ te fi/lhn ta/ t' a)/poina de/xesqai, ‘set free my dear child, and accept this ransom.’ A 582, su\ to/n ge ... kaqa/ptesqai, ‘do you address him.’ So too A 323, a)ge/men. B 413, mh\ pri_\n h)e/lion du=nai kai\ e)pi\ kne/fas e)lqei=n, ‘let not the sun set and darkness come on before’ etc. 3.285, *trw=as e)/peiq' *(ele/nhn kai\ kth/mata pa/nt' a)podou=nai, ‘then let the Trojans give back Helen and all the treasures.’
